column3: A corner of paradise, tainted by some of the worst pollution on Earth.

column2: I think I'd find it a little bit redundant to postpone them entirely. Unfortunately I'm still a little salty my hometown wasn't picked, but nonetheless Brazil does and will have its problems. Postponing the olympics won't change that. If they could somehow be relocated to a more suitable location, I'd be fine with that (wink)
column3: It's redundant to postpone them. Brazil's problems won't go away if they postpone the Olympics.

column2: Holding the games in Brazil is pure insanity. Zika and dengue fever are out of control. The Olympic committee expects swimmers to compete in an open sewer. Participants and fans will be risking their health, and the health of their families and even their future children, to attend these games, and also risk the health of their home countries upon return. All so that NBC & the olympic committee can make big bucks. It's not worth it.
column3: The Olympics should be postponed because of ZIka and dengue fever concerns. The swimmers shouldn't have to swim in toxic water. Attending the Olympics will risk the health of participants and fans as well as their families and entire countries.

column2: Home school is good thing. I've had great success in the classroom at the college level with home school students. Sports is not academics. There seems to be some value in permitting home school students to play sports from the social development perspective. As far as competition is concerned. A more appropriate mix of academics and competition is interscholastic speech competition (forensics and debate) and chess. These activities mix competition and academics much better. In fact, I believe funding for the above activities should be equal to sports. They also serve title nine objectives and should be counted as interscholastic competition activity, just like sports in competitive activity with some thinking taking place.
column3: Sports are not academics. Sports can help home-schooled children improve their social skills. Mixing academics and competition is good for all students.

column2: School sports teams should consist of kids who attend that school, not those who are home schooled or who attend private schools. Home schooling is a choice and choices have consequences. There are kids sports leagues not affiliated with any school (at least here in California) and those are the leagues home schooled kids should be playing for.
column3: School sports teams should only have players who attend the school. Home schooling is up to the parents, and is a choice with consequences. Home schooled children can participate in non-affiliated sports leagues.

column2: Nick, homeschooled kids are part of society. They just don't go to public school, same as private school kids. In my state, the state athletic organization that oversees high school sports created guidelines for homeschooler participation in high school sports. They must meet academic and other requirements that enrolled kids must meet, but as long as they do, they are eligible. The overseeing organization realized that excluding homeschoolers was indeed discriminatory, and set about creating a system within which they could participate. In other states, there are laws on the books that require schools to allow homeschoolers to participate in school activities. My daughter was very involved in sports, and very talented at it, and she took advantage of both elite leagues and her high school teams (she was an enrolled student, not a homeschooler). The elite leagues are available to those who can make the teams, true, and most serious athletes participate in them. It's the lack of programs for the average kid after the age of 14 that's a problem. Also, even those who can make the elite teams can't always afford the fees.
column3: Kids that are homeschooled are still people. It is right for home-schoolers to play for high school sports teams if they meet the same academic and other requirements for enrolled kids. In some states, there are laws that require school to allow homeschoolers to participate in activities. Many sports leagues are available for students who can make them especially if they are serious.

column2: It seems to me home schoolers willfully separate themselves from the community to a certain degree. If they wanted to benefit from the community, such as participating in public school student activities, then maybe they shouldn't be trying to remain separate from it.
column3: Their desire to separate themselves from the educational community should also separate them from student activities.

column2: i agree with these article because home-schooled children should have the right to play sports and venger into sports that they like. they should be allowed to play in sports teams to not only be active and do something they like but to also socially inneract with teamates. it would give them an oppurtunity to enjoy the sports and company of others around them. they pay school tax funds so they should have the right to play school sports and have a chance to further their abilities in the sport of their choice. just like tim tebow they chould become sports stats as well. why give up a chance like that?
column3: Home-schooled children should have access to sports as well as public school children. Playing with high school teams allows home-schoolers to have more social interaction. Home schooled kids could enjoy sports and company of others around them. They have paid for the right through taxes and deserve the chance to further their athletic abilities.

column2: when kids are homeschool they dont interact with people as much as a public school kid would. I think thats a really good idea. If every public school had that program that would give kids a chance to get to know kids that like football and that are from differnt cultures.
column3: Home schooled children do not interact with other students as much as non home school children. Home-schoolers should play for high school teams because it would allow such kids to get a chance to interact with other kids who like football and are from different cultures.

column2: It amazes me that what is best for children seems not to be part of this discussion. Why wouldn't we want as many children as possible to be able to participate in high school athletics? We all know the benefits of sports for kids, why would we want to deny home-schooled kids these same benefits just because they are doing their academic work outside of the classroom?
column3: All children should be able to participate in sports. We should not deny home-schooled kids the benefits of playing sports just because they are doing their academic work outside of the classroom.

column2: I think not. They and their parents make the decision not to be a part of the classroom experience. Those reasons do not disappear after class. Team sports is just that, being a part of the team. That means being in the Class Room, in the school activities. Showing up for practice and the games is only a small part of being a team player.
column3: Parents have made the choice not to be involved with public schools. Being part of a team is more than practice and games.

column2: Well, I think the home schoolers who live in my nearby neighborhood should be able to get together and form their own Homeschooler Hornets team and then play the Homeschooler Hamsters across town. To let them play against a real high school team would then open the door for them to ask for helmets and shoulder pads to be provided at no cost to them, school bus transport to their games, etc.
column3: Homeschoolers should be self-reliant and organize their own leagues. The home schooler might want the school to pay for their gear and transportation.

column2: My daughter would LOVE to be able to opt in and out of classes at the Virginia public high school she attends. Personally, I would LOVE to be able to pull her out of certain classes and get her tutored in them or some such. But that's now how it works. If her high school is not good enough for these kids to attend, then they have no business being there playing sports. It is not a cafeteria, you don't get to pick and choose what you do and do take off the tray. Why don't we just take team sports out of the schools and make them a separate institution? Certainly a lot of the folks who are gung ho on their local high school football and basketball programs don't give much of a damn about the academics of those students anyway so long as they can have a winning team. Let's set up something elsewhere and let the rest of our kids concentrate on getting an education that will enable them to do something besides playing sports!
column3: Why should kids be able to play at a school that they feel is not good enough to learn at?. Those choosing to home school should not be allowed to just take what they want from public education.

column2: Where do we go with this? If families who don't believe in public schools can enjoy the athletic privileges, why not someone who doesn't believe in education period? Why shouldn't a dropout be able to play football? Or, for that matter, someone who wants to attend one school but wants to play ball at another? The far right loves to rail at what they see as narcissism and elitism, but they never recognize it in themselves. This is a matter of someone opting out of the community effort, stating by their actions that they are better than the riffraff, yet demanding participation in the only thing that they think the public schools are good at. These people are basically saying to the community, "You aren't smart, you aren't good enough to teach my kid, but I will admit that you are good at athletics, so we want in on that part of it." If this doesn't disgust you, fine, no one's gonna die. But it is yet another reminder that we will never be a community as long as groups of people don't want any part of a shared effort.
column3: Families who don't believe in public schools may enjoy athletic privileges, why not someone who doesn't believe in education?. The parents should not be able to reject the public school system and then demand the athletics system for their use because they like that part. Home schoolers are not part of the community.

column2: Why would a kid who attends a public school and plays for one of its teams want to, or have to, give up a spot on the roster, or even their position, to a kid who doesn't attend their school? Why would a team of kids who may have played together, hung out together, studied together, taken the school bus together, eaten lunch together, for a number of years want to welcome a kid who they may only see at practice onto their team? Why shouldn't a talented kid who goes to a school with particularly weak athletic program and/or facilities be able to join a team from a school in another part of the city or county that has a great athletic program and/or facilities? Should public schools be allowed to set up a draft for home-schooled free agent athletes? And so on.
column3: A public school student who plays on a team could be forced out of his position or off the roster by a home school student. A homeschooled child won't be a part of the social group because they are not a part of the entire school life. If home schooled children get to pick a high school sports team high school kids will want to be able to play for other schools.

column2: Yes, Steve. That's just how it works. My kids have been part time enrolled students at the local high school. They've taken chemistry and French, theater and music. They've been in marching band, color guard, acting, and chess teams as homeschooled kids. Homeschooling means the parents determine what educational tools best serve the interests of their kids. Savvy school districts happily include home educated kids when they can facilitate that education. It's worked wonderfully for us, in West Chester Ohio.
column3: School should facilitate sports education for home-schoolers. Has worked  quite well in West Chester Ohio.

column2: Seems it would be good for the children of folks who have rejected being a part of society to be exposed to the children of normal people no matter how it happens. Being brought up in the paranoid bunker without exposure to the outside world can lead to a warped world view. There were things I did not like about our public schools but the kids will have to swim in the big pond sooner or later. Better they learn to do it sooner.
column3: It would offer homeschooled children a chance to be exposed to wider branches of society. Great experience for home-schoolers to navigate in the bigger world.

column2: This idea is absurd. If a child's parents choose to home school him or her, that seems a clear choice to remove one's family from the life of the school, including its extracurricular programs. How about the home-schooled students play on teams of home-schooled students? Or perhaps individuals could compete in solo sports against other home-schooled individuals. Their parents could make the effort to create their own league, or have their children participate in community-based or private recreational or competitive leagues. The taxpayer argument does not hold water. People without children-as well as commercial property owners who live outside the district where their business is located-must pay local property taxes without receiving the benefits of sending their own children to that school. Moreover, as far as I know, most schools' indoor facilities (libraries, gyms, pools, and so on) are not open for the general use of taxpayers who live within the boundaries of particular school systems. Outdoor tracks are probably the exception.
column3: Children who are home schooled should not be allowed to selectively participate in school activities, like extracurricular programs. Everyone else must pay taxes into the school system whether they use it or not and if they do not they receive nothing in return. Home-schoolers and other residents not enrolled in the public school are not be permitted to use schools' indoor facilities.

column2: I was home-schooled, and so I sympathize with the plight of home-schoolers without adequate athletic competition. However there are at least two strong arguments against home-schoolers' inclusion (and against the tax payer argument) that none of the debaters brought up: 1) Private school families also pay taxes and yet may not try out for public school teams 2) Public schools only get funds based upon enrollment. Thus opting out, depriving schools of the funds for your enrollment, and then demanding services from them anyway, is unfair. Why did no debaters bring these up? Am I mistaken? I suppose the only reason it's even considered is the opportunity for competitive advantage to the school. If they were demanding inclusion in art class, I doubt it would be on the table.
column3: Public schools earn their funding by the number of students who are actually enrolled, therefore, anyone who doesn't enroll should not get to use services paid for with that money.

column2: Home schooled young people should be allowed to participate in after-school activities in their home district school, but I fail to see the relevance of the fact that their parents pay local taxes. In most communities a majority of taxpayers have no children in grades 7-12 and thus no participation in after-school activities.
column3: Although they do not learn in the classroom they should be able to participate in after school activities.

column2: People make a choice to send their kids to public school private school or to home school them. I'm all for it. I'm also all for people making a decision and living by it. No public school? No public school sports, social events, etc. Part of being an adult is knowing that making choices does not include "all I want is all there is".
column3: If you didn't go to a public school you shouldn't get to participate in there sports or events. Adults should know that making choices doesn't mean that all you want is all there is.

column2: It does not matter that parents who home school may pay just as much into the school system as other families. People without children pay as well and don't think this authorizes them to use the library or recreational facilities. In addition, supporting a school is not just about paying taxes. Parents who home school because they don't think public schools are good enough for their offspring weaken the very fabric of the public school system and should not seek to benefit from it. If it's not good enough for English and Math, it's not good enough for sports. (Of course, this should not apply to children who are home schooled because of special needs.)
column3: School support does not just come from tax dollars. Parents who withdraw their children from public school because they think it's not good enough end up weakening the system and therefor should not benefit from it. If the parents do not like the way the schools operate they should not be allowed to take what they do like.

column2: There are layers upon layers of sports organizations that accommodate home schooled kids - high school varsity should not be one of them. These kids have the opportunity to compete athletically in local recreation leagues, travel teams, AAU teams, and elite regional teams. High school sports should be about building athletic excellence and also about developing a sense of pride and comraderie in a placef that's that's truly the center of their existence for 4 short years. After all, should we then allow kids in private schools, boarding schools, or local religious schools to compete for varsity spots in their local public school? After they all pay taxes, but what do the school colors really mean to them?
column3: Many layers of sports organizations accommodate home schooled kids. Home schooled kids can compete in local, travel, AAU, and elite sports leagues instead. High school is an important place for 4 years and it is about the pride and camaraderie of those attending. Like private school, boarding school, and religious school students, home schooled students might pay taxes, but the school colors are not meaningful to them.

column2: The main reason educators argue against home schooling is because it works. It works so well, they have designed the system to work against the parents who chooses to become a primary educator to their own children. The legislators' should embrace the parent's decision and remove legislative road blocks that would hinder and disrespect a parent's unique role in their children's lives. I believe this is called progress in the right direction. One way to overcome this obstacle with sports would be a standardized test that would allow public and homeschooled students to participate in all extra curriculum activities without any bias or discriminatory practices. As it is now, home schooled students are being discriminated against.
column3: Homeschooling is a unique role for parents in their children's lives and there shouldn't be laws that punish those who choose to go that path. Standardized testing can be given to allow both public and home schooled children to play sports together without any bias towards anyone. Home schoolers are discriminated against when they can't play sports.

column2: In previous times the Virginia High School League did not let black high school students play sports. It is interesting that it took 16 years after Brown vs. the Board of Education to integrate schools. Perhaps homeschoolers may be able to overcome the prejudice as well. 24 States currently permit homeschoolers to participate in high school sports. If the Virgnia High School League had its way perhaps black athletes would not be in high school sports now.
column3: If they play for high school team maybe they can overcome the prejudice of being home schooled. Homeschoolers should play sports because 24 states already allow that.

column2: How about children who live in the district but attend private schools? Should they be allowed to play? What if their private school doesn't have a football team, or they don't make the team? Presumably their parents pay taxes; should they get to try out for the public school team? Home-schooled children do NOT attend the school. It is a school team. They should not participate. Should home-schooled children get to participate in the spelling bee, robotics club, science olympiad? in Michigan, public schools receive a certain amount of money for each child who enrolls, not a lump sum based on how many parents pay taxes. These schools should not have to use their budgets to pay for opportunities for children who are not enrolled and, therefore, do not bring dollars to pay for their education or other opportunities the school provides.
column3: Since it is a school team, home-schooled children should not participate. If children aren't enrolled in the school and bringing financial gains to it, they should not be permitted to play sports there.

column2: To JeffB Well, Rachel raised great questions that got attention - great. This is what this debate is about. I am quoting you: "Controlling prostitution at the level of the prostitute is like controlling drugs at the level of the junkie." This statement (on the GRE or LSAT) would not pass a stress test on logic, regardless of sides, as there is a missing correlation - business of prostitution similar to business of drug trafficking (missing piece). Great focus on demand! So, we get help for the junkie, indeed. All addicts need help for the addiction, including the sex junkie. So, do we legalize prostitution so the level of sex addiction that will always be with us becomes abundantly clear? No - because the consumption of women, as flesh and blood drug, is a form of cannibalism. Not all of us against prostitution are of the 'Christian majorities' - some of us survived serial killers and are trying to get a word out. Imagine that.
column3: Controlling prostitution is like controlling drugs to the junkie. All addicts need help for the addiction, including the sex junkie. Do we legalize prostitution, so sex addiction that will always be with us?. The consumption of women is a form of cannibalism.

column2: So does the article suggest that if a woman chooses to work as a prostitute, then working conditions will improve? So much of what we're learning about prostitution is that it is a job that is forced upon a woman/girl for financial gain, and that the prostitute is not the one who fully benefits from the money.
column3: Prostitution is not any safer when it is legal.

column2: I am currently a legal prostitute at the Moonlite Bunnyranch. Making prostitution legal everywhere would help to decrease not only the spread of STD's and help stop sex slavery. Laws making prostitution a crime aren't stopping people from entering the sex industry, regulation is truly the only answer.
column3: Legal prostitution will lead to a reduction in STD's and make sex slavery more difficult it has been shown that legality does not stop the sex industry from existing.

column2: Prostitution is harmful and dehumanizing and encourages modern day slavery which is Human trafficking. If legalized, we will be providing a much larger opportunity for traffickers to exploit more victims. This is what many people do not understand and need to be educated in.
column3: Prostitution is harmful, dehumanizing, and encourages modern day slavery. Legalized prostitution opens the doors for sex trafficking.

column2: Should be legal. Sex work - oldest profession - is not going away. Reduces AIDS and STDs when controlled. Half the celebrities are sex workers of sorts selling their bodies so why not the ones who actually have sex be allowed. Not everyone wants to do that. It has a strange effect on the psyche of women. An act made for bonding and love done with people you dont like - messes with the mind.
column3: Prostitution has been around a long time, and will not go away. It reduces STD's. Half of the celebrities sell their bodies so it should be legal to actually sell sex.

column2: On the island of Curacao legal prostitution has been there since I was a tiny toddler there (60 years now). That place, Campo Alegre (or Happy Place), was always bussy and always gleaming reports from indeed happy locals and tourists (Americands included - they were more than just happy; they went nuts). No diseases and within walking distance from the airport. Same health security in places like Amsterdam, Hamburg, etc. Grow up America.
column3: Campo Alegre had booming business and wonderful reviews from Americans. It should have the same health security as places like Amsterdam and Hamburg.

column2: I strongly disagree with the author's characterization of prostitution, but strongly agree with the author's suggestion of what to do about it. Prostitutes are most certainly allowed to say no to unwanted sex. It is only because the current system within which prostitution operates has so disempowered prostitutes -- leaving them vulnerable to both their clients, their employers, and the law -- that their wishes are so easily disregarded. If the prostitution laws were reversed so that it is the johns and the pimps, not the prostitutes, who commit the crime, then prostitutes would have much greater power to avoid unwanted sexual contact and violence, and perhaps a much better chance of getting out of the business altogether.
column3: Prostitutes have a choice as to whether to have sec. The current system causes prostitutes to be unable to control their work and safety.

column2: I believe working in a legal brothel cuts down on violence and abuse.Here we are safe and here by choice.People that come here are also safe we are tested weekly and all sex is protected and safe.In a legal establishment keeps girls off the streets and away from abusive pimps. I have been working in a legal brothel for about 6 months and I am happy here.
column3: Workers in legal brothels are safe and there by choice where violence and abuse are minimized. Legal prostitutes are tested providing a safer interaction. Legal establishments reduce the dangers of prostitution. Working in a legal brothel makes prostitutes happier.

column2: We've seen how a wild west approach with no laws works - abused children and adults get exploited. At least with a legal system there are some checks and balances to protect the workers, satisfy demand, and ensure a safe work environment for adults. With a legal path, there's an incentive to play by the rules. Those who continue to operate outside of the laws - the traffickers and child abusers - have less cover from the laws and those who enforce them.
column3: Abused children and adults get exploited under a "prostitution is illegal" regime. Prostitution being legal only stops arrest not diseases and murderers. Legalization of prostitution will bring order to an uncontrolled system.

column2: Legalizing prostitution and cracking down on trafficking are not mutually exclusive. The increased traffic in Amsterdam comes from the fact that it is just one such city and attracts men from all over. If prostitution was legal in every country in Europe this would not happen. Does prostitution dehumanize women? Absolutely. But until we get rid of it, legalization does, in theory, offer protections that doesn't currently exist.
column3: Legalizing prostitution will not necessarily reduce trafficking. if prostitution were legal all over Europe there wouldn't be so much traffic to Amsterdam for prostitution. By legalizing prostitution, it can provide safeguards and protections.

column2: Violence is inherent in the sex industry only in the same way that criminality is inherent in business in Russia. All private business in Russia was illegal under communism, so when communism fell, the first and strongest entrants were people from criminal backgrounds who had already been engaging in it illegally. They have not yet lost control; not enough time has passed. Similarly, because prostitution has been illegal in many places, even where it has become legal, there is a tendency for it to initially be dominated by the sometimes violent pimps who prevailed when it was illegal. As time passes, in large areas where it is fully legal, it will become less dominated by the criminal element and less violent (although it will never cease to be unpleasant in other ways).
column3: Because prostitution has been illegal, it tends to be dominated by often violent pimps. Legal prostitution will over time remove the violence and criminal element.

column2: Numerous studies show that between 70 percent and 90 percent of children and women who end up in commercial sex were sexually abused prior to entry. The author seems to imply that if there were no sex workers, all of these people would not have suffered abuse. The problem of abuse came before the activity of prostitution. Abuse leads to prostitution, not the other way around. Banning prostitution will do nothing to prevent abuse, and abuse is the real problem, not commercial sex. I see no valid argument that legalizing prostitution would prevent prior abuse of women and children. It could be bettered argued that if there were legal outlets for sexual urges, cases of abuse would decline.
column3: Abuse will exist even without legal prostitution. Prostitution doesn't lead to abuse, it's the other way around. Banning prostitution does nothing to prevent the real problem, abuse. Abuse could decline if prostitution were legal.

column2: The unacknowledged advantage of privileging 'starchitects'' over the local talents is that the first come with a set of standards, a rigorous vocabulary and a name that prevail over the compromises usually inherent in a developer-driven culture (cost cuts, value-engineering, the client's 'taste', etc. - whatever could damage a project from the design phase to the actual built outcome). If one looks objectively, disregarding personal taste, whether it is a Gehry, a Nouvel or Isozaki building here in New York - they all stand out as impeccably executed architecture. Most of them relate to their context (see the formal empathy between the Beekman Tower and Woolworth Building, for instance), or creating a new one where such context is either weak or lacks character. It is a welcomed fad that reinstates the lost 'edge' New York once had, and subliminally educates both the developers' taste and the local crop of professional talents. Why should we be afraid of that?...
column3: Starchitects adhere to a more rigorous set of industry standards than do local architects. If you don't judge by personal taste, New York has amazing architecture. Starchitects are a welcomed fad that reinstate the lost "edge" New York once had.  Starchitects educate both the developers' taste and local professional talents.

column2: Having left NYC many years ago, I eventually came to live in a city of 40,000 that through the generosity of a patron secured the talents of the mid 20th century 'starchitects' and prominent firms. Today this small city and its architectural treasures is an international destination for those interested in architecture. Other than the large cities, where else can you find a collection of work by Saarinen, Venturi, Pei, Meier, Polshek, Stern, S.O.M., Pelli, Weese, Gwathmy, Barnes, The Architects Collaborative and sculptors like Henry Moore, Jon Tinguely, Chihuli. Obviously, none were local.
column3: A small city with architectural treasures can become an international destination for architecture aficionados. Work from the Architects Collaborative and sculptors, which includes many well-known names, have enhanced large cities.

column2: I am a retired HS media specialist and I am still asked all the time to help people find things on the Internet. My HS age granddaughter needs help evaluating reference material. Example: Why not depend on Wikipedia only? Libraries and the Internet work together and a library can't exist on its own. Without a person in the facility to keep it going and to teach students its value, it will die. Teacher or media specialist is not the issue. We need to support public education fully. That means teachers, the arts, sports, and the Media Center.
column3: Libraries need faculty to teach it's value to students to keep them open.

column2: As a former network and radio communications specialist for the U.S. Army and a small network administrator, I believe that I can say with confidence that I agree, eliminating librarians so that they can be replaced by technology is a gross diseconomy. First, the school board must be forgetting about the fixed costs of maintaining a library. Second, there is a complete neglect for the fact checking costs. Third, current technology costs are prohibitive; the school board's enthusiasm about the power of technology, though understandable, is misplaced. Then, there are the children themselves to be considered. What level of confidence will these children be able to have in the integrity of their resource material without a person to person interaction that will be able to uncover the specific focus and the nature of the child's, or the adolescent's, inquiry. That alone should be reason enough to reconsider.
column3: School boards may forget about maintenance costs for libraries. The costs to replace school librarians with technology is prohibitive. Without a person to person interaction, what level of confidence will these children be able to have in the integrity of their resource material? They'll be unable to uncover the specific focus and the nature of the child's, or the adolescent's inquiry.

column2: The reason school administrators are reviewing library budgets in light of new technology is because they themselves are mostly confused about new technology-and all too few of them have ever had much insight into what librarians do in schools. Too many school administrators, and subject teachers too, think of the library as the baby sitting department. Meanwhile, the librarians-who are usually the only professionals in the school with notable training in research methods-go along quietly, educating students about how to tell a source from a delusion. The web has made that need more acute, not less. Good quality school administrators know that, but they are few and far between.
column3: Librarians are usually the only professionals able to teach students to recognize credible sources of information.

column2: Easy access to relevant and accurate information is a cornerstone in our democracy. How can we not have specialists (aka librarians) who find, catalog, index, and protect the information used by all of us? We all frequently rely on specialists - medical, technical, financial, etc. - for the best information and advice. In this exploding universe of digital information, let's encourage our academic and governmental decision makers to fully realize the critical and specialized value that librarians provide to patrons of all ages.
column3: Democracies need easy access to information. Librarians find, catalog, index, and protect information used by everyone. Specialists are relied on for advice. We must encourage our decision makers to realize the value that librarians provide even in the digital age.

column2: My high school librarian was wonderful. She was at my 50th high school reunion two years ago, no longer able to see, alas, but still the lively, alert, aware person she was years ago. It seems to me that this isn't a question of ebooks replacing paper books as one commenter seems to imply. Nor is it a question of whether or not "internet access" is the same thing, as another comment states. Reading an ebook is a skill, and a different skill from reading a paper book. Using the internet efficiently and critically is also a learned skill. Google and Wikipedia are not the beginning and end. These skills need teaching--skilled teaching. Librarians have the skills to do this, and they have the heart and mission to do this, and they have the love of patrons of the library to do this. So let's not suggest that a visit "once a month or so" is the equivalent of a human being available down the hall daily.
column3: Librarians are not expendable because there is more to learning than digital format. Librarians have the ability to teach a special skill set to those who come to their buildings and they generally have the love of their job to do just that.

column2: I was a library aide in elementary school, for Mrs Archer, who treated both books and people with respect. I still have the dictionary she gave me at the end of sixth grade, when I moved up to junior high school, and another library. Mrs Archer and Mrs DeVoll, who ran the public library branch in my neighborhood, were both a huge part of my life as a child -- I am incredibly grateful to them and to all their colleagues, and am thrilled to have this chance to recognize them here, among their peers.
column3: Public librarians can be important to people's lives.

column2: If lawmakers don't (can't) recognize the contributions librarians make to the endless need for researching good answeres to questions that arise in all arenas of life, no wonder our politicians are so lame-brained loser-lunkheads. I want lawmakers to have close ties to competent research librarians. I want lawmakers to research, seriously research, the matters they vote on. Without librarians providing RELIABLE data, a lawmaker is voting based on guess, bias and campaign donations.
column3: Librarians make contributions by way of researching in all arenas. Librarians provide quality data but politicians are using inappropriate influences to make the decision to remove them.

column2: Librarians might find some protection if they were to get back in the classroom and teach a course for credit on research methods. Most school librarians are already certified teachers, so this would not be a difficult transition. Librarians are involved in classroom instruction, but usually in the classroom of another teacher. Let's get research skills or information literacy into the mandated curriculum and protect our kids' libraries and librarians.
column3: Many school librarians are already certified teachers. Librarians are important because they are secondary instructors for other classes and they add research skills and information literacy to the curriculum.

column2: As a school librarian who enjoys working with our local public library system, I think there is a lot to be said for looking at ways for the two to work together more closely to best serve our students, not as a cost-saving measure. Can we deliver better service and aid student achievement by joining up more effectively? But while there is overlap in the goals of public and school libraries, they have a different focus in their staffing and services. In addition, as teachers are asked to do more and more, a school librarian is able to support THEIR training needs and those of students to provide instruction and resources that match their curricular needs. The school librarian provides a fantastic value, reaching every single child and staff member in a school - every program, teacher, administrator, and students of every background and ability are served. Talk about bang for your buck!
column3: Too much is asked of teachers. School librarians provide support and resources to help students. The school librarian's role touches all teachers and students and affects every program in a positive way.

column2: It seems that many of the comments in this thread are from educators who are in the classroom, face to face with students every day, as am I. My experience teaching students to use the Internet and do efficient, objective research runs the gamut from those who easily learn techniques for evaluating and validating information to those who can be convinced that President Lincoln was actually a female based on a ridiculous edited photo and a headline on a tabloid from the grocery store! My advice to politicians, policy makers, and pundits is to spend a few days in a school, in Mr. Wurman's case with certified Library Media Specialist, and see what is really going on. The problem with schools today is not the teachers, it is the decision makers who think they know what is good for students because they once went to school.
column3: The internet is full of things which can fool impressionable students, some learn easily, while other will be fooled. The politicians and policy makers should spend time with librarians before removing the position.

column2: I have to agree with Wurman to the extent that "If we are to have any hope of meaningfully increasing the literacy of our students, the solution must lie with classroom teachers and not with libraries and librarians." What he neglects to include, however, is how important the school librarian can be in ensuring that teachers have the necessary resources and skills to work with students in improving literacy. Keeping abreast of literature and new technologies that will meet the needs of the wide range of learning styles and abilities within one school is a yeoman's job. To expect the classroom teacher to be that expert without support is once again expecting too much from teachers, leading to many leaving the profession. A school librarian, if the right one is hired, can be the school leader in information resource management and use.
column3: Librarians ensure teachers have the necessary resources. School librarians are a gate keeper to knowledge and are necessary to keep students informed of all of the ways to search for information needed to complete their studies. It puts too much pressure on teachers to have to fill yet another role. A librarian can lead the school in information resource management and use.

column2: When every document ever written has been digitized and available without charge on the internet, then one may argue that libraries with physical books are not needed. Old, even ancient, literature is just as important for research as recent literature. During my PhD research in chemistry in the 1950s I had to refer to work from the 1850s. My university did not have these in their library because they were so old. The research institute where I ended up working most of my career would not have had this work because the originators thought that only work produced after 1925 was relevant. (Someone convinced them otherwise.) There you have the gamut of poor thinking about libraries.
column3: Even when all knowledge and documents are electronic, librarians will still be needed. School librarians research insitute.

column2: I am sorry but I agree. I love books and libraries. However, my kid being in elementary school, and having Library as special subject (along with music, gym, art, computers), I often think he better had a foreign language or something else instead of Library. The teachers already teach regularly the students about books and authors, and help them in this domain, in addition to very accessible local libraries and children librarians.
column3: School teachers perform the duties that libraries are expected too perform, and thus libraries are redundant.

column2: The entire issue then seems to one of inadequate funding and sometimes inability to even do the job. A short while ago we made great strides in reducing average class sizes at least for K-3. Now all those gains have evaporated in the crucible of 'can't afford any new taxes.' We are raising a huge number of kids who don't/can't read and certainly cannot write.
column3: The issue with school libraries seems to be inadequate funding and inability to do the job. A large number of children cannot read or write.

column2: One of the most crucial reasons that education from K-12 in this country is so bad are activists and aspiring politicians who run for School Boards and prevent people who have the interest and learning to keep the schools funded and educating students well from serving on the Boards. These people are out to attract attention to their pet projects, gripes, transformative visions, and general ego promoting activities which will help them advance and to excel. They basically keep the students in their districts from gaining the educations which they need to excel. Being an activist is a big ego boost but it making a difference means giving up one's ego and just making the dull and banal the focus of one's efforts.
column3: Activists have been infiltrating school boards and preventing those who can actually run a school from being able to serve on the boards. When activists try to be politicians it is clear they are only pursuing their own narrow objectives and visions, just to stroke their own ego. They keep students from gaining the education in which they need to excel. Being a successful activist means putting one's career second.

column2: Activists run for elected office and are elected frequently, and they advocate for their causes just like every politician advocates for something. They usually accomplish their purposes and sometimes what they introduce actually remains after they leave office. As public servants they tend to be focused upon their core constituents and their core issues and tend to trivialize the concerns which do not relate to them. They really feel that the day to day concerns of people who they formally represent but really do not wish to bother worrying about do not matter or can be ignored as they follow their passions. One of the reasons that so many people feel alienated by politicians is the way local politicians are preoccupied with causes and special interests.
column3: Activists push for their causes when elected as all politicians do. Activists do what they set out to do and some effects are lasting. They are more focused on core issues.

column2: RC is right. What if a public employee even publishes a comment supporting the right to burn the Koran on the New York Times website? Does that mean the government should fire him or her? This dangerous precedent will lead to the stifling of free expression and censorship throughout the country.
column3: Limiting the speech of public workers stifles expression and promotes censorship.

column2: Why is this such an important issue? Muslims should be sensible, diplomatic in their thoughts & actions; and not let this or any similar acts to be used as provocation. Let them burn a few Koran - heck, let them burn a few million copies. Burning some Korans certainly wouldn't weaken Islam. And didn't Allah said that "I have sent you 'The Book' and I will protect it"? So why are we so threatened by some misguided acts of a few ignorant people and let the detractors sully Islam's name? On another note, the transit worker should not have been fired. It was a private, non-violent act, and if it gave him peace of mind let him have it. Muslims should even urge the transit authority to reinstate him. And it should be remembered that if we gladly accept that denying of someone's right to free expression now out of expediency; then we must also be prepared to accept the same fate in future.
column3: The worker's act caused no harm and should be allowed. If speech is allowed to be suppressed for public workers than we may suffer the same fate later.

column2: Looking at the violence carried out in response to the mere concept of "International Burn a Koran Day" and before that with "Everybody Draw Muhammad Day" and before that with the publication of a few caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad in a Danish news paper: One could make the argument that the followers of the so-called "Religion of Peace" are so inherently violent as to make any speech which is deemed an insult to Islam tantamount to yelling "fire" in a crowded theater. If we allow ourselves to do this, then what we have essentially said is that constitution is incompatible with world wide Islam.
column3: By limiting a public workers free speech and allowing Islam to use the threat of violence to silence opposition, then we show that our constitution is not compatible with Islamic views.

column2: The Government has no business controlling its workers' free speech on religoius matters during off-hoursand to attempt to do so amounts to government endorsement of which religious practices are acceptable. This is easily demonstrable -- as follows: A person is an adherent to a new religion. This religion believes that the holy books of three large monotheistic religions, Judaism, Christianity and Islam, have been corrupted, have errors and therefore must be cleansed. The required cleansing is done by fire. Each Sabbath, adherents must burn one page of each of the holy books for these faiths. It is a bona-fide belief helf by adherents to this faith. If the government prevents them from conducting their cleansing ceremony because others are offended, then it is clearly taking sides on what does and does not constitute acceptable religous beliefs and practices.
column3: Workers' off-hours religious speech should not be controlled or limited by government. You cannot decide what is and is not acceptable religious belief.

column2: I agree that legislation neither can nor should alter one's intellectual disposition (or demonstrated deficiency thereof), but what is the cumulative, aggregate effect of such a hands-off approach from our government when the media is so actively involved in pursuit of the polar opposite: informing citizens' views, fertilizing nascent biases with clever sound bites, punditry and selective editing, and even stoking flames of [fill in the blank] - all the while protected by the First Amendment? The result is a two-way mirror, with the citizen - Quran burning or not - sitting in the interrogation room, too comfortable in his or her biases or just too dumb to question the reflection before them.
column3: Limiting speech is a two way mirror with a citizen being too comfortable in his or her biases or too dumb to question what they see.

column2: But I certainly would fire any of my employees who would consider flag-burning as an act of defiance. It's not. It's childish and immature behavior, and those who would do such a thing would be unworthy of public employment. Actually, I once told my wife that if an amendment were actually passed banning flag-burning, I would burn one the next day on the steps of the Supreme Court. It's not necessarily an act of childish defiance; it can be an all-in statement of what is important about this country. By the way, flag-burning is required by law. Last time I looked, it was the only proper way to dispose of a flag too worn to be flown any more.
column3: Their speech isn't childish, it is their personal belief of what is important in this country.

column2: As I Muslim, let me say that I am glad that Salam Al-Marayati is not my boss. That the head of MPAC does not understand something as basic as the right to free speech, gives me pause about his own understanding of America and, by extension, that of his organization. Mr. Fenton had every right to burn the Qur'an and should not have been fired, and I fully support his right to do so and believe he should be given his job back.
column3: Not allowing free speech for public workers makes me question if leaders understands what America is about. The right of free speech is granted to all Americans and it was done off the job, therefor he had the freedoms to do so.

column2: This is America, and we should not give in to political correctness to appease these fanatical Muslim thugs. If someone can burn the flag with impunity, show a crucifix dipped in urine, stage plays making fun on Catholics, deny the Holocaust, then he or she can burn a religious text. And the Muslims who seek to live in this country had better get used to it. Will the ACLU, that intrepid defender of left-wing and Muslim civil liberties, take up this case? I doubt it.
column3: Political correctness should not superseded our rights to free speech. A person is free to burn the flag, show a defaced crucifix, stage plays mocking religion, and deny the holocaust. So they should be free to burn a religious text as well.

column2: At what point does the concept of free speech become a hate crime? The Nazi regime started out burning books written by Jews and then we know where that led. Taken to an extreme, burning of books is just the opposite of free speech. It empowers ignorance by destroying the written word. Sadly, this is an example of someone committing a dumb, but not illegal, act. Is it really freedom of speech or an example of intense hatred? Should that person be fired for his actions, off duty? Probably not in our society. Is this an example of American society, at its best? Definitely, NOT.
column3: Although the speech is hateful, off duty actions cannot be considered to fire someone.

column2: As long as he did it on his own time, did not use resources from his employer, and in no way represented himself as acting in an official capacity, he had every right to do what he did. I don't agree with what he did. But he had every right to do it. If employees are able to fire their employees for doing things off duty that the employer doesn't agree with, essentially we don't have a right to free speech anymore. We just have a right to speech that doesn't offend our employer, and that's not much of a right.
column3: Workers should have right to speech if they do it on their own time with their own resources, representing themselves. This would eliminate free speech.

column2: What the NJ Transit employee failed to understand is that there is a distinction between free speech rights (burning a Koran, a flag or what have you) and the fact that employment in America is, by and large, at-will -- you can get fired if your boss doesn't like the color of your socks. If his off-hours -- but very public and very controversial -- actions were deemed to affect his workplace efficiency, then his employer had a perfect right to fire him. Sadly, this particular individual has learned, in the harshest way possible, a rule of Free Speech that many tend to forget in our times: just because you have the right to say whatever you want it doesn't mean that it's always a smart idea to do so.
column3: Free speech rights do not trump employers rights to at will employment. If a person's actions during his or her work hours affect workplace efficiency then employer's may have a right to fire. Although free speech is the law, sometimes one should refrain from speaking.

column2: Well, that guy just burned a bunch of paper... Why he can't protest against fanatic Muslims? Those who punished him are just getting upset for nothing. Can the burning of a Bible or a Koran means war? this is stupid. People must learn to not get upset for things like that. To convince about God, please don't use terrorism or bullying... use love, reasoning, and wisdom
column3: If the transit worker caused no harm he should be allowed to protest.

column2: One thing that nobody seems to be asking, and that no source seems to have made available (quite possibly because nobody knows) is what Mr. Fenton was wearing. Regardless of being off-duty, if he was clearly identifying himself as a Transit employee he's very likely still subject to the Transit code of conduct. Most New York firefighters wear NYFD t-shirts when off duty, at least some of the time. the same goes for New York police and NYPD t-shirts. If Mr. Fenton was doing the same, there's a strong case that he's acting as a representative of the NJ Transit Authority rather than a private citizen. Keep in mind two things folks. First, if he'd burned a Christian Bible lynch mobs would be forming. Second, the only protection this idiot has from being fired is that he works for a government office. Any private employer could fire him for the act without hesitation.
column3: If he is clearly identifying himself as a Transit employee then he is still subject to the Transit code of conduct. Private employers can fire workers for acts easier than public employers can.

column2: While I find Mr. Fenton's behavior appallingly violent and highly immoral, I also find the long reach of his employer's arm legally unsupportable. I wouldn't be surprised to see this man reinstated in the backlash. Being a democracy has always meant tolerating all manner of disrespectful and hateful language - as long as it remains language and not a specific call to violent action.
column3: The long reach of an employer's arm is legally unsupportable. Public workers should be allowed free speech as long as it does not lead to violence.

column2: Democracy destroys itself because it abuses its right to freedom and equality. Because it teaches its citizens to consider audacity as a right, lawlessness as a freedom, abrasive speech as equality and anarchy as progress. -Isocrates I believe in the first amendment but this man is intentionally trying to cause pain to others by disrespecting their beliefs. People will obviously be upset by this. I am upset by it and I am not a Muslim. So NO your 1st amendment rights are not violated when you are told to shut up because you are going to cause a panicked mob during a fire drill. You DON"T get to claim American rights of protection when you violate the tenets of equality and freedom in your speech.
column3: Freedom without responsibility and accountability undermines democracy. Speech can be limited when the intent is to cause pain and disrespect others beliefs. The 1st amendment does not provide the right to cause panic in a mob. Public workers have a right to free speech when off-duty.

column2: As long as jobs are scarce, it makes sense that people who have not been convicted should have a better shot at them. This means that the burden of the scarcity of jobs should fall more heavily on the convicted, even though this makes it more difficult for them to go straight and have successful lives. On the other hand, those with criminal records and experience are more likely to return to crime if they cant find legal sources of income like jobs, and those with no criminal experience are less likely. From this point of view, it makes sense to give the oil to the squeaky hinges, thereby rewarding lawbreaking and penalizing those who have not gotten caught breaking the law. This is our present policy, which we wind up with because it is supposedly cheaper in the short run. People unlikely to make trouble because they cannot find jobs are left to their own devices.
column3: Non-felons should get priory for jobs when they are scarce. Those that have committed crimes against society should have that seen when competing fairly for jobs with those who did not commit crimes.

column2: No, ban the box is not enough there should be a time limit for back ground checks, 6 months for non violent misdemoners, 2 years for non violent felonies. and a longer time for violent crimes depending upon the crime. People need to work and have a job and have a place to live.
column3: Applicants should not have to report nonviolent crimes after 6 months (misdemeanor) or 2 years (felony), and whether an applicant must report violent crimes depends on the crime. Everyone needs to work, have a job and a place to live.

column2: The desire to continue punishing people who have served their sentence and paid their debt to society is pervasive, unjust and inhumane. It seems all too many of us would prefer to push individuals with a criminal record off the proverbial edge over extending a hand to help them regain their footing. Fear may be at the bottom of this pattern of behavior but in my view it only makes things worse in the long run.
column3: Criminal records of job applicants should not be an initial screening tool for employers. Too many people would prefer to push individuals with a criminal record of over the proverbial edge instead of giving them a helping hand. It gives a very negative impression.

column2: It is nothing more then one big commercial farce labeled a friendly competition. At the end London is going to find out its folly just like Greece did. When it is all over Lords Coe will be no where around to address the issue and answer questions.
column3: The Olympics are a big commercial rather than a friendly competition.

column2: A lifelong New Yorker, I agree entirely with Mr. Moss about the detrimental effects of hosting the Olympics that a city suffers. Now, as a professor of urban policy and planning at New York University's Institute for Public Service, I hope he will turn his attention to the devastating effects of NYU's expansion on neighborhood life and architectural scale in our city.
column3: Cities suffer detrimental effects when hosting the Olympics. NYU's expansion has harmed the neighborhood life of the city.

column2: So based on these numbers London is forking out ~12-24 Billion dollars to pay for the Olympics. According to the Official projection they have already spent 12 Billion pounds (or just abous $20 billion). Unofficially the bill is looking more like 24 Billion pounds (or closer to 40 Billion dollars). What a complete waste of Money.
column3: The Olympics have already cost 12 billion pounds and will end up costing closer to 23 billion. Hosting the Olympics is a waste of money.

column2: The Olympics seem like a frivolous project that will benefit a few well placed construction companies. After building the venues they get to walk away with fat bank accounts and the cities get stuck with maintenance and interest expenses. Granted the cities now have an opportunity to use the venues for other events, but those opportunities are few and far between. The publicity generated for the host city seems dubious. Who doesn't alread know about London or Rio?
column3: These games really only serve as a frivolous event that benefits construction companies with connections. Building the venues leads to cities being stuck with maintenance and interest expenses. Even though they are opportunities for the cities. Publicity generated for Olympics included has both positive and negative impacts.

column2: If laws like this are a good way of dealing with reality, I'll stick to reading fiction. Public schools do differentiate between students! Most schools have AP classes, gifted programs, etc. Even elementary and middle schools have talented and gifted programs and/or challenge courses. How much students care to learn also affects how much they end up learning. I'm quite confused what is good about this idea of yours as it seems to equate public education to shoe shopping. I am saddened that people are making money off these stupid ideas that you seem to be willing to propagate. Kids go to public schools and they do learn there. If parents want them to learn a competing view, have them pick up a book after school and learn some more. To ask public schools to cater to the whims of parents is more harmful than the big, bad federal government mandates you seem to fear sir.
column3: Public schools already tailor classes to children's needs without parent interference. How much students learn is also dependent on how much they care about learning. Kids do learn at public schools. Parents can choose what their kids learn at home. Federal government mandates are less harmful than parent mandates.

column2: Then numerous schools will spring up and parents will be able to pair with educators who share their views... I should think college admissions offiicials would be interested to know if an applicant is coming from a school whose goal is to omit significant areas of history, science, etc. What a shame for those young people who will be deemed ill-equipped to enter the world of grand ideas. Here's how it works in my house: My kids learn facts at school, we talk about the implications at home, I give them my view and tell them to form their own. To date, none of them have spontaneously combusted.
column3: Parents should not be able to select their child's learning plan because it could negatively effect their college performance. Kids should learn at school and be taught at home as well.

column2: One size does not fit all is a good sound byte. And trying to make students learn about and take an interest in subjects in which they have little or no interest is difficult. But allowing students to choose to be ignorant by only studying what they want to study is just sheer stupidity. We Americans are already THE most illiterate and ignorant bunch of "educated" human beings on the planet. But countries like Russia and China are certainly pleased with "It's your right ot can be as stupid and ignorant as you want to" mentality.
column3: Its good to remember "One size does not fit all". Students do not need to be allowed to choose to be ignorant. Americans are already illererate.

column2: So if someone can't do algebra they can out of it, but if another student takes it and fails they get an F on their transcripts? How could this work and be fair to those who attempt to take subjects which challenge themselves?
column3: Parental control will lead to children being unchallenged at school.

column2: People assume the only parents opting out will be conservative evangelicals who don't want their kids to learn about evolution or the birds & bees. When I was in school, one of the best history teachers in the district was forced to retire early because a few African American parents didn't like how he taught the Civil War. Now around here in CA, Latino families are objecting to how American history books teach the Mexican-American War. People have a lot of different opinions. Liberals want their way of thinking taught, conservatives want theirs. There has to be some way for schools to deal with this other than bowing down to the pressure of the most vocal parents.
column3: Political bias clouds the debate surrounding public education. Need to find another way than bowing down to the pressure of the most vocal parents.

column2: It's disappointing that the Times would ask a professional bigot to contribute to this discussion. The Cato Institute is funded by people who wish to denigrate and weaken government at every level. If they pay McCluskey's salary, it is because he is carrying their water. Parents who are not content with what their children may or may not be taught in public classrooms have always been free to home school or enroll them in private schools. Public education has been a smashing success story for America and tens of millions of its citizens. However, allowing individual parents to alter lesson plans at will can only result in chaos and a less-educated population. This New Hampshire experiment will end in failure.
column3: Parents are welcome to home school or find a school that teaches as they approve instead of dictating public school teaching. Public schools have successfully taught tens of millions of Americans. Results of individual parents controlling lesson plans would be chaos and less-educated population.

column2: I think that parents should not have the right to change every lesson they dont like. If they dont like the then they should ask for the student to learn something else not change the lesson. If parents are so worried what there children are learning then they should put them in pirvate school. Also teachers have gone to school for this , this is what they do for a living so i think they know what to teach kids.
column3: Parents can choose to place their children in a different school, if they don't like what is being taught. Teachers are trained professionals and I believe the parental interference only hinders them.

column2: Should parents be given a shopping list or a line item veto for everything their tax dollars are involved in? Seriously? Procedures & materials for road repair? Medical practices in surgery? Proper chemicals used to treat the town water? We could all have opinions on these but are they professional or informed? Parents do not have a six-year degree and teaching license to qualify for text/curriculum/lesson plan design - just as they have no geology degree for road projects, or med degree for surgical procedures, or chemical engineering degree for civic operations. If individuals are so fearful and filled with anxiety & distrust of modern society, isnt that a private matter for the family and perhaps a mental health professional to deal with vs. these private fears being foisted on the general public who want modern medecine, scholarly education, and sound civic operations to be able to do their best for us. This attitude of "Some of my tax money is involved so I wish to inject my own set of facts and opinions with a red face and a loud voice like I've seen on Fox News" is getting out of hand.
column3: Parents don't have a six-year degree, or teaching license to qualify for text/curriculum/lesson plan design -  just as they have no geology degree for road projects, or med degree for surgical procedures, or chemical engineering degree for civic operations. People trying to force their opinions on the school by claiming it is their right because they pay taxes is getting out of control.

column2: I live in New Hampshire most of the time and all I can say is that this doesn't surprise me. The right wing has taken over the state and as far as they're concerned education is a waste of time because gravity doesn't exist and global warming only has something to do with sexual dysfunction.
column3: The right wing has corrupted education and is convinced it is a waste.

column2: My comprehensive high school sex education course was one of the most valuable to me of all my subjects. My high school classmates and I were the guinea pigs for the pilot program at LSU's University Lab School in 1953. The course was quite comprehensive. It covered the mechanics, contraception, VD, prostitution, deviant sexual behavior. I don't recall the word abstinence being used. However, the teacher, J.Q. Long, emphasized that sex should be more than a physical act with potentially serious consequences, physical and psychological, and was not to be undertaken casually. Twenty-five years later I was amazed when some parents in my children's school in Michigan objected to the sex education courses which I'm pretty sure were less comprehensive than mine thirty years before in Louisiana.
column3: Parents should not have control over important topics like sex ed.

column2: Obviously they SHOULD NOT. Such people are often narrow minded and ignorant, and want to keep their children the same way. How a state would write such a law says something about the sickness of their legislature. How about parents who DON'T LIKE ANYTHING? Will the school have to write an entire curriculum for them and assign a teacher to work with this child and teach whatever worthless nonsense the parent's desire?
column3: The parents that want to control learning are narrow minded and ignorant and wish their children to be the same. The school shouldn't have to rewrite the curriculum and get new teachers because the parent doesn't like what the school teaches.

column2: I'd just like to see the curriculum. Too many times, the syllabus for any given course is behavior focused with no mention of the topic material to be covered. I also have to agree with one of the commentators below. Language Arts and similar classes are not academically challenging for good readers because of the need to accommodate those who struggle. I don't object to helping those who struggle but I would certainly let my child opt out of classes where he/she does not learn anything new. I'd also opt out of the character education training, which too often, requires students to respect everyone's opinion.
column3: I would like to see what they are teaching my kids. Smart kids aren't being challenged in language arts and other classes because the teacher has to work with the kids who struggle. I would also prefer to avoid character education training, which requires students to respect everyone's opinion.

column2: One of the horrible developments of the internet age is that people can actively avoid those topics they do not agree with or which cause them distress. One of the fundamental issues facing our society is that this avoidance of intellectual conflict leads to STUPID people, and an unwillingness to compromise for the betterment of society. Civil relations and critical thinking are dead under this model. Pick and Choose should be OPPOSED at ALL LEVELS. The only thing I have to say about getting old is that it is likely I will be dead and buried before this country implodes in a holocaust of partisan hate. But it will come.
column3: Avoiding intellectual conflict creates stupid people who will not compromise for society. If parents controlled why kids learned civil relations and learning critical thought are dead.

column2: I think that teachers should teach what there assinged to teach. Teachers have gone to school for this and this is what they do for a living. So they probably know what they're talking about. If you dont like what teachers are teaching in public schools then you should probably enroll your kid in a private school
column3: Teachers should teach what there assigned. Teachers have gone to school for this, it's what they do for a living. Parents should consider private schools if they don't like public curriculum.

column2: I am not now, nor Have I ever been a beach person. I have often commented that beach front property would be wasted on me, and those who most want it and are willing to pay for it should have it. I do, however, believe that private ownership should be limited to the spaces above and adjoining the beaches. Public access to the beach seems to be a no-brainer. I believe we should also make these private owners of beach adjacent property responsible for rebuilding their own homes when the next storm or tsunami comes their way. Beach cottages used to be ramshackle affairs, built on sticks, with second hand wicker furniture. Now the hoipolloi builds mega million dollar mansions, filled with great furniture and art on the beach. Surprise surprise, your house got washed a way again. The Federal Government should stop encouraging and supplementing people who build irresponsible sand castles on foundations of sand.
column3: Private owners should also be responsible for rebuilding their own homes when storms hit. The Federal Government should stop encouraging people who build irresponsible beachfront homes.

column2: Most beach communities have public beaches and private land. I don't see why that's a problem, frankly; it is a problem if people begin believing that 'what's yours is mine,' unless you want people to then begin believing that your home is also theirs because they like it, or your living room couch should be theirs because it's 'welcoming.' Unless you're a communist; then it makes sense.
column3: Most areas have both public and private beaches. What belongs to one person doesn't belong to the masses and the masses should have no claim to personal property.

column2: I would argue that, at least on the Gulf Coast, the government DOES compensate coastal residents for the use of their land. They are compensated in the form of aid whenever a hurricane destroys their beach houses. Seems to me a small price to pay to allow people to walk on the beach behind your house. (I would, however, understand if beachfront owners pushed for strict rules concerning the use of those beaches: curfews, open container rules, and that sort of thing). . Me, I'll avoid the whole problem when I buy a weekend house for my family. We'll buy on a lake instead of on the ocean. No beach to worry about, and no hurricanes....
column3: In some areas, the government reimburses private residences for the public use of their land. If a hurricane destroys their beach house, they are compensated with aid, so allowing people to walk on the beach is a fair trade off.

column2: If some rich curmudgeon buys all the land around a public school can he then deny access to the kids? Access should be guaranteed: if the landowner won't sell a piece of his property leading to the public area, it should be confiscated; case closed.
column3: Lakes are public and should be accessible. Access should be guaranteed, and a landowner should have to either sell the property or have it confiscated.

column2: What exactly is the point of preserving the pristine character of beautiful beaches if the only people who can afford to enjoy them are the uberwealthy people who own them? The value of such scarce natural resources is so high that it really shouldn't be affordable for any one person to own them. Because, once a beach leaves the public domain and becomes the private property of one person, the benefits of that beach are the right of that person to enjoy (and charge others for or restrict others from) in perpetuity. In my opinion, beaches all over the country should be declared public property
column3: Preserving beautiful beaches is pointless if only uberwealthy people enjoy them?. This natural resource that is not readily available everywhere should not be the under the sole ownership of one person, instead it should be a public domain. Beaches are private property and the owner can decide how to use them. Beaches should be public land.

column2: Beeches and access to them should be open to all. For those that argue the rights of private property and the free-market solutions they should remember it when it comes to flood insurance and disaster relief. The public should not have to open their purse for others sho build homes on what should be public commons.
column3: Beaches and their access should be public. Proponents of private property rights and the free-market should consider social programs like disaster relief and flood insurance. Homes built on public commons and not open to the public, should not receive public funding.

column2: I grew up in Malibu and my family still lives there. I have no problem with public access to beaches, what I do have a problem with is public access with no public facilities - ie. restrooms and trashcans. I can't count the number of times my family picked up litter on the beach in front of our home or emptied the overflowing, un-maintained public trash cans at the access. The public has a right to the beach, but I'd like to think I have a right not to step off my front steps into another persons excrement. Disgusting.
column3: I have no problem with it. Beachfront should be open to the public, so long as the public takes care of the land.

column2: Maine and several other eastern states define private ownership out the mean low tide level. Water covered zones are open to fishing, fowling, and water-borne navigation, but not recreation. I certainly support the idea of public access, especially in areas where barrier reefs and islands naturally move around. I don't think your typical Maine coast solid-rock ledge is in that category.
column3: People can fish, fowl and drive on the water, but can't use if for recreation. Beachfront should be made public, especially where barrier reefs and islands are.

column2: I would say if private owners insist that the public not be allowed access to public beaches, IE: high tide marks. All recovery of private property because of natural disaster be nullified. My tax dollars pay for these folks to recover loses due to their choice to build in obviously unstable environments.
