column3: It would have been better for everyone to have Medicare, but we couldn't convince everyone of that. It's the best we could do with circumstances aren't likey to change soon.

column2: What Chris Jacobs is really saying is that he hates a plan that the Heritage Foundation developed that was the basis of much of first Romenycare and Obamacare. I agree that there was a much simpler and better plan out there and I am a beneficiary of it and can tell you that it works real well for our family It's called Medicare and it will can serve us well as a common sense model for our entire population.
column3: Medicare for all is a much better alternative to Obamacare.

column2: How can this be the so called 'law of the land' when there are so many waivers and exemptions ? Give me an example of another global law that only applies to certain Americans? As such I think the law is invalid and the real attack should be for injunctive relief to force the administration to rescind the waivers or the law is nullified.
column3: There are too many waiver and exemptions for this to be the law.

column2: I live in Maryland (DC suburb) and my wife and I are on it. It greatly lowered our costs. Our children were able to go on it until they each found jobs with their own health care. We love Obamacare and so will everyone. It's doing exactly what it's supposed to do, and it has freed people where one family member has a pre-existing condition to change employment, thus helping the economy. The Republicans don't want it to go into effect precisely because they know it will expose them as frauds.
column3: Obamacare lowered costs and children were able to utilize it until employment was found. Obamacare has allowed people with pre-existing conditions to change employment.

column2: I am fully insured on my own and help finance Obamacare too. And I don't regret. Such obligations are imperative for a civilized society and a nation. These obligations pale in comparision with,( like all citizens do),the benefits, advantages and rights I enjoy at the same time. In fact, what I want is a far less complicated, straight-forward, far more liberal and universally applicable health care system that is at least comparable to what are obtaining presently in France,UK and Scandinavia.I don't mind the personal costs,no one should, I believe.It is the basic minimum that any nation should render to its citizens.And it could prove to be quite cheaper than whatever provided by any insurance company and far more efficient, if wisely administered. Anyway, I personally believe, ofcourse buttressed by my own calculations and ratified by my intellectual friends, that the rich are indeed the free loaders in any society, extracting far higher benefits from it than what they themselves contribute.But they make the maximum noise and grossly distort the reality for denying the middle class and the poor what they richly deserve-- through rational logic and by canons of progressive civilizations.
column3: While not perfect, Obamacare provides healthcare for some people that would otherwise not be able to afford health insurance.

column2: The status quo ante prior to Obamacare was that healthcare was a complete perversion of the free market and open competition. This country allowed insurance companies to corner the market on healthcare via insurance, to price medical treatment beyond the range of any individual to pay without insurance, and therefore to deny care and coverage to anyone with impunity. Obama has restored the balance by taking away the insurance companies' ability to block consumers from receiving medical care. He did it without the social violence that, by rights, should have accompanied such a revolutionary change. Obama actually initiated a return of healthcare to a free market, competitive status. But it required an acknowledgement that basic healthcare is a right that cannot be abridged.
column3: Before Obamacare, the healthcare industry was completely ruled by market forces. Obamacare has removed insurance companies' ability to refuse coverage to consumers. Obamacare was a return of healthcare to the free market.

column2: I don't know how Kristen Feemster can sleep at night. No amount of money is worth inflicting that damage by force. They always want to focus on the one person in an iron lung from 1947. How about you focus the attention on the 154 people paralyzed by the polio vaccine in the last 35 years, while nobody unvaccinated got polio? The scientists are anti-science, and they believe in Nazi medical experiments.
column3: 154 people were paralyzed by the polio vaccine, but no unvaccinated person got polio. Sometimes scientists do not believe in the scientific process.

column2: I take issue with the idea that the only valid exemption aside from an individual medical issue is religious, which is the law in my state (MA). This means I can only exempt my children from vaccination requirements if I do NOT have an objection based on reason - it can only be a faith-based objection. I find it very condescending to be told that the thinking has already been done for me and I cannot think for myself but only follow the tenets of a religion. Why do we privilege religion as beyond questioning and reproach but have no respect for freedom of thought?
column3: kids must take vaccination shot it helps with health issues.

column2: It seems clear from reading the comments that the vaccine debate is falsely represented. While there are those who absolutely refuse any vaccinations, they are clearly in the minority. In fact, the vast majority of those who question the childhood vaccine schedule are looking most closely at a few of them, specifically Varicella, Flu, Hepatitis B and to some extent MMR. Their reasons for questioning these vaccines are solid and sound, and answers are still lacking to key questions about their safety, effectiveness and necessity. There is another camp of people who, like me, believe in vaccines and vaccinate their children but who question the recommendations and educate myself. I am lucky to have a child who can handle vaccinations without consequence, but it is cruel and disrespectful to families affected by vaccine injuries to claim that their child's suffering is for the greater good. You don't need a medical degree to think critically about your family's health and to demand answers from vaccine manufacturers who are, frankly, not forthcoming with information.
column3: People who are skeptical of the childhood vaccine schedule are looking closely at a few of them, specifically. We do not know enough about vaccines. It is unfair for families affected by vaccine injuries to say that their suffering is for the greater good. Vaccines manufacturers are not forthcoming with information and people can make their own decisions.

column2: It is quite sad to see a doctor advocate for government coercion for something that every doctor acknowledges has its risks. How would this doctor propose to enforce this coercion, prison terms for parents who refuse to vaccinate? Stalking the kids and vaccinating them in the street? Providing each child with a vaccine record microchip? It would be one expensive government program to run. It seems a lot more reaction would follow and hence some real outbreaks. Peaceful persuasion seems to be a wiser alternative. Or, if an increased compliance is sought for the more serious diseases, such as pertussis, measles, polio, rubella, then offer separate vaccines that fewer parents would object to and eliminate the ludicrous vaccines from the compulsory list, by ludicrous I mean those that clearly might be doing more harm than good as is the case with the varicella vaccine and the hep B vaccines given routinely to babies of non-carrier mothers. The more such vaccines are forced, the more families react by complete refusal of vaccines.
column3: Doctors advocate for vaccines even though they know they carry risks. There is no way to enforce manditory vaccination. Increasing the number of vaccinations for children causes more people to refuse to be vaccinated at all.

column2: The United States of America is the most advanced country in terms of childhood vaccination. (that means, American children are the most heavily vaccinated in the world) And yet, more than half of that most vaccinated U.S. children suffer from chronic illnesses or obesity. Have you ever thought why? Wake up Americans.
column3: Vaccinated children suffer chronic illness and obesity so that means vaccinations do not work.

column2: the fact of the matter is it is our decision as parents to make the decision we feel best suits our children. if one chooses to vaccinate, that is their choice and i respect that they've made the difficult decision to protect their family by vaccinating. my choice however is to not vaccinate our children, as i feel i would be doing more harm to them than good. it's not an easy answer whichever you choose, but i am proud to be born in a country that allows me the freedom to make decisions regarding this. we as parents have researched the options fully, and are aware of both sides risks...and choose the lesser of the 2 evils for us.
column3: Parents muse be able to choose what is best for their children and family. Vaccination does more harm than good. Parents can research options and want to have a say in making a choice.

column2: Please show me the study that proves that vaccines are either safe or effective. There are no such studies, but there are many studies that cause me to question their safety, not to mention the thousands of cases of vaccine injury documented on the VAERS site. If vaccines are safe, why has our government given monetary compensation to thousands of vaccine injured families through the VICP program?
column3: No study proves vaccines work. There are thousands of people injured by vaccines, and years of studies that make me question their safety. The government has given compensation to thousands of people injured by vaccines. They are not safe.

column2: No Thank you. I do not EVER, want my government to force me to inject my children with anything. Many vaccines and eye drops for that matter, contain the carcinogen Mercury, which in later years can present as rheumatoid arthritis and lymphoma-like symptomology. And, people still today get polio from live but weakened polio virus vaccines... This has to remain individual choice. My child was allergic to Pertussis vaccine, but homeopathy protected my children much more than any vaccines could. It's educated parents that are needed, not forced vaccinations.
column3: The government should not be able to force injections upon my children. Vaccinations should not be mandatory because they have mercury, a carcinogen which can cause symptoms similar to arthritis and lymphoma. Vaccinations can cause polio even in the weakened form. Vaccination should remain a personal choice. There can be allergies, and homeopathy is a better alternative. Parents need to be educated about forced vaccinations.

column2: There should be no exeptions from vaccinations with the exception of valid medical exemptions i.e. an individual with a serious allergy to the vaccine for example an egg alergy in the case of the flu vaccine. Asside from that demonstratable allergy no exemptions for either personal belief or religion should be entertained. If I had my way vaccinations would be a part of a single payer national health system providing universal care. The private sector has proved itself to be incompetent to provide modern health care and need to step asside.
column3: The only acceptable exemption should be a legitimate medical reason, such as a vaccine allergy.

column2: Of course vaccines should be required for all children, despite whatever religious or philosophical reasons parents might have for withholding such preventative medical care from their children. Why? Because we live in a cooperative society where our actions have direct implications on the lives and wellbeing of others. Those "withholding" parents are no better than the selfish fools who won't get a flu shot because, "everyone else gets them, so I don't need to." Spanish Flu killed 20 million people, yet today's parents still have the gall to say the medical onus should be on others, not them. For all those parents out there who don't want your child immunized, try living for one year in a third- or fourth-world country where immunizations are rare (if they exist at all), and your kid is exposed to myriad diseases all but extinct in our society. You'd be terrified to let your kid play with neighborhood kids, yet here you think nothing of exposing other people's children to the same. Vaccinations should be mandatory. It's time religion and philosophy (which are one in the same) take a back seat to rationality and public health.
column3: These vaccines are preventative medical care that are more important than religious or philosophical ideals. Vaccinations should be mandatory in a cooperative society were actions have a direct impact on others wellbeing. Parents who do not vaccinate their children should consider what it is like to raise a child in a more disease prevalent country.

column2: The choice to abstain from vaccination tends to be based upon concerns about the additives and preservatives placed in the shots. I do not understand why my cat can get an additive free vaccine and my child cannot. How about demanding a change in the pharma industry to make the actual shots safer? There are known human carcinogens like formaldehyde and neurotoxins such as aluminum in many vaccines. Vaccine injuries are very real and a risk some are just not willing to take.
column3: Abstaining from vaccination tends to be based on additives and preservatives in the shots. The pharmaceutical industry needs to change. Vaccination shouldn't be mandatory for children because many vaccines still contain dangerous chemicals like formaldehyde and neurotoxins. Some are not willing to take the risk of vaccine injuries.

column2: I couldn't agree more. The decision of well-meaning but ignorant people to deprive their children of vaccinations endangers not just the children, but the children of others, and vulnerable adults. Our right to choose ends when those choices result in harm to others.
column3: People who choose not to vaccinate their children endanger their children as well as others. If vaccinations are not mandatory then those making selfish choices will cause others to be harmed.

column2: NO CHOICE ! John Stewart Mill defined freedom as all inclusive except when it infringes on that of others. So, if parents decided not to have their children vaccinated... OK. But this choice puts others at risk. It has been said that certain vaccines or combinations of them lead to autistic spectrum disorders based on anecdotal evidence. Though sincere these people know nothing about science and the scientific method and when two events occur simultaneously -- it may be the "false cause and effect fallacy." And in the present case this is what exactly is going on. And there is agreement about this in the medical and scientific community. Students in high school and college who take biology, chemistry, physics... are apt to learn just facts in favor of what the scientific method is all about.
column3: Not vaccinating infringes on the rights of others. [Not vaccinating] puts others at risk.

column2: It is a news media-driven misperception that parents who claim philosophical or religious exemptions are uneducated or misinformed. MOST PARENTS WHO INDIVIDUALIZE THE VACCINE SCHEDULE ARE ACTIVELY EDUCATING THEMSELVES, CONTINUALLY ASSESSING THEIR FAMILY'S SPECIFIC HEALTH NEEDS, and doing everything they can to keep their children safe and healthy. Ms. Margulis offers no data to support her blanket assertion about the industry and motivation of "most parents," a position which, on its face, seems improbable given the breadth and weight of scientific evidence supporting immunization which is not subject to reasonable dispute. Based on anecdotal information, "most parents" are refusing to vaccinate their children based on their gross misunderstandings and unwarranted fears of the alleged risks of immunization, or based on their unique interpretations of religious dictates. If you intend to offer relevant commentary, Ms. Margulis, it should be evidence-based. Your personal opinions are no more interesting (or informed) than mine.
column3: Vaccination should not be mandatory because informed parents make sure to educate themselves so they can make the best choices for their individual child. Most parents are refusing to vaccinate.

column2: I am a libertarian, but this is not a purely self-regarding choice. RC is right. This is a choice that might endanger others. If a parent's failure to allow their children to be vaccinated creates a transmission belt for an infectious disease, then the parent should be liable for the consequences of their choice. Moreover, the parent who won't let their child be vaccinated is a free rider. Other parents are accepting a minuscule -- but real risk -- of an adverse reaction to the vaccination. Their decision helps to protect the child of the free-riding parent because the vaccinated child serves as a sort of firebreak to slow the spread of the disease.
column3: Unvaccinated children endanger others. Anyone refusing to vaccinate children should be liable for any disease or death they cause. The risk of an adverse reaction is small.

column2: If, as the author suggests, "Most parents who individualize the vaccine schedule are actively educating themselves, continually assessing their family's specific health needs, and doing everything they can to keep their children safe and healthy," then why are we having these outbreaks? It is apparent that whatever these parents are doing is not working, and in the interest of public safety, it is time for meaningful legislation to ensure that these preventable diseases are indeed prevented.
column3: Vaccination should be mandatory because non vaccination is not working. Legislation should protect children from preventable diseases.

column2: I agree that parents (and the kids, once they're old enough--say, 16) should have the right to opt in or out of SOME vaccinations--namely, ones for diseases that are hard to spread. Hepatitis B? HPV? Be my guest--that choice only affects your family, because those are not diseases your kid can spread at school, on the bus, etc. But no one without a medical exemption should be able to opt out of vaccinations against HIGHLY CONTAGIOUS, very dangerous diseases like German measles, pertussis/whooping cough, mumps (which can leave little boys permanently infertile), etc. Measles can live on surfaces like classroom desks and the metal handles people hold in buses for several hours. Nobody has the right to expose complete strangers to devastating diseases that are so easy to prevent.
column3: Without a medical exemption, no one should be able to opt of vaccines. Not vaccinating your child exposes others to risk from preventable illnesses.

column2: The problem is the cost of non-vaccination is not borne by the dissenting parents, but by the sickened and possibly dead injured by the loss of herd immunity. If someone does not want their children to be vaccinated, that person should be required to post a bond to cover the potential damages. A bond should also be required by individuals claiming religious exemptions.
column3: Problem is the cost of non-vaccination is not borne by the refusing parents, but by the loss of herd immunity. People should be financially responsible for their choices on vaccination.

column2: An American parent could reasonably decide not to follow the C.D.C.'s current vaccination schedule by choosing to vaccinate on the schedule they use in Norway, which has one of the lowest infant mortality rates in the world. You don't come close to explaining how it's "reasonable" for a parent to second guess the CDC's recommended schedule. Do you have actual evidence that the potential risk of infant vaccines outweighs the risk of the diseases they prevent? It seems not.
column3: Do you have evidence that the risk of vaccinating infants is greater than the risk of disease.

column2: Both the child and the rest of the population have a right to be protected against Communicable diseases that can result in Deafness, blindness, paralysis, mental retardation and death. Newborns, immune-compromised adults, and the unvaccinated are protected by herd immunity. If all parents decided to forgo vaccination for their children, our infant and child mortality rates would soar. By the way, Breast feeding has no protective value against tetanus, diphtheria, measles, or whooping cough.
column3: We all have a right to be protected against communicable diseases which cause serious issues or death. Herd immunity protects against those that cannot be vaccinated. Vaccinations save lives. Breast feeding does not confer immunity to the illnesses we immunize for.

column2: We still haven't addressed the problem of children who come from other countries into America and have not had the advantage of early childhood vaccinations. We are seeing cases of measles, mumps, etc. increase, and this cannot be all the fault of those who have lived with and been in contact daily in this country since birth with their peers who have been vaccinated. I'm old, and when in 1st grade, I contacted German measles. NOT from someone in my class and, in fact, no one seemed to know where I contacted it. I then proceeded to infect almost all my entire class apparently. My point in telling this story is that we cannot know exactly where a child gets his contact, and therefore IMO opinion, vaccinations should be mandatory for every child entering schools from pre-K up. Until everyone - from the child who comes with their parents to America to the kiddo next door, we have to be consistent.
column3: Some children come to America from other places who have not had early childhood vaccinations. Cases of measles, mumps and other diseases are increasing. Vaccination of school children is important and should be mandatory because it is impossible to tell where a child might contract a preventable disease. All children should be vaccinated for the sake of consistency.

column2: The choice of whether to breastfeed is of little consequence to others. Not to vaccinate one's children places others at risk, particularly other children and health-compromised adults. The analogy used by the author doesn't hold up. I'm also willing to bet that in Norway the overwhelming majority of young children are inoculated.
column3: Unvaccinated children places others at risk. I believe the kids in Norway get vaccinations.

column2: Unlike in the United Arab Emirates, in America we believe parents are capable of making their own decisions about their children's health. We believe in freedom of choice. This freedom of choice extends to when - and even whether- parents vaccinate their kids. Oh really? I seem to remember reading about several recent outbreaks of formerly all but eradicated viruses putting the health and lives of many at risk because of the so called "capable" choices. And this recent choice is rather new. When I was a child back in the 70sI had to get a back-up MMR shot or be denied access to school. What has changed is organized and ill-informed parents pushing back politically to gain exemptions from sound public policy that has protected the American public for generations. Individual choice should not dominate here. We need herd immunity to ensure our society is protected from serious and even fatal diseases. Parents need to be better educated but I don't think we need to continue to allow ever larger groups of children to go without vaccinations - not only for the broader American public but also those children themselves.
column3: In recent years, there have been a few outbreaks of viruses that were once all but eradicated and they can be blamed on people who make "capable" choices. People should not have a choice. Herd immunity is vital to protect society. Parents should be better educated, but children still need to be vaccinated.

column2: I am a health care worker and I have to get a flu shot because it is federally mandated. I have no choice; I have to get the shot. I would get a flu shot anyway but it does not feel good to be forced, it makes me very angry. I strongly believe in immunization and believe people should be encouraged and educated about why immunizations are important but I don't think forcing people is the right answer. I also believe that schools and day care centers should have the right to refuse to accept kids who have not been immunized.
column3: Flu shots should not be mandatory. Forcing people to vaccinate isn't right even though I personally believe in vaccinations.

column2: People should not be able to impose their religious beliefs on others when it would harm or endanger others. Parents should not be able to deprive their children of medical care, like vaccinations, and employers should not be able to deny their employees of medical care, like contraception.
column3: Imposing your religious beliefs on others can harm or endanger others. Parents shouldn't be able to take away medical care like vaccinations from their children.

column2: Why does Jocelyn Elders support religious exemptions from vaccination requirements? This not only endangers public health, but also violates the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment in my opinion. I don't approve of any exemptions. But if religious exemptions are permitted under a state's law, than so also should non-religious exemptions. Providing preferential treatment solely for religion is unconstitutional. It would be like exempting churches--and only churches--from property taxes.
column3: Religious exemptions for vaccinations should not be allowed. Not vaccinating endangers the public and violates the establishment clause of the first amendment. I don't agree with any of the exemptions. The rights of non-religious Americans are being violated.

column2: People in the US listen more closely to the rantings of a former Playboy model than they do their doctor. Americans tend to believe more in pseudoscience because of ignorance. These two things are driving the loss of herd protection from diseases long thought virtually eradicated in the US.
column3: It is unwise to listen to a model as opposed to medical professionals. Americans often are ignorant and believe in pseudoscience. Vaccination should be mandatory for kids because diseases that were considered eradicated are now popping up in the US population.

column2: Mr. Jaffe seems to be confusing three very different situations. Parents of minor children already have the right to know what is going on with their children's care. And people who have been appointed as legal guardians (conservators of person) also have this right; naturally, that includes parents of adults who have been judged incompetent to manage their own affairs (in probate court), unless someone else (such as a spouse, adult child, lawyer, or physician) takes that responsibility. Done deal! The third case is that of an adult who suffers from a mental illness but has not been found legally incompetent. That person has exactly the same rights and responsibilities as anyone else. Of course one's doctors, lawyers, accountants, priests, and (for that matter) barbers do not communicate with our parents about one's decisions! Why should they? Mr. Jaffe seems to think that we should have a new law that would sidestep the need to establish that a person is, in fact, psychiatrically disabled. That is a dangerous road indeed.
column3: Parents of young children are already granted the privileged of knowing every aspect of their child's care. A mentally ill, competent adult has the same rights and responsibilities as anyone else.

column2: All human beings are a potential threat. There are those who are honest about aggressive feelings and thoughts and those who deny and conceal. Imminent threat is a other matter. Tarasoff properly recognizes some responsibility to third parties but offers tremendous leeway to deal with that--reporting to the police is one option and usually the most ineffective and destructive. Involving family and others in the patients supportive social environment usually is far more effective and, even when done dispite objection by the patient, may preserve the therapeutic relationship. This risk is usually not confined to the moment but is at least in part characteriological and sustained. Mandating reporting to he authorities makes psychotherapists functionaries in an increasingly militarized police state. Might as well just outlaw psychotherapy outright as no real psychotherapy can occur in such an oppressive setting.
column3: The laws are tough enough and the patient's family and support system are more effective in helping the patient to not become violent. Mandatory reports would make a psychotherapists job useless.

column2: Still fail see how this would have necessarily prevented this horrific event. This would only work if the patient actually tells a mental health professional that he or she wants to harm someone (targeted individuals or in general). There's no evidence that Rodger ever communicated any such feelings to his therapists except a few minutes before he started killing. There is substantial evidence that he knowingly and willfully lied to police, withholding entirely his intent to harm. He demonstrated enough mental capacity and control to have hidden his real intent from his therapists, too. He plotted for well over a year without anyone else knowing. Unless he told his therapists in advance that he felt like shooting up a sorority house or the community, your proposed measures, even if already in place, would not have stopped it.
column3: The patient needs to be forthcoming for this to work. Laws that are already in place should prevent violence.

column2: I find this discussion tremendously beside the point. Some good ideas here that parents should be more in the loop and that mental health professionals should have adequate support for sharing information with law enforcement. And THEN WHAT? Presupposing that these things could be predicted, it is extraordinarily difficult to have someone involuntarily committed for psychiatric treatment and that commitment does not last long. Police can't imprison someone because their therapist or parents think they might do something dangerous. As long as we make guns easily available, we are not even trying to stop this. They have psychotic people in other countries and many fewer murders.
column3: Parents should be more involved with their children's lives. It is difficult to be committed involuntarily, and these commitments are usually short. We aren't trying to stop violence because we are making guns available. A therapist can't have a person imprisoned because they think they are dangerous.

column2: Hold on. Reporting concerns to police is not very effective if the police are not very well trained to respond. Very few police departments have the funds (or priorities) to provide special training for dealing with mentally ill/disturbed people. Too often mentally ill people are tasered, assaulted, or shot unnecessarily. And patients who are reported to law enforcement often feel, understandably, betrayed by the person who reports them, leading them to stop treatment--or at least stop being honest about their thoughts and feelings.
column3: The police may not be trained to respond to concerns once reported. Authorities have little to no training in dealing with mentally ill people. If people seeking helped are betrayed by their therapist they will leave treatment or be dishonest which will not help them.

column2: I think our, so called, entertainment industry is conditioning our young to more violence and radical behavior. In the case of all irrational behavior... More aggressive action must be taken when family or authorities see unusual behavior. In this case his parents recognized his problems, had concern, and notified law enforcement. The sad thing is he conned law enforcement and they took no action at all. In this case he should have been forced to seek professional help. Law enforcement does not have the experience or capability to make decisions as to mental capacity or stability.
column3: Families and authorities should take irrational behavior more seriously. Law enforcement lacks sufficient experience to determine a person's mental capacity or stability.

column2: As a former teacher and long-time first grade volunteer in a low income school district, I regularly use the CLEVNET system to get books for our class that compliment our curriculum or that are about subjects in which the kids express interest. We develop a reading list of the books shared each year, and let kids know they have access to them all through our local library. For communities in which books are an unaffordable luxury, libraries level the playing field, giving access to unlimited literary riches to all. In our community, they also provide much needed parenting help through story times and reading activities for caregivers and young children every week. Many families without computers at home get access to the internet at the library for homework help, employment and tax information. While libraries may be redundant for more affluent families, they provide a window into a different present and future for those of lesser means.
column3: They provide supplemental materials for curriculum to both teachers and students. Libraries level the playing field for people who cannot afford books. Libraries provide much needed activities for caregivers and young children in communities. Libraries provide internet for those that need it to do homework, find employment, and file taxes. Libraries give a chance for poorer families to get information and reading material.

column2: Librares are more than places for reading, borrowing books and recordings, and doing research. They are community centers of wisdom. And as such, they are the intellectual aspect of overall community health. When policy makers (providing funding for libraries) understand this aspect, libraries and their surrounding communites, thrive.
column3: They are the intellectual aspect of overall community health.

column2: The seats in the Central Branch of the Brooklyn Public Library are filled with high school and college students reading, researching, and completing assignments.I used the library in the same way, as a quiet place in a crowded city away from a crowded apartment with little private space when I was teenager living in the Bronx in the nineteen sixties. The space is free, the walls are lined with books, and you can travel around the world, back in time, and to distant planets during your breaks. I once had a high school teacher who took points off of a report because I did not include pictures. I explained that the library did not allow you to cut pictures out of the magazines. He did not seem to understand. People who do not understand what libraries mean for working class youth are too blinded by their privileges. For working class youth the library is like a small piece of heaven.
column3: Public libraries are filled with students seeking knowledge and learning. With books, an individual can travel all around the world without leaving the room. Libraries provide access to books to minority children.

column2: I don't sure next generation will read printing books or not. but I needed to visit library. browsed the books handle the new arrivals doing this every week I experienced mental satisfaction.That kind of joy I never experienced on Internet. ,may be old habit never die..For references libraries are essential.There is other advantages of Libraries you can meet there book lovers we can enjoy discussion on book,exchange idea ,may some time debate .Can it possible on virtual world?
column3: Libraries provide satisfaction to people. Libraries are essential for references and can provide a joy never experienced on the internet. Yes, we still need libraries because there are many advantages they offer. There is social interaction at libraries.

column2: Information has moved from print to digital. That does not mean it is free or that it is easily located. Stop equating libraries with print. The point of most libraries never was to serve as a storage space. Unless you are a librarian or work at a library, you probably don't realize that everything in a library, including computers, wifi, online journals, and ebooks, is there as a carefully curated collection created to meet the needs of the people who use it. What you do realize is that when you walk into a library, or go there online, you find what you need and don't need to think very much about how that happened. Libraries serve the same purpose today that they have always served... to make information accessible to everyone through resources and services.
column3: Libraries will keep print media alive. Don't equate libraries with print. Those familiar with libraries realize all the resources that have been carefully placed there to help people. Libraries have always been about making information available to all people.

column2: Yes we need libraries. Public libraries provide so much more than just internet access, though that is an important service. Many libraries assist with literacy training, host book clubs, provide after school activities for children, give senior citizens on fixed incomes a place to borrow books they otherwise could not afford to read. Many libraries do dual duty as de facto community centers. Using the internet at home to do research is fine, Wikipedia is not a peer reviewed source that is accepted as a reference for many schools and universities. Scholarly databases that provide access to academic journals are available at libraries and are usually not affordable for most people. I could go on, but in short YES - we NEED libraries in our communities!
column3: Public libraries provide much more than important internet access. Many libraries provide numerous valuable services to their communities. Libraries function as community centers, as well as lending out books.

column2: Not only would enlightened libraries provide us with a more sensible approach to information, generally, it COULD be a great way to help us educate our children. The opportunity to access educational opportunities would be greatly enhanced and the cost of educating our children would drop dramatically. Each child at his or her own rate of accomplishment. It would catch on like wild fire.
column3: Enlightened libraries could provide us with a sensible approach to information, it COULD be a great way to help us educate our children. We need opportunity to educated our children with opportunities like libraries.

column2: Libraries are a place for word literate people to visit in the increasingly computer literate wasteland. In a world where we are increasingly ROTFL and LMAO in twitterese or emailese (sorry to make up these proto-language names), some people just want to read a book while surrounded by other books. We want to check them out of the library and bring them back and repeat the process. We are still in love with the comfort of the printed page on paper. If all you are using it for is computer access, stop. Get a cheap android tablet, go to McDonalds, buy lunch and a coffee, get the password from the manager and surf away. Next time you are there, sit in the browsing section and read something other than your electronic reader.
column3: Libraries allow a sanctuary for those looking to escape technology. Some people like a social place to read. We want to be able to check items out of the library and return them. People still like reading printed pages.

column2: Yes I'm wired and also have a Kindle and Netflix. Nevertheless I'm a heavy library user and can't imagine living in a community without these resources. My husband and I are now deciding where to retire -- just as we want a location with good medical facilities and an airport we also want a first class library system. We want to live in a community that respects literacy, reading and has good children's programs like story hour, etc.
column3: I use the library often and it would negatively impact the community to lose these resources. Libraries promote good reading habits to children.

column2: Libraries r important in the minority neigbborhoods. When one talks abt minority, the Asian immigrant neighborhoods are NEVER included, andyet these r occupied by new immigrants whose adults work 7 days a week, leaving children to non English grant parent as care takers.Libraries serve as a save haven for knowledge and learning during weekends and holidays. Library plan reading activities and children programs to entice young readers who would otherwise stayed home, watchng the junk programs on TV. What I do not understand is why libraries would find it necessary to provide Dvds of movies to be checked out! Isn't there enough outlets around for that without wasting public money to benefit Hollywood?
column3: Libraries have great value in minority neighborhoods. When school is not in session, one can still gain knowledge and a peaceful environment in a library. Libraries draw children into reading rather than television.

column2: The books, the computers, the storytimes, even the staff expertise are only elements of the emerging (or, more properly, continuing) role of the public library. The library is a community focal point and a community development agency. For decades, my colleagues in the field rode the wrong bus. Libraries and librarians sold themselves as information agents. Then we were blindsided by the development of do-it-yourself information tools. We forgot that our mandate is broader -- much broader -- than information. We are a place where people gather to connect to other people, to culture, to information, to works of art and works of the imagination. From an individual's perspective, that's enriching. From a community's perspective that's vital to the sustenance of vitality and diversity in the polity.
column3: Libraries have many events and activities as well as expert staff which play a vital role in the community. The library brings community together as a center for development. Having a place to gather to connect to people, culture, information, and works of art is enriching and vital to the sustenance of vitality and diversity.

column2: For the Homeless, libraries are also an increasingly important safety net: providing them with a warm place to get indoors on a cold day, newspapers, magazines and computers to let them look for a job or any other need they have, often with a means to make application for the same online. A friend of mine told me that she became homeless for a year and lived in her car. She said it was libraries that gave her a means to search and apply for the job she needed -- and won, getting off the street and into a small rented house again.
column3: Libraries provide help for the homeless, including temporary shelter and career resources.

column2: It will be a sad day for all of us when libraries become simply access points for the Internet. Libraries should be for books and reading, primarily, and all other activities secondarily. Plus the fact the most every library which I have ever had access to has funding problems. And libraries, like teachers and schools, are always the first to feel the cut of the budget axe. We are a strange society, and, I predict, one which is moving quickly downhill as did the old Roman Empire..........
column3: It will be sad when libraries become only access points for the Internet. Libraries are essential for books and reading.

column2: We definitely need libraries!! It was my safe sanctuary when I was chased as a kid by bullies on my way home from school. We definitely need both printed books and Internet access, and digital books accessible from home, too. However, everyone cannot afford the digital devices so public access from the library is necessary. We would be wise to put a library within walking distance of every American, and keep the library open 24/7. The library is the most valuable resource for lifelong learning.
column3: Libraries are needed. Libraries can be safe havens for children. We need printed books and internet access from the home. Libraries are needed since everyone cannot afford digital access. Libraries are a wise addition. Libraries provide for lifelong learning.

column2: I am always amazed at the number of people I see in a library. At the college where I teach, students pack the large computer center, use the stacks of books and study (just as I did 40 years ago) at the tables. The addition of small, private meeting rooms in our new facility allow students to congregate in study groups without disturbing others. Public libraries are also a hive of activity as people who struggle through the recession use the lending of books, movies and music to remain entertained at virtually no cost. Benjamin Franklin would be proud of this American legacy, yet so often it is the first to lose public funding. How sad that we take these institutions for granted and yet we refuse to provide for their necessary functions in our lives.
column3: We need libraries because they offer computer centers, print books and a place to study. Libraries allow students to meet and collaborate. Public Libraries are good for those less fortunate, providing a nearly free source of different media's. Libraries are needed.

column2: Aside from all the new and exciting ways libraries are giving their public access to information, I am in love with the fact that I can access books I would never buy just to see if I like them. If not, no wasted money or time. And sometimes I uncover new gems by this method. Something I didn't have the time to do at Borders. I love the fact that my library appears to be a hub for all kinds of learning and discussion. Where else in this money-driven world is there space for a community center that operates well and offers value to everyone?
column3: Libraries are giving the public access to information in new and exciting ways. I can access books without having to buy them. My library has many kinds of learning available and provides a community space for everyone, which I love.

column2: I didn't realize that libraries were an American invention. I knew that Benjamin Franklin established the first on in this country (almost enough to let me forgive him for floating the ghastly daylight savings time joke in Paris a few years later) and Andrew Carnegie is the only philanthropist I've heard of to devote his fortune to the cause. I thought we had just done our fair share in keeping up with our responsibilities. I don't use the library often, I'm too fond of instant gratification in book stores and too undisciplined to return books on time, but I'm convinced they are a great value in our communities and support them willingly. I also have more internet bandwidth than most libraries. Books and DSL are expensive. I may be crazy enough to put those equal to or even ahead of paying for groceries but it's crucial that others in the community have access to what I take for granted without making the same commitment. Van
column3: I do not use libraries but they add to the community as a whole. Libraries provides books and internet access to those who cannot afford it. Libraries are crucial resources so that everyone have access to their resources.

column2: Having worked in the public library sector in Australia for over 20 years, I am a strong advocate of life-long learning and equity in access to information, thus I support the Open Access movement. In May 2012 I started in a fixed-term contract position at a University Library, my first foray into academic librarianship. As such, the topic of digital libraries and institutional repositories is of personal interest to me. The Open Access movement and institutional repositories have openly challenged the traditional scholarly communication system, supporting a new model for scholarly communication. Indeed, it is possible for academic libraries to alleviate the conflict between these two paradigms. Institutional repositories (by their very nature) exert pressure on journal publishers to permit as much free online access to their content as economically possible. The library and information sector plays an important role in providing public access to networked information. Public libraries worldwide are a significant component; by ensuring that there is equity in access to information (for both educational and recreational purposes) through the provision of quality library services for all citizens.
column3: We need to be able to access information and learn all our lives. Libraries are important because they allow everyone in the community to have access to knowledge. We need libraries because the significant role libraries play in the information arena and providing public access to networked information can't be overstated. Public libraries provide equal access to information for all citizens for both recreation and education.

column2: Do we need libraries? I'm shocked that such a question is being asked at all. There has never been a time when the library is more relevant and in demand. Internet, digital books, multi-media com, culture, meeting point, making friends, quiet haven, working corner, coffee breaks, workshops, forums, seminars, newspaper and magazine reading, fiction collection, etc etc. In fact I would venture to suggest that the library should be open 24/7. A well-designed library should be the HUB of every city, no less.
column3: The library is more relevant and in demand than ever. Libraries provide a venue for a number of desirable individual and shared life-enhancing activities. A proper library should be a focal point for it's community.

column2: Look, there are issues to be debateed. Do we need as much brick and mortaror public shelf space as we have? I use libraries a lot. I download audible books frequently, but I don't use my local northern NY library system to do it, I use the NY City Library. If I do want a book I locate it on Amazon (since its presentation of the book: description, professional and reader reviews is much better than the libraries) then I order it (on-line) from my local library system. When I get the e-mail notice that the book is ready I finally pay a visit to my library to pick the book up. Using this process I wonder why my library has publicly displayed bookshelves at all.
column3: Libraries now offer books online reducing the need for a brick and mortar style library. I can locate books and reviews easier online. With the internet, we really don't depend on the old system.

column2: In our community, the most elegant, welcoming and practical buildings are our libraries. In the 9 years I have lived here, two libraries have been built and one redesigned and refurbished. Like the comments about the need for internet access among the poor, libraries ARE so much more. They have become a cultural, community hub for education, community activism, art, music, video and social interaction. One library has attracted the local gardening society to create and maintain a butterfly garden with many native plants that are marked for people to learn about them. Another group has offered to create a meandering walking path around the expanse of the building for reflection and a chance to walk in beauty outdoors. In many ways, I see our libraries becoming a sort of secular ministry -- feeding the souls as well as the minds of people. They are far from obsolete -- they are becoming more relevant and essential than ever before!
column3: Libraries are elegant and nice buildings in my community. They provide internet access for the poor, as well as other things. Libraries provide a meeting places for many positive activities. I lot of reasons. Libraries are needed more than ever to feed the soul and minds of people.

column2: If libraries were used for information only, those who are there for the computers benefit from the librarians, who know where to find appropriate info. But there is so much more at the library--music and book cds, dvd films, magazines and much more. I have used and owned computers for many years, but I value the library as much as much as ever.
column3: Libraries have lots to offer in addition to books they provide music, dvd's, magazines and more.

column2: The banks have been making enormous profits and paying out (again) obscene bonuses, seemingly forgetting that their purpose (as per Founding Fathers) is to serve the public not themselves. I could accept being nickel and dimed if the executive salaries were brought down to acceptable levels (i.e., maximum $500 000 for the CEO).
column3: Banks are making big profits and forgetting to serve the public first.

column2: If banks were doing what banks have traditionally done, i.e. provide credit for home purchases, small businesses, etc. they would not have to assess so many largely hidden fees. It seems since the financial collapse of 2008, banks are afraid to loan money. Even with interest rates as low as they are, providing consumers and the economy this essential service would provide them with the income they need to function.
column3: The banks should provide credit for home purchasers, small businesses, and other entities. Interest rates are low and consumers should have basic services to help them.

column2: Perhaps in the interests of balance this piece should mention that a checking account is the loss leader that any bank requires in order to get consumers to take out a credit card, savings account, buy CDs, take out a Mortgage, Car loan, etc. Not to mention that without consumers depending on the banks they wouldn't get bailout or cheap federal funds...
column3: If citizens weren't forced to use banks for so many day to day things, banks couldn't depend on the government for a bailout or any funding.

column2: In the early 90's I was studying Maths of Finance at university and fees and charges were just starting to raise their ugly heads. In hindsight Australia is about 20 years ahead of the US with regards to bank fees and charges and now the amount spent on User Paid fees and charges each year is equivalent to the total amount of profits declared by the Australian banks each year. I was curious and developed the Leveraged Depreciated User Paid Leasing system model at the time to calculate the consolidated impact of levying fees and charges per $1 unit on items that were already depreciable and leasable such as ATMs and PC's. It's not surprising that this simple but userous structure (with a 10%GST) can produce $1.36 in tax for the government and $2.56 in direct profits for the banks while the poor old user has to pay $6 for something that previously only cost the bank $1 in house and the government $1 from the public purse in depreciation, leaving the user and the bank with no net impost.
column3: A bank user has to pay many times more for a service that costs the bank much less.

column2: This problem didn't just arrive with recent regulation. Long ago banks started to look towards fining their customers as a way of making money. This was accompanied by deceptive practices used to maximize the amercable events ergo some of the regulations. Indeed hitting upon fines as a profit center coincided with discovering that gambling with the free money customers provided was more profitable than providing services to customers and the community - like making loans. We all know how that ended. Banks are a regulated industry (just like Wall Street) and the cost of doing business is offset by all that free customer's money and the banking monopoly (freedom from competition) created by the law regulating them. If retail banking is such an unsustainable business model, re-introduce the postal savings system or other government bank with expanded authority to make personal loans.
column3: Bank fees ought to be regulated because banks are too eager to make money off their customers in the form of fees that function like fines. Banks are making more money with services than though offering basic services to the community. The cost of doing business for banks are offset by their customer's money and the banking monopoly.

column2: Those banks have FREE USE OF OUR MONEY for weeks and months and years on end. Their business model is supposed to involve lending that money out at interest and generating profits that way. Fees? What do they need to charge fees for? Greedy bums!
column3: Banks have free use of our money for weeks, months, and years. Banks generate profits by lending out money. Banks do not need more fees.

column2: While it is true that Banks need to cover their costs and even make a profit the problem here is that Bank profits are once again substantial. When Banks show that they are loosing money on every retail customer (not just on offering checking accounts) I'll have some sympathy.
column3: Banks' profits are too large. Banks don't lose money on retail customers.

column2: Here's a funny episode: IRA account was closed February 2011; $12.86 interest was deposited after the balance was $0; February 2012 bank says deposit at least $1,000 or $30 fee will be charged starting April 30, 2012; requests to close essentially dead account have been circumvented with the most wordy, polite and obfuscating excuses; wondering how many years before account is actually closed.
column3: I attempted to close an account in 2011 and in 2012 the bank stated they would charge a $30 if $1000 wasn't deposited, and the account is still open.

column2: The way banks structure their fees for their services is absurd. The free account but profits made through hidden unrelated fees no one expects. It is like grocery stores that offered all their food for free to pull the most possible customers from competitors. But then they charge random cars in the parking lot $100 for parking more than 10 minutes. They charge a $10 surcharge on exit for every child that enters the store (with no signs posted about this on entrance). And an assortment of other fees that change as people catch on. And yet people keep coming for the free food. When the store wants to increase profits it comes up with more absurd fees.
column3: The current fee structure banks impose for their services is absurd. Accounts should not be listed as free, when they include hidden fees.

column2: Why shouldn't banks charge fees for accounts? It costs the bank money to open a branch, hire tellers to work at the branch, set up ATMs around town, produce debit or credit cards, print checks, and support the systems that transfer money electronically throughout the financial system.
column3: It costs the bank money to operate.

column2: How about this? My sister sent me a check for my birthday. I took it to her bank, and with my own i.d. tried to cash it. The teller said no problem ( I didn't have an account at her bank) but that there would be a $6 fee . So the $100 check cost me $6. Is this being ripped off? You bet it is.

column2: This mess began more than 30 years ago when the government did away with the usury laws. Since then it's been open season on bank customers. With the rates imposed and fees added you'd think you were dealing with loan sharks. So far the only difference is that nobody drops by your house to break your knee caps if you overdraw your checking account, miss a payment, or move your money to a credit union. We need to reimpose caps above which no money lender or financial institution can impose fees, interest, or any other charges or fines.
column3: The government getting rid of usury laws allowed banks to charge high fees. Fees and rates should be regulated because it is as if you were dealing with criminals.

column2: Banks have to make their profits somewhere. Overdraft fees were very lucrative (if unsavory). The additional fees we're seeing now are a direct result of the decreased profitability around overdrafts. Consumers really didn't understand the extent to which overdraftees were propping up the free checking account for te rest of us. Also, some fees are designed to encourage unprofitable customers to walk out the door. And you guessed it. Small personal checking account customers who never purchase other products (e.g. mortgages), never generate overdrafts, etc. - we are the proverbial deadbeats. Big banks would love to see us walk to the credit unions. They will even hold the door open for us and wave goodbye.
column3: Banks have to have a way to make profits. To regulate the result of decreased profitability around overdrafts. Overdraftees can affect the checking account system for everyone. Fees can make some people, who would not be desirable customers, choose to not use certain banks.

column2: Unfortunately in this nation owned and led by the greediest, most unethical, and immoral executives America has, none of them care about the American people and wouldn't think twice about keeping a $5 fee instead of letting the baby have some milk. column2: The Center for Financial Services Innovation...that says it all. Looking for innovative new ways to gouge consumers. I did financial services marketing and advertising for years. And I'm always amazed at the different marketing tactics banks use depending on their target audience. For example, I have a relatively high income, while my sister's is low. We both have mortgages with the same large bank. Both of us pay on time every month. But I'm offered special low refinancing rates with no closing costs via FedEx, and the bank sends someone to my home free of charge at my convenience to close, while my sister gets no offers and in fact they refuse to refinance her house at any rate. I can't even imagine the fabulous offers they make to the truly wealthy.
column3: The Center for Financial Services Innovation provides an explanation for bank fees. Banks are constantly looking for innovative ways to pass fees on to consumers. High income customers are receiving more benefits than lower income customers who actually need help financing.

column3: Children go hungry in the deserts finite resources and causes wars between tribes. Overpopulation results in armed conflict if uncontrolled.

column2: All six commentators make valid points. But I'm struck by the fact that none of them discuss the injustice of human beings monopolizing so large a percentage of Earth's habitat and resources, or the resulting ongoing mass extinction of Earth's species. If a particular nation or people were aggressively displacing other nations and peoples, overrunning their land and taking their resources, leaving these others displaced, diminished, even completely exterminated, the world would have no problem calling this behavior by its proper name: genocidal warfare. The modern endless growth economy--dedicated to making ever more people ever wealthier--is interspecies genocide. Its time we ended our war on nature and accepted limits to human numbers and human economic demands.
column3: Often people overlook the fact that humans take up a lot of the Earth's habitat and resources, when discussing the mass extinction of species. Capitalism causes overcrowding to be problematic.

column2: Wrong! Two reasons. One, Malthusianism does not hold, since resource production can go up exponentially too. Two, the population will peak out at 12-15 billion or so, when it will start to shrink, as it has been doing in Europe for decades now. Uncontrolled extrapolation is a trap to avoid.
column3: Resource production can increase exponentially to match population growth. Population will peak and decrease just like in Europe.

column2: Well in the last 50 years there has been at least a small improvement in thinking. One doesn't hear "god will take care of us" or "we have always found new sources of oil before" as much as one used to. But there is still a very limited understanding of the problem, probably because so few of us thought seriously for a minute when our high school teachers were covering entropy and the second law of thermodynamics. The solar constant ultimately determines the carrying capacity since it provides us with all renewable energy sources: wind, water, solar. It must cover not only our daily energy needs, but also the energy needed to recover and reuse all non-renewable resources that we mine and scatter around the world as products. This limiting factor also means of course that all national states will approach zero-growth, steady state economies.
column3: Solar constant ultimately determines the carrying capacity, it provides us with all renewable energy sources: wind, water, solar. It must cover not only our daily energy needs, but also the energy needed to recover and reuse all non-renewable resources. This limiting factor means that all national states will approach zero-growth, steady state economies.

column2: Malthusian [mal-thoo-zhuh n, -zee-uh n] Word Origin adjective "Malthusian. Definition: of or relating to the theories of T. R. Malthus, which state that population tends to increase faster, at a geometrical ratio, than the means of subsistence, which increases at an arithmetical ratio, and that this will result in an inadequate supply of the goods supporting life unless war, famine, or disease reduces the population or the increase of population is checked.. . ." Todays Malthusian scholars somehow seem not to be aware that their theories of "overcrowding" were advanced 200 or so years ago by Tom Malthus--and haven't been validated in experience. It matters not that today's scholars cite overproduction of CO2 due to increases in population as the source of the problem, rather than inability to produce a supply of goods adequate to support life.
column3: Overcrowding theories have never been vaildated. Overproduction of CO2 doesn't matter when there is not enough supplies for all the people on the planet.

column2: Pearce wants to fix the overpopulation problem by, " low-carbon energy, recycling of everything from metals to water and fixing the massive inefficiencies in food production." This will not solve the problem, only temporarily and then exacerbate it. There is only so much hay in the pasture folks, you can stretch that hay out any way you like, but in the end, we must control human growth rates. When we have food, we will reproduce and that creates a host of other issues in the long run.
column3: There are finite limits in the world. Unchecked reproduction causes many other problems.

column2: Laurie Mazur talks of women's rights being the key to population, a mantra embedded in the Rio Declaration of 1992. But this approach, which came to dominate the population field, has not lead to a significant reduction in fertility in many of the most overpopulated countries. Unfortunately, the well meaning leaders of the women's reproductive rights movement have not yet confronted the rights of the future generations of this planet that resources will not, and already cannot sustain. Are they to be doomed to a grim life of chaotic climate, food and water shortages and no jobs? What is clear is that the world is not sustaining the thousands of refugees drowning in the Andaman Sea and Mediterranean Ocean escaping an unsustainable existence.
column3: Though it was speculated that women gaining equal rights would lead to population control, this has not proven true in some of the most overpopulated countries. The pro-life movement does not consider overcrowding and population growth in it's ideology. If the world was sustaining itself thousands of refugees would not be dying trying to find a place to live.

column2: There is another way that our population growth will be our undoing: There are not enough meaningful jobs on the planet for the number of people who are already on it. With our efficiencies in production, and the limits to natural resources, this problem will get worse over time. We do have a population problem, a serious one, but it is more than just numbers and how to feed them. We can make it so large numbers of people do not die, but that doesn't mean this planet can be manipulated so that those same large number of people can truly live.
column3: Overcrowding is a threat because there are not enough meaningful jobs for everyone. The issue will get worse as time goes on because we aren't efficient with our natural resources. We can find ways to keep more people alive, but not necessarily with a great quality of life.

column2: Yes, America needs to get its house in order. Our population is growing by about 30 million per decade!!! Just about all of the population growth results from immigration. So let's reduce immigration and also focus on reducing consumption. Without reduced immigration all our environmental efforts to be more efficient and consume less are swamped and irrelevant.
column3: Populations grow every decade.

column2: If media outlets would be fair and objective and report the news, there would be no need to to Facebook and see what others are talking about. Facebook is a democratization of the news in the sense that you can find stories and opinions that the corporate media are too afraid or intimidated or just plain arrogantly refusing to cover. Bernie Sanders is just one example NYT. Please wake up and do the right thing before you become irrelevant.
column3: Media outlets need to learn to be more fair in their reporting. Facebook shows a wide variety of news, that corporate news sources might not show.

column2: What has been uncovered so far is that there are faceless, nameless people posing as real journalist deciding what stories are important and not important with ZERO oversight from an editorial board or any peer review. Facebook should be taken for what it really is ----- Just a BLOG in the Blogosphere of the Internet. Facebook is only useful for sharing photos of your children or dogs and cats.
column3: There are anonymous people posing as real journalists with no oversight or peer review. Facebook is simply a blog on the internet.

column2: Right on! The watchword for any business, restaurants included, should generally be "the customer is always right." This is especially true with regard to tastes, and appreciation of flavors. People do not all experience the same food the same way and for an egotistic chef to imagine he has the right to determine how much salt should be put on something is ridiculous. The chef doesn't know best for everyone. So keep the salt and pepper shakers. They are the ubiquitous best flavor enhancers around--the very reason they are ubiquitous in any GOOD restaurant IMHO!
column3: Restaurants should not impose their will on customers and allow customers to salt food to their own tastes. People experience food differently and an chef should not have the right to determine how much salt to put on something. Chef doesn't know best for everyone. Salt is one of the best ways to enhance flavor.

column2: I learned to salt in culinary school. If the cooks and the chef are SURE of the flavor level of every dish, then keep the salt off the table. But not every food preparer is perfect. It is presumptive of the chef to think his food is perfectly flavored for every portion of the dish and for the entire meal. I think it is more an ego trip, than assisting the diner.
column3: Not every person who prepares food is perfect. The chef cannot presume to know the salt preferences of their diners.

column2: I don't like the idea that a chef or restaurant owner would make that decision for me, but I have to say that I almost never need to add salt at a restaurant. The food is usually very well seasoned.
column3: Chefs or restaurant owners should not make "salt" for cstomers.

column2: Does not bother me as I have left salt out of my diet for over 40 years. I keep salt on the table for my husband nor do I salt food. If anyone wants to add it to their food they are more than welcome
column3: Anyone is more than welcome to add wanted salt to their food.

column2: For me, it's pretty simple, whenever I go to a restaurant, and don't see salt, pepper, or condiments, I can rest easy knowing that a real, honest to goodness artisan is staffed in the kitchen. I know my food will come out tasting just fine.
column3: If I don't see salt, pepper, and condiments on the table, I know that an artisan is working in the kitchen.

column2: I never add salt to my food at the table -- because I prefer my food to be very lightly salted. It has been my experience that every restaurant I have dined at that has stopped putting salt shakers on the table completely OVERSALTS the food . I no longer eat at any of those places.
column3: I don't add salt at the table.

column2: I am amazed that these chef's think that they might possibly know how each diner likes his or her food seasoned. I find most food at restaurants too salty. My husband is the opposite and almost always adds salt. Salty of the food varies a lot between regions of the country. Chef's should not take away the customers control of this small item. I wish they would salt less in the kitchen.
column3: The chef can't know how each person wants their food seasoned. Tastes vary by region. Consumers should be able to make their own decision about salt.

column2: Frankly, it is arrogant for a chef/restaurant to assume that their food does not need additional seasoning. People have different preferences when it comes to a desire for more salt in their meal. Let the customers choose, and offer salt at the table. I am irked whenever I have to ask for it. Chefs are in the hospitality business, so be hospitable!
column3: The eater might want more salt and the chef is arrogant to ignore this fact. Each person is unique and has their own specific tastes, it should be their personal decision. Chefs should cater to their diners' preferences.

column2: Most restaurant food is already too salty. I'd rather they salted their food LESS and let us control our salt at the table. I don't use table salt, myself. I lightly season my food and then if others want more salt they can have it. Salt should be treated as an adjunct. Food should be seasoned with spices. The salt is there to increase those flavors, not to be a flavor in and of itself. At least that's how it worked in my restaurant, and that's what I do at home now that I'm retired.
column3: The chef should put less salt on the food and let the patron ad more if needed.

column2: Oversalting in the kitchen is the best way to kill a dish. Some chefs have a salty pallate. Tastes good to them but tastes like a salt bomb to others. There are plenty of chefs that fall into this category. Those chefs will continue cooking even after they see dishes getting sent back to the kitchen. If there's a salt shaker at the table they know they can add less salt than they would prefer and let the diner adjust the salt at the table. May the salt shaker remain.
column3: Chefs and consumers have different tastes. Chefs should slightly undersalt food and allow the consumer to decide the proper salt level for their tastes.

column2: I am not a big user of salt, but I like having it available in the event the meal needs it. I don't know why people get upset when people salt before tasting when the restaurants insist on grinding pepper into your food before you have tasted it.
column3: Salt should be available to those who want to use it.

column2: I have a salt sensitivity and have not been able to eat some foods at prepared by the chef. I use just the right amount of salt at home to season dishes. It's a necessary seasoning in most dishes, it just doesn't need to be used in excess. Guess my message is: put those salt shakers on the table for those who enjoy extra salt on their dishes. Please don't have a heavy hand in the kitchen....I'd like to be able to enjoy what I order.
column3: It is important seasoning and can be used in moderation. People who want extra salt should be able to enjoy it.

column2: I find most restaurant food too salty. I know this not so much from the taste but the way my body reacts afterwards. I often wake up in the middle of the night with extreme dry mouth after eating out. Since there are some people who should have little to no salt in their diets for health reasons, I'd prefer to see chefs go very lightly with the salt and then let people add salt if they wish.
column3: Because some people are on salt restricted diets, it would be best to offer salt at the table for discretionary use and for the chef to salt very sparingly in cooking.

column2: I live in Las Vegas where there are plenty of really good restaurants. if i am paying good money for a meal I should be able to season the food with salt and pepper as i see fit. Why should some chef dictate to me what I can and cannot do with my food. There are plenty of famous name restaurants here in Vegas that have salt and pepper shakers on the table.
column3: I should be able to season my food as I wish.

column2: No two people have the same sense of taste nor does any one person have a consistent sense of taste given variables such as response to environmental allergies and recovery from colds. To say that salt is not offered at the table is Bloomberg Nannyish at minimum and downright control freakish. I long ago sought to reduce the salt in my diet and my taste has adjusted over time, but I have not eliminated salt nor do I intend to. Most baked or roasted poultry dishes are horrible without some added salt and there are other foods that cry out for it- popcorn is a good example. Having worked in healthcare for 27 years I have no illusions about the harm that a high sodium diet can have on some people. However, it is also possible to wisely reduce salt intake and still enjoy it in some foods. As the taste is highly subjective and individual I cannot agree with Mr Sbragg.
column3: Everyone has different tastes. Many foods, like poultry or popcorn, require salt for optimal taste.

column2: Biology plays a role in an individual's perception of how salty something tastes. If a chef insists on making the decision of how to properly salt a dish, then some will perceive it as over salted and some as under salted. It's a lot easier to add more salt than to remove salt from food. I always prefer a restaurant to go easy on the salt, and allow me to add what I feel is necessary for my tastes. Otherwise a number of diners are forced into eating food that they might enjoy more, if allowed to have input on how it's salted.
column3: Some people will not agree with the chefs level of saltiness. Customers can add but cannot remove salt to taste. Salt should be decided by the consumer.

column2: I disagree. For some of us, such as runners who go out in the sweltering heat for a long distance run in the desert, replenishing the salt and electrolytes lost during the run is a matter of health and recovery, not merely a flavoring option. I can understand that sedentary people and some chefs might blanch when the see me salting my food at a restaurant. But I'd like them to realize that I am doing so almost as a medicinal application and would prefer they reserve judgment until they've run a dozen miles in my shoes.
column3: Salt is useful for replacing electrolytes lost through exercise. My salt intake is medicinal and catered to my individual needs.
