While I know you can't write a column by committee, I think a columnist that occasionally addressed specific, thoughtful reactions to his/her columns could bring in a lot of readers, and make readers feel they are listened to by the Times.
column3: I have read more than I would have if I hadn't been reading the comments. Comment sections can bring in more readers if the author addressed different reactions to columns.

column2: As a former psychologist and career counselor, I am interested in encouraging forms of expression that reinforce good mental health. On line commenting has been over taken, sabotaged, and abused with a high percentage of mentally unhealthy abusive speech. This one negative aspect is significant enough to justify abolishing commenting. This unhealthy behavior does not serve as a safety valve but rather encourages self destructive ruminating that can explode in violence. Time to bite the bullet and give up on both moderated and unmoderated online comments!
column3: People cannot have educated debates, rather they name call and insult in comment sections. Comment sections can incite violence rather than serving as a healthy release.

column2: I find the comment section indispensable especially when reading an opinion piece in culling the purported facts with other website links, pointing out sloppy reasoning or offering an alternative opinion. Sometimes an article is not complete without the comment section, it is an alternate universe of editors, and though this maybe disconcerting for the authors, I have to imagine it makes them better journalists and writers.
column3: While reading the comment sections postings I find alternative opinion and fixes to incorrectly reported facts from the original article. Comment sections complete incomplete articles even if the authors don't agree, it makes them better journalists.

column2: Foreign agents may use the comments section to make it appear that the American public has opinions that are favorable to the foreign country they represent. I believe this was particularly true for comments on articles about Ukraine and the Russian backed separatists. It seemed to me that many commenters and those who recommended their comments were RT writers or Kremlinbots using pseudonyms.
column3: Comments sections can be used by foreign agents to skew the appearance of public option.

column2: Sorry, I'd feel uneasy if I had to use my real name for EVERYTHING online. People could find me fairly easily, maybe even track me down at work. Besides, I kind of like using a name online that doesn't indicate whether I'm male or female. Thanks to good moderating, we can have useful and interesting discussions on here.
column3: I like being able to use a name that does not indicate gender. With good moderation, useful and interesting discussions can be had.

column2: The quality of reporting and the general knowledge of writers and editors has markedly decreased in the past 30 years. Many of the commentators are more intelligent and knowledgeable than the beat reporters and the columnists. Of course, many comments are of low quality and often historically ignorant but that is more than compensated for by the ones that are of very high quality. Democracy needs a comments section.
column3: There is a marked decrease in the general reporting of writers over the last 30 years. The commentators are often more knowledgeable than the journalists. Comments section enable the democratic discussion of ideas.

column2: The Internet would be a vastly different place if we could somehow do away with anonymity. But would it actually be a better place? In our very polarized world, many people are understandably reluctant to speak out on controversial issues, unless they can do so anonymously. If we want to know what people really think, we need to let them speak anonymously. So long as there has been written communication, people have had that ability, and maybe that right. Before that, people threw rocks under cover of darkness to get their point across. I understand the temptation to demand that people use their real identities, but it seems almost impossible to do in the real world. Even if you ask for a scan of my driver's license, you can't be sure it is really my license, or be sure that it has not been altered.
column3: People are more likely to speak up if they can do so anonymously. Although it might be good to have commenters reveal their true identities, it is impossible to enforce.

column2: i assume the 'microbio' declares my background and competence and avoids unpleasantries known to have occurred to others in the current highly polarized environment. One's argument , if it has merit, should be more important than the name of the person who wrote it. I understand that well thought out ideas and even humor will be remembered longer than a rant and trust the NYT editors will view those with lasting value favorably in their posting decisions.
column3: Arguments within the comment section are more important than the name of the authors. Intellectual ideas will be remembered longer than angry attacks in comments section.

column2: The NYT monitors its comments and avoids the problem. Not all media outlets are in a position to do this. I find the comments useful and interesting as a gauge of how NYT folks are responding to the various ideas found on its pages.
column3: They moniter their comments. The comment sections help me get an idea of how others feel about the articles.

column2: Mr. Wolf sounds as if he would have castigated Mark Twain, and George Sand for using pseudonyms. The fictitious nom de plume is an old and venerable way for writers to express themselves. The actual solution is the one the New York Times employs. Editing irrational or vitriolic commentary, rather than publishing everything, afraid of offending a subscriber here and there if they don't. Instead of threatening to throw out the baby with the bathwater as an alternative, or subjecting the commentariat to TSA type scrutiny before allowing our opinions to be published.
column3: Commentary offers an alternative to all opinions that cannot be published in the commentary.

column2: A great idea that I have implemented in my own case over 5 or more years of commenting. Have I been called names? So what? I agree that it might be wise to permit exceptions. But I fear the exceptions would quickly begin to swallow the rule. I take anonymous comments less seriously than ones that disclose the poster's name -- though, granted, it is not always easy to tell them apart.
column3: Comment sections are an important place for discussion even if some posters abuse them.

column2: There may be unpleasant racial and sexual truths. If they are repugnant, that is all the more reason to express them. That one doesn't like hearing a particular truth is probably a good reason to think one needs to hear it and learn from it, not that it should be suppressed as dangerous information.
column3: It is good to express opinions even if repugnant. Comment sections provide a place for people to hear opinions other than their own and learn, without suppressing them.

column2: Obviously i am not using my legal name. I only comment on the NY Times which supposedly is moderated. I did at one time use my real name with no problems. One day, however, a man said "I would like to break your arm" in response to my comment. How that comment slipped through i have no idea. I decided it would be smart to drop my name and start over. There are enough nuts out there as it is and i don't want to be hassled online or even receive a visitor who wanted to "deal with me." I live alone and i just feel better doing this. Besides, i kind of like my "new" name.
column3: In the past I safely used my real name. Comment sections provide an avenue for unwanted hassle and even interaction with so-called "nuts.".

column2: I wonder of what use my comments would be without that I stood by them. Do I honestly have any crucial wisdom to impart upon the world that would be of such benefit that even doing so anonymously would be of service to the community? Or does it just make me feel good to spew? But truthfully - the reaction given by the readership here - anonymous or not - has got to be a reasonable barometer of the feelings of the community, whether or not an individual feels comfortable posting as a person, or only as a glyph. And there is value in that for us all.
column3: Comment sections give value by showing the feelings of the community.

column2: I would actually repeat any comment I have made online in person- and I have some very harsh critical opinions- but it is impossible to have a critical comment on a subject without someone being offended and flagging the comment and having it removed- for example ANY criticism towards Israel or zionism is immediately flagged and removed- is seems that Israel supporters have the thinnest skin when criticized!
column3: You cannot comment your honest opinions without it being flagged by someone who doesn't agree, rendering comment threads pointless.

column2: Sorry, Facebook doesn't do much better. There are plenty of trolls on Facebook and those trolls have no problems expressing themselves. There are bigots, liars, people who love to say sensational things, people who will insinuate in order to hurt others and they are all on Facebook. There's plenty of vitriol on Facebook as well. Try to have a conversation in some of the groups and there's always someone who comes on with a completely uncalled for comment.
column3: Facebook is full of trolls, who attack others on comments sections. On Facebook comments there are people who are there to attack and hurt other people. People make uncalled for comments.

column2: Women take a risk in using their real name. It is not worth it. There are too many seriously deranged people out there. Beyond that I have a name that was once used by a famous stripper and also by a character in a comic strip. Over the years my phone number has received some very interesting unsolicited calls and I have been told me real name was not real (the comic strip interpretation) including on my resume. Monitored comments is the sensible solution. And yes, I avoid Facebook because of the name required mandate.
column3: There are too many deranged people out there to use your real name especially if you are a woman.

column2: Ms. Lemieux wants to silence those who disagree with her. Wouldn't someone with an open mind want to know what readers with a different viewpoint have to say? Or, wouldn't a thoughtful writer want to read well written comments praising their writing and opinion but perhaps offering some added insight? I agree with a need for moderators, but to scrap the comments section altogether is to throw away the best part of this online newspaper.
column3: A person with an open mind should want to know what readers with different viewpoints have to say, and a thoughtful writer should want to read well written comments, praising and offering insight. Moderation might be needed, but the comments section is the best part of the online newspaper.

column2: In all honesty, if I were a published author (as I aspire to be someday), I might not want to read even the good comments about my work. I do know some authors who do not read either the good nor the bad. That, to me, is understandable. However, why should the rest of the world feel the same way? If someone wants to offer an insight - and other people read it and get something from it (whether or not the original author gets involved), why deny that basic right to free speech? There will always be bullies, online or in the real world. You cannot stop them completely, but to not allow the general public to have discourse because trolls exist, then why write anything in the first place? You may as well keep it in diary form, to be seen by no one by yourself.
column3: The basic right to free speech should not be denied if other people can read and benefit from someone's insight, whether or not the original author gets involved. There will always be people who make negative comments but comment sections allow a place for thoughtful discussions on issues affecting our communities. Getting rid of comments sections to stop trolls prevents the rest of the public from engaging in meaningful discourse.

column2: The NY Times comments are the only ones I read anymore, so I would hate for it to be discontinued. I can imagine the work involved in moderating the comments; unfortunately, I don't see a way around it anymore to keep thought-provoking, and informative dialog going. It is sad, but it is also obvious that there are more than a few people who troll various sites for issues/people that bother them so they can unleash their self-righteous intolerance and name-calling. Ironically, it is usually these same people projecting their negative attributes to others. I enjoy the NYT comments section. Most of the comments seem well thought out and on-point, and the commenters are very knowledgeable. I frequently learn something new or see a point of view I hadn't considered.
column3: Comments sections have failed with the exception of the New York Times. comments sections have been blocked due to disrespectful words. I enjoy the NYT comments. The majority of the comments are accurate and concise provided by knowledgeable people. People can learn a lot from reading the comments.

column2: Democracy is coming / to the USA. - Leonard Cohen. COMMENTS are a major factor in this democratization, although, yes of course, each site needs a moderator to keep the conversation level and the tone constructive. Only an authoritarian sinecure of the MSM will argue otherwise.
column3: Comments, with good moderation, are a part of democracy.

column2: Is it not unfair for a writer in a public forum to be able to say whatever they want through whatever bias they have and personal agenda without any recourse? These people should know that their words are like bullets and they they can expect return fire from those of us who may think differently. This is still America where contrary opinions are both legal and valuable if we are ever to be able to compromise and get results for the people. Our system is designed to take into consideration all views and to come to some compromise. Even the President welcomes competing opinions. Shouldn't writers?
column3: Words matter and people who think differently should be able to respond. In America differing opinions are not only allowed but they have value teaching us to compromise for the best results. We are able to take into consideration all views and come to a compromise. Writers should welcome opinions.

column2: I think it's great that the reading public can now freely comment on articles and editorials in the corporate media. It's about time that the people have the right to talk back to the erstwhile gatekeepers who try to decide what's news and how it should be presented. If writers and journalists can't stand the heat they should grow a thicker skin or get out of the kitchen.
column3: The reading public can use comments sections to voice their opinion on media. People have the right to talk back to the gatekeepers who determine what news is presented and how.

column2: Many times I find comments more interesting and accurate then the articles. The writer of this article thought it ok when writing comments and now feels something has changed somehow for the worse? I do not agree. Does that make me a troll?
column3: Comments sections have not failed because the comments are often engaging and insightful.

column2: Some other sites or newspapers may allow vulgarity and animosity but I have never seen it on NYT, and in fact I feel the comments make the article more interesting and sparks discussion. I look forward to reading others' thoughts on the subjects explored by the authors of the articles published here. On other sites, I rarely read the comments. I do appreciate the moderation very much. I hope NYT does not do away with comments.
column3: The NYT seems to have good and clean comments unlike some other sites. Comments add interest and spark discussion. They provide other peoples perspectives on topics.

column2: I read NY Times and Washington Post but only read and occasionally respond with comment to NY times articles. NY times management of comments is exemplary and enlightening. I do not like to read David Brooks or Douthat without reading Gemli comments.
column3: Management of comments are exemplary and enlightening.

column2: The New York Times has it right. A moderated comments facility provides immense value to readers seeking to understand the considered views of fellow human beings. Understanding the interests of others and seeking sensible consensus and compromise is one of the key foundations of a democracy. In times of bleak news, the NY Times comments pages provide a heartbeat of global perspective that reminds one the world is full of good, interested and decent people who care enough to speak out.
column3: Comments, when moderated, provide value to readers. Comment sections allow for understanding of other views and reaching a consensus and compromise just like in any democracy. The NY Times comments remind of the good and decent people in the world who speak out where there is a lot of bleak news elsewhere.

column2: Buyer beware. Most comments pages are a dead zone. On the other hand, I love the NYTs comments - so insightful. I look forward to reading them and they are a significant addition to the piece. What is better than hearing what my fellow human beings (and NYT readers) have to say? There are several other sites that I feel the same way about. Other than that I just avoid them.
column3: Most comment pages are inactive. Comments on the New York Times are insightful. They add a lot to the piece and I look forward to reading comments. Hearing what fellow readers have to say is a positive.

column2: I don't think I would even read the Times any more if it didn't have a moderated comments section. I don't trust the reporting any more without checking the comments. I am sure the Times knows how much valuable content they are getting for free.
column3: Some readers would not read the Times if not for a comments section. I need the comments to trust the reporting in the article. Comments are valuable content.

column2: Even the comments on the Washington Post are appalling. While one might think there would be some intelligent commentary accompanying news articles in that respected venue, a relatively small posse of regulars-on both sides of the political spectrum-seize every chance to hurl utterly unrelated partisan insults at one another. Sometimes I think the Post just republishes the same comment section day after day. And then I kick myself for wasting my time looking for signs of intelligent life. The Times, on the other hand, does a great job of moderating.
column3: Even the Washington Post comments section is abused. Comments sections are full of partisan individuals looking for a fight, not a conversation.

column2: The Guardian has recently cut down on the numbers of articles that allow reader comments. Like the Times, the comments are well moderated and also often more interesting and informative than the actual article. I notice I am reading the Guardian less, the site just isn't as interesting without the reader comments.
column3: Well moderated comments can be more interesting and useful than the article. Now that the Guardian has removed comments, I am not interested in reading it very much anymore.

column2: Comments are a useful and frequently informative part of online news; they should be encouraged but much more closely monitored. For openers, commenters should be allowed only one comment per article to avoid these ubiquitous back and forth , witless arguments which often clog the comments section. Obscene, vulgar and personal attacks should be edited out, but care must be exercised. Many subjects almost demand strong comments which some may find offensive, but do not really cross the line. Some are clearly at the far left, right, or some other extreme, but often bring out ignored, but important points of view. In addition, many articles and editorials contain claims that are either wrong or at best distorted, despite usually high standards of editorial review. Comments are essential for correcting these problems. Some blogs, like Prof Juan Cole usually contain thoughtful, informed and useful information. Others seem to call forth the the worst forms of trolls, bullys, idiots and haters. Proper monitoring, I believe can correct the abuses and allow a very important part of the internet to thrive.
column3: Comments are informative. Some subjects require strong comments, that might offend some without crossing the line. Comment sections allow different points of view to be heard. Many editorials are wrong or distorted and their claims are corrected in the comments.

column2: Human moderation is the key. There are terms and conditions, and if a commenter fails to meet them, their comment does not get posted. The network should disallow anonymous posting. This means comment sections cost a newspaper more money, as they generate money. Do they make a profit? As newspapers are firing employees, it becomes a hard choice. If disabling a comment section does not hurt the bottom line, get rid of it. No one wants to know what is at the anonymous back of anyone's mind in the age of social media.
column3: Moderation is the key.

column2: Moderate and block if necessary. Without readers comments the Times would be greatly diminished. I'm as interested in them as I am in my most respected reporters and columnist. Comments sections that are not moderated get no attention from me. The Times is to be commended for supporting readers comments even though they are often managed arbitrarily as Margaret Sullivan's last column's comments were and are. Where probably hundreds of readers positive remarks were not posted. it was an important column from an admired writer.
column3: Moderators are needed. Publications like The Times would be less interesting without comments. The comments sections are becoming not available because of insane words.

column2: Moderated comments are an excellent way for original ideas to be heard from the most unlikely corners. Sifting through a lot of unmoderated comments is not only distressing for the author, it is discouraging for the reader and serious commentator. Publications that want to engage a mass audience and those that seek to interact with more narrow expert audiences should put the resources into professionally moderating comments.
column3: Moderated comments are a great way for unlikely sources to have their opinions heard. Publications that want to engage an audience should be prepared to moderate feedback.

column2: Media has found too much truth in readers' comments and has started censoring views contrary to who pays the bills. The Daily KOS for example has flagged more negative views on Hillary than any other Progressive site. This is NOT freedom of speech when others have the power to silence your opinion. And even the NYT was guilty of a lack of attention to Sanders campaign for awhile. Yet Trump has garnished more free publicity than them all because of the increased readership draw, therefore more profits in their advertising dollars. And around the world we are laughed at because we have a reality show candidate, another family oligarch, and all the other clowns on the Republican wagon. Welcome to the Freakshow.
column3: Truthful comment sections have failed because of censorship. You don't have freedom of speech when others have power to silence your opinion.

column2: I have to agree with all the other posters that a moderated comments section is one of the things that makes the NYT great and worth the cost of subscription. I like to read the intelligent thoughts of so many of its readers and find that often there is much to be learned from the commentors' writings.
column3: New York Times's comment section makes them great because they are moderated. It is often educational to read commentors' opinions.

column2: The best comments are those that make me think about things differently. They often introduce thoughts and ideas that haven't been given a voice in regular editorial content. And often they are those with which I disagree. Such comments are rare--a rate I would guess at less than 1 in 20. But if they introduce me to a new way of thinking, or of just understanding my fellow humans, it's well worth sorting through the other 19. Editing makes all the difference. The Times' editing is, to some extent, crowd sourced--the most popular comments are given prominence. I will, from time to time, up-vote a comment with which I disagree just because it introduces a new idea.
column3: Comment sections with good comments help me see different views. Comment sections provide a voice to thoughts and ideas outside the scope of regular editorial content. Finding one gem in the comments section is worth all of the other problems.

column2: I am extremely grateful for the moderators at NYT, and I shudder to think of the things they must have to read through. The NYT comments are the only ones I currently read. I follow many comment writers here, both agreeing and disagreeing with them. Some I look forward to, if only to have my own world view challenged. It would be too easy to read only those opinions that I share, and have myself devolve into a participant in the echo chamber that seems to feed too many steadfastly held beliefs out there. As for the anonymity, I never really thought that I might be hiding behind my user name. It goes way back to 1999 when I first subscribed. I am Tom Tyson, and I live in Sheboygan, Wisconsin. You can call me Tom.
column3: Comment sections provide divergent opinions and different world views.

column2: I agree with many of my fellow commenters that the NYT does an excellent job of moderating comments, and I am extremely grateful for the resources they expend to offer this service. Being able to comment has made a big difference to me as a professional --I find it an invaluable outlet. Plus, reading NYT comments generally makes me feel pretty hopeful about humanity, as a matter of fact.
column3: The NYT always does a good job modding comments. Commenting is an invaluable outlet in my experience as a professional. Reading comments can make one feel better about humanity.

column2: Without open comment, I rarely any longer bother to read the article. Unlike Jamilla, I always check the comments first to see whether the article will be exciting. The NYTimes is the only venue that censors over half of my remarks, the Post and WSJ almost never. I don't mind offending, but find what is censored 100% here is trying to be funny or ironic. I noticed even as a kid that the liberal elite has zero sense of humor....
column3: Many things that are censored are trying to be funny or ironic.

column2: One of my favorite sections of the printed NY Times is the letters to the editor. The comments sections on the website are even more pleasing, because there are more comments than could possibly be printed, most of which are very well written. I recognize that moderation is essential, and hope that the Times will continue to devote resources in that direction.
column3: Comments are plentiful and generally well written.

column2: Another tragedy of the commons. For newspapers, restricting access to paid subscribers would probably end this problem, or ameliorate it enough. Non-subscribers could solve math problems or the like before being given access to make comments, one problem solved per comment made. Skin needs to be in the game or there are no rules.
column3: Restricting access to paid subscribers and people who solve simple problems before posting would end the problem. Unless commenters have investment in the story, they won't behave appropriately.

column2: I learn quite a lot from NYT comments, often and in particular from thoughtful comments by authors who think differently from me. I find them valuable. I think the Times' general level of commentary is good. This in part results from the Times' curating its comments, which filters the merely shrill or ad hominem screeds. I recognize this also introduces curatorial bias, but for me, the reduction in noise is welcome. I hope the Times continues to solicit reader commentary. I think its system is working well.
column3: Comment sections have varied and valuable opinions. I think the general level of comments in the Times are good.

column2: I personally think that any organization allowed to provide Press Cards to its employees should be required by the law to have a public section comment on its website. Think about it, people are being put in jail to protect the right of journalists. The least they can do is defending the freedom of speech of others, journalists need to be held accountable on that, a right without a duty is an oligarchic priviledge. They should be required to provide and sustain a space for open debate for any information they provide. Comments sections have fails because media failed them by treating them as after thoughts, and under investing in them. What's missing is a whole ecosystem of accountability as far as journalism and freedom of speech are concerned.
column3: Comment section have failed because they do not provide a space for open debate. Comment sections have their disadvantages. Comments sections fail because they are underfunded. Journalism and freedom of speech are missing an ecosystem of accountability.

column2: The New York Times often reinforces its editorial biases by carefully editing out comments from readers who do not agree with them. Its comments sections are thus made into a propaganda device, adding force to the paper's views. The comment from readers of the Washington Post are too often degraded by the inclusion of personal attacks upon other posters.The glue--rubber form of discourse.
column3: Comments are not reliable because they are edited. Comment sections are just a propaganda device. Commenters on the Washington POst are often degraded and receive personal attacks.

column2: I appreciate the fact that the NYT moderates comments, even if it means mine don't go up for 12 or 18 hours. That said, there does seem to be a decline recently in the quality of some comments on your site, which may reflect growing crassness that you can't always catch, or that you're letting more get through without moderation. Please stand by your principles and keep the conversation civil.
column3: When comments are moderated, it is appreciated by people like me.

column2: Comments sections provide an important outlet for people who may not otherwise have a sounding board. Though it may be true that truly illuminating comments are few and far between, there is value in people being able to voice their opinion. Of course, there are people who take advantage of it with vile comments, so that is why we need quality moderators.
column3: Comments sections are useful, they provide a way for people to speak their minds. Comment sections provide a place for people to have their opinion heard.

column2: But what if Ms. Lemieux has an error in her post/article? No one is perfect, & there are cases where dates, figures, etc. may appear in error. If the author claims to never read the comments, how will she know if there are technical errors/ Even the best websites with editors still need correction from time to time.
column3: Some of the dates and figures may be in error by mistake. Even the best writers and editors need correction, sometimes.

column2: In many cases, I get more from the comments section on this site than from the article. I like to hear what regular people are dealing with in daily life rather than the "Yipee! The economy is great because these numbers say so" type comments.
column3: Comments can be more valuable than the articles themselves sometimes. It's preferable to hear what people are really dealing with rather than mindless comments devoid of thought.

column2: 1) Except for updates and corrections to the story, authors who get involved in the comments section of their articles are not doing themselves any service. 2) It may come as a surprise, but authors of articles are not omniscient. Comment sections usually bring out pertinent points and perspectives that the author omits. 3) It is important, especially for social and politics issues to understand not only the content of an article but what the opinion of the public is toward the article that can be particularly important, and more relevant than any poll. 4) The internet is, by nature, interactive. If you present topics of current interest and don't give people the ability to interact with them, people will go elsewhere to where they can. 5) Most people want to have a discussion about issues that of importance to them, few simply want to sit and be lectured to.
column3: They expose important points often left out by the author. Comment sections provide the public's opinion of an article more accurately than polls. The internet allows people to seek out topics that interest them. People want to discuss issues rather than be told what to think.

column2: It would be an enormous mistake to get rid of comments sections as so often the comments outshine the actual article and offer a range of opinions no single author can compete with. As others have said, comments generally needs to be monitored which obviously has a financial cost to it, but it would be impossible to go back to a world where only the author gets to weigh in.
column3: Comments are often better than the article itself.

column2: I view comments as part of he cost of doing business and think they should remain. I scroll over the vulgar, bigoted and racist ones but have learned much from additional views contributed by people worldwide. Comments provide new dimension to stories and sometimes vital insight.
column3: Comments are part of the cost of doing business. Comments from individuals and their viewpoints has brought new insight to topics. Comments give new perspectives and context to stories.

column2: Aside from the NYT, participating in most other comment-enabled media is often like a Trump rally with its mindless vitriol and verbal violence. Who needs to be exposed to that and how does that benefit civil discourse, the basis of any democratic society's ability to thrive.
column3: With the exception of the NYT. Comments often show mindless vitriol and verbal violence.

column2: I don't think comments sections have failed; the media have failed. I see several things happening; - first, the fat cats who control these things (the press, newsletters, etc.) don't want to be publicly embarrassed by well-written, cogent counter arguments; and two, they have found out that they can't hire editors to handle the volume for thirty cents a day. The sheer volume itself is an indicator of how deep the sense of abandonment is among the hoi polloi.
column3: Comment sections have not failed.  The media has failed. Publications don't want to be embarrassed by well written, coherent arguments, and they are unable to hire editors for a low cost to handle the job.

column2: Don't jettison them altogether, moderate them the way the Times does. I love reading the comments in the Times, they are mostly well-written, and sometimes extremely well written, and I often learn more about the topic and various ways of thinking about it. Thanks, all you regular Times commentators! But, I would agree that most sites that don't moderate their comments are cesspools of vitriol and snark, and not worth reading at all.
column3: Often times, I gain important insight and knowledge from the comment section.

column2: The problem is how nasty, vulgar, and hate filled many of those unmoderated comments can be. Until the web provided unfiltered commentary, an editor always moderated publication. What we have in unmoderated commentary is often not the correcting of misstatements, or the expanding of the conversation, but commenters attacking other commenters, hurling insults, changing the subject to beat the commenter's drum. We get lots of Obama hate even when the subject isn't Obama. If we had a culture of common courtesy before this, it's been severely jeopardized by coarse talk in comment sections. We even see that coarseness celebrated now as a good thing.
column3: Comments sections, when unfiltered, will always be vulgar, nasty, and hate-filled. Comment sections devolve into insults and demagoguery. People do not show respect in comments sections, which takes away from their value.

column2: Oftenthe comments sections are where the biased reporting is set to rights. Unfortunately for those of us who used to rely on the NYT to be unbiased straightforward reporting, thst has changed. As a result, opinions are presented as facts. Words pregnant with multiple meanings are used to slant stories to placate corproate owners. Comments give those of us who read other sources like European papers to as a bit of balance and to fact check the fact checkers. Comments are important. Those who don't like them have very likely been found out once to often by observant readers and they want it to stop! Let the people talk.
column3: Biased reporting is called out in the comment section. Comments allow those with other knowledge to act as a balance and fact check the article.

column2: Comments are necessary because Opinion pieces and publications are often promoting a narrow agenda that is masquerading as majority opinion and settled debate. Comments section balances out the opinion and offers an alternate view as well as evidence that contradicts the opinion piece. That is what a good debate is about. Comments should be moderated but with a light touch that allows legitimate discussion to get through. I would not read any article or publication that does not allow comments to get through. My opinion of an editorial or commentary immediately goes down and I ascribe less value to that article if it does not accept comments. Not accepting comments means that the author is afraid of debate and criticism and has this superior attitude, that I know more than you and therefore you have to accept my opinion as the the final word on this topic. No you are not, and no I don't have to!
column3: Comments sections are necessary to give a wide variety of opinions. Comment sections allow other views to be heard. Moderated comments allow legitimate discussion. Comment sections add value to an editorial or commentary; the lack of comments earns the item less respect from the reader. Not accepting comments means the author is shying away from debate.

column2: One does NOT have to read the comments, and one can easily skip over the hate. But often I learn more from the comments than from the article, story, or opinion piece. Sadly, the media is so biased and slanted (NYT included) that without the comments one simply does not really know what is going on.
column3: No one is forced to read the comment section. People learn a lot from comment sections. The media is biased, and comment sections can help one understand what is really going on.

column2: Comment sections are important in understanding the viewpoints and passions that may incite people to disagree. In the empathetic exercise of understanding why people think or feel how they do, we can better understand their argument so that it can be fought with reason - instead of dismissed on grounds that one is crazy or bigoted. Personally I love reading the opinion pieces where multiple writers take a different spin on the same prompt, and comments sections allow a microcosm to weigh the strengths and weaknesses of dozens of perspectives.
column3: Comment sections are important to understand why people disagree. Comment sections have not failed because with out them it cannot be seen how people feel and there is no place to create reason instead of dismissal. Comment sections provide different views on opinion pieces. Comments sections permit a reader to analyze many different perspectives in one place.

column2: Until recently I was a frequent contributor to the comment section of my local newspaper. When I began contributing I had hoped for intelligent and meaningful discussion and debate concerning the subject. What I had found was a medium consisting of contributors who, by appearances, thrive on belittling and disparaging attacks on those who don't share their beliefs. After a few years, I removed my profiles due to the increasing belittlement and disparagement of posters who may disagree with ones opinion. These forums appear, to me, nothing more than an electronic school yard full of anonymous bullies who have little to offer to any debate or discussion. I welcome the moderation the NY Times offers the readers and contributors to the online comments. Regards, Dan
column3: I recently stopped contributing to the comment section of my local newspaper. Comment sections have people who attack those who disagree with them. I stopped posting after years of attacks. Comment sections have devolved into anonymous school yard bullying, offering no debate or discussion.

column2: The Slowly Boiled Frog is mostly about LGBT advocacy. I frequently have posts with 100  comments (unmoderated). My experience is that opponents to gay rights tend to behave themselves; framing their arguments as inoffensively as possible. Meanwhile my core readers refine and shape their arguments accordingly which, I think, serves them and us. I have learned a thing or two from a dedicated reader. I have also witnessed opponents gaining a greater understanding of our needs and concerns. No, I think that the comments section is a very good thing.
column3: Opponents tend to behave themselves and frame their arguments inoffensively. Comment sections permit opposing sides to see and understand the other side of a debate.

column2: Comment sections are forms of direct engagement with customers and outlets that let them run wild without supervision have themselves to blame for the vitriol. Engagement is too valuable to the organization for it to give up and eliminate comments. As a form of engagement, which drives loyalty and repeat business, it must be invested in by paying for moderators. If your comments section is failing don't blame the haters, blame yourself for lack of investment.
column3: Comment sections allow customers to have direct engagement. Engagement in the comment section is valuable to the organization.

column2: I agree with J.L. that it's time to give up on comments and save the staff the unpleasant task of reading them as well as the expense of moderators. Free speech is precious but is easily abused in non productive ways. Let's revert to letters to the editor and other forms of essays that rely on reason and admit failure with the online comment experiment.
column3: Comments are not worth the hassle and expense. Free speech is easily abused in non productive ways. Online comments are a failed experiment and we should go back to letters to the editor that require at least an essay format.

column2: While it's true that many unmoderated comments sections can become sewers (the NY Daily News section was an absolute cesspool...), moderated comments sections like those The Times actually make a tremendous contribution to both reader understanding of the issues and our political process. I would also stipulate that allowing anonymous comments can indeed be problematic, and that commentators should be willing to disclose their identity when expressing their opinion - and thus expose themselves to the potential scrutiny that goes along with doing this.
column3: Comment sections can be full of bad language if left unmoderated.

column2: I agree with some sort of moderation, including blocking the repeatedly abusive. There is no need for anonymity but it does help encourage the comments from insiders on various issues. "Comments" sections seem to me to satisfy the "Ray Healey rule of debate" (my dad) who said that you should not enter into an argument unless you are prepared to be persuaded. If I were the publisher, my columnists would read the comments, or go back to blogging.
column3: Comment sections satisfy the argument that you should  not enter into an argument unless you are prepared to be persuaded.

column2: Please do not take away the comment section in the NY Times! I will occasionally read comments on more conservative publications and marvel at the time people take to post hateful, nasty comments. But when I read the NY Times comment section, my faith in humanity is restored; not only are the comments smart and well thought out, but because the Times has strict standards for publishing comments, there's certainly disagreement but never direct hatred and threats.
column3: Some comments sections, like the NY Times, are well moderated and full of intellectual, thoughtful comments.

column2: They may be trying to close the achievement gap, but are they doing so at the expense of good teachers? Good teachers are the ones who love to teach and want to be in the classroom for the long haul. Every major newspaper reports of budget cuts to educaion on the local level and of teacher layoffs. It is an insult to hear of hard working certified teachers being replaced by someone who is marking time for a year or two until they get into law school or find something that pays better.
column3: Good teachers will teach because they want too, not because of Teach for America's programming. Across the states we are seeing many teacher layoffs and budget cuts. I am insulted that  good teachers being replaced by teachers waiting for a year or two to get into law school or a better paying job.

column2: Foote quotes someone who compares TFA volunteers to Army recruits. Even there, in fact, TFA suffers by comparison. Soldiers spend more time in basic training than the few weeks that TFA recruits do, let alone all the additional training specialists get. So what she's saying, effectively, is that the message of TFA is that teaching is less difficult than learning to march, obey orders and fire a gun.
column3: It's easier to march, obey orders, and fire a gun than to teach, according to TFA.

column2: This article screams entitlement. After a year, you're an expert? Having been in the trenches of education reform for 25 years before becoming a classroom teacher a few years ago, I can tell you that your youthful arrogance is extremely naive. Whatever talk Washington is talking today will be different than the talk Washington will be talking in a few years. In the meantime, y'all keep flitting in and out of these children's worlds and patting yourselves on the back for making such a difference. I used to admire Teach for America back in the day when it was beginning. It is now populated by such an entitled group of self-serving neophytes who believe only they have THE true answer to the problems of public education that I have lost all respect. Oh, and dear - could you a) list each of the "much easier ways to burnish a resume," and b) look the students and their families in the face when you speak of ",,,hard labor in some of the crummiest classrooms in America?" I'm sure they'd appreciate the reference.
column3: The group is comprised of self-serving individuals no longer focused on the issues surrounding public education.

column2: Teach for America has done nothing for public school teachers's status. The only thing it has done is fetishize its own image, to create a trendy CV filler for cossetted Ivy Leaguers. The vast majority of TFA teachers don't stay in the profession, so the job becomes little more than a balm for their conscious before they move on to JP Morgan Chase and like-minded capitalist enterprises. It takes more than two years to become a good teacher, so if TFA has such a low retention rate for its students, how can it be rated a success? The fact that admission is difficult doesn't mean its a good program.
column3: TFA is just CV-fodder and not helpful for teachers. TFA doesn't train career teachers, but is a stop-gap for more lucrative employment. TFA has a low retention rate so it is not always considered successful.

column2: A retired teacher who observed, and often mentored, many Teach for America teachers, I whole-heartedly support Ms. Crocco's observations. In what other profession would it be assumed that minimal training, no matter how well-educated one happens to be, is sufficient to enter the field: law, medicine? The fact we not only allow it, but encourage such an approach in eduction to me says a great deal about how teaching is viewed in this country, that is, it is not truly a profession. One will never build a first-class educational system based on this widely held conviction. For further thoughts, I refer the reader to the book by Diane Ravitch (one of the best historians of American schools) The Death and Life of the Great American School system.
column3: No other field would rely on minimal training before entering the field, and this should be no different. We can't raise the status of teachers or build a first-class educational system in this country until we view teachers as true professionals.

column2: I wonder how having one or two Teach for America teachers at a school can make a difference. A few children, lucky to be in those classes, may benefit but how does it benefit the school as a whole? And what does it do for the morale of the regular teaching staff, many of whom may be wonderful, dedicated teachers to have these neophytes who come with a label of special, gifted drop into their schools as though manna from heaven? Finally, do these special, gifted new teachers have some kind of solution for the poverty and other conditions that surely have at least, if not more, to do with the condition of their schools and their academic achievement than does the ability of the teacher? Can they magically help the parent who doesn't have the education to help or encourage the child? Can they promise these kids that if they work hard and do well, they will have a better life?
column3: TFA does not help public school teachers as a whole, there are some passing benefits for a class or two but it makes me wonder about the students not in those classes or the school itself benefiting. TFA decreases morale of regular teachers by promoting inexperienced teachers over them. Do these special, gifted new teachers have some kind of solution for poverty, and other conditions to do with the condition of their schools, and their academic achievement than does the ability of the teacher? Can they magically help the parent who doesn't have the education, or helps/encourages the child?.

column2: There is currently a glut of qualified teachers. Why are we taxpayers paying millions of dollars for TFA and, here in NYC, NYC Teaching Fellows, et al while other grad students like myself are struggling to get through paying our own way and facing more and more miserable job prospects?? Why should I (and laid off teachers) have to compete with govt-sponsored, less-qualified drones who are hand-picked for their willingness to follow blindly if not for the fact that they water down the labor force in a period when the government is trying to undercut and underfund US education?
column3: We currently have a glut of teachers. Tax money going to TFA is unfair to other people who struggle to pay their own way through school and still lack good job opportunities. Good teachers shouldn't be forced to compete for jobs against those who have no true skills but are picked by the government because they follow along like sheep. This is simply another way the government is undermining public education in the US.

column2: Many TFA folks are feeling defensive these days, and rightly so. The program promises more than it can deliver. It is not the fault of these idealistic and/or ambitious young people that the program has been overly touted as the silver bullet for all education's problems. There is nothing wrong with leaving education after two years, becoming an administrator or going to law school. The problem is that attrition is basically a design feature of the program. An unprepared teacher in a high needs classroom will burn out in two years. I almost did, until I realized that I needed to set boundaries and have a life. The problem is that students pay by losing energetic teachers every year, would-be teachers are discouraged and leave the classroom, and the taxpayers are footing too much of the bill for a program with questionable returns. There needs to be an overhaul if the public is to be expected to continue supporting a program that is not successful in helping create long term stability in schools.
column3: TFA cannot live up to its promise to solve all of education's problems, notwithstanding the good intentions of its young teachers. It is ok to leave teaching after two years. TFA has short term gain over long term loss. TFA has high turnover by design and is expensive.

column2: Some of my best students--bright, knowledgeable, committed--wanted to teach for America. I advised them against it. They did not have experience. Schools deserve the best teachers possible, especially in challenging schools. Being a good and effective teacher requires years of training and then continuing education,, not just in one's subject, but also in pedagogy, didactics, classroom management, organization, etc. Other countries train teachers much better and longer: they have years of specialized course work and then up to two years of assistant teaching. It pays off. Like the structural inequality that finances schools through property taxes, teacher training in the US is vastly uneven and thus perpetuates social inequality and hinders economic progress. We need uniform standards across states, equal funding for all schools, and a better education for educators.
column3: Good teachers need both experience and education.

column2: As someone who attended an elementary school which received TFA teachers and as an 'elite' college graduate who saw classmates fight for spots, I have mostly contempt for Teach For America. However, I see that one thing that high flying elementary education systems around the world have in common is that teaching is a prestigious career that the top college students fight for. Look at South Korea. If TFA starts America along that path, then I suppose it can be endured.
column3: TFA has made teaching positions something that the best and brightest are in competition for. TFA increases interest in public education teachers so what I believe to be negative about it can be tolerated.

column2: The success stories highlighted here seem to be away from the classroom; why is that ? Because the reward system is skewed away from the very very hard work of the great classroom teacher. I understand that the idea is to use these talented few to create more great teachers. This is not a new model, however; the status quo is largely predicated on it. Make classroom teaching as financially rewarding as staff work and you'll get there. Who stands in the door( like a George Wallace) blocking this kind if revolutionary reform? Da Teachers Unions...
column3: The hard-working great classroom teacher is not rewarded under TFA system. TFA does not help because teaching needs to be more financially sound as a career  to have positive returns to the public school system.

column2: Teaching is a profession. Who would go to a college graduate with no specialized skills rather than to a trained doctor to diagnose and treat a medical problem? Who would trust that same unspecialized college graduate to build a bridge or argue a case in court? Why then do we think that college graduates, albeit bright, well-intentioned, and enthusiastic ones, are ready to teach our children when they have had no educational training? It is an insult to their students.
column3: People prefer professional people who have actually been trained. TFA does not provide skilled teachers to students.

column2: Why is the queen's retirement even a subject for debate? She is of sound mind and body and clearly is not ready to abdicate. Most monarchs reign until death if they are capable. Charles (and William) will just have to wait.
column3: Why are we debating the queen's retirement?. Queen Elizabeth is healthy, and does not need to step down. Typically, monarchs lead their country until their death.

column2: Having been born "Her Majesty's Loyal Subject (albeit Colonial-hence no longer one), I would like to see Charles become King before he reaches his mother' s age. Yes, I know William is much cooler. however whatever his shortcomings, Charles does not deserve the unprecedented humiliation of being passed over after waiting patiently and loyally for over 40 years. It's just not fair. I think Charles would be a reasonably good Monarch. His biggest problem is Camilla. I'm going to be brutally honest, and expect to get some flak as a result. Dianna was undoubtedly the Queen of Hearts, a star with a capital S, gorgeous, charismatic and blessed with incredible ability for empathy. However as Eliabeth has proven beyond doubt, one does not need to be a star to be a good monarch. Camilla is no Dianna, but she is, like it or not infinitely more suited to be Queen of the Realm then Dianna could ever hope to be.
column3: Charles should become King at a younger age than his mother's. Queen Elizabeth should step down and let Charles rule, who has been waiting patiently. The queen shouldn't be a star.

column2: It's time for the whole Windsor tribe and their cohorts to go. Royalty and a royal birth a major event in the Twenty-First Century is some kind of lunacy, certainly in any rational world. Why don't they just retire their royal titles and go back to Germany and spent their time breeding pedigreed (titled) cattle. On the cusp of my adulthood, I left the United Kingdom in 1945 because I had no intention of becoming the 'subject' of anyone!
column3: The Windsor family all needs to leave. Royalty and royal birth are outdated.

column2: I think if one had Prince Charles for a son, watched how he treated Diana, and learned of the Camilla as tampon conversation her stepping down would be unworth of her. QEII loves England and while she also loves her son why would she inflict him a people she cares for. He is a lightweight and if we may use his past behavior as a future predictor I'd say stay on the throne Granny. Then maybe Chuck will have the good sense (not likely) to step down and let William reign. OK so it's a fantasy. Shoot me.
column3: Why should Queen Elizabeth II should not have to inflict her country with her son. Queen Elizabeth's successor would not be able to handle the throne.

column2: As a five year old, I watched the young Queen take up royal duties, after the death of her beloved father. In 1953, her government was still struggling with the aftermath of the wholesale destruction and devastation of Britain and the loss of a whole generation of young men....Governing a country is no easy task. It ignores the facts to imply that all she knows is horses. Having lived through some of the more catastrophic changes on this planet, political as well as economic and personal; bringing a country back from the ruins, and having been forced to make some very tough decisions, which impact millions of people, not just a few paragraphs... Her Royal Highness, has probably, more wisdom than all journalists combined.
column3: Having lived through some of the more catastrophic changes on this planet, political as well as economic. Having made some very tough decisions, which impact millions of people...Her Royal Highness, has probably, more wisdom than all journalists combined.

column2: I can't think of a reason for the Queen to abdicate her solemn responsibilities. Should she become incapacitated the Privy Council has a mechanism for naming a regent. Charles should refuse the throne.. Nobody likes him. Of course, the British monarchy has evolved greatly over the past millennium or so, but historically, the monarch would have just as likely to have murdered or exiled the heir as to abdicate in his or her favor.
column3: The Queen does not have a reason to give up her responsibilities.

column2: 1) Why are we even debating something that is none of our business in the USA? 2) As a 50  woman, I'm thrilled to have the Queen out in the spotlight at her age, on her own terms. The monarchy has never been a popularity contest, and the modern monarchy is about issues of traditional, not about actual governance.
column3: Monarchy has never been a popularity contest, the modern monarchy is about issues of traditional, not about actual governance.

column2: Fletcher has got it exactly right. The best solution would be for both Elizabeth and Charles to abdicate and turn the Firm over to William and Kate. But since that will not happen, let's postpone until we're left with no choice the ascension of Charles--and even worse, Camilla. The thought of boring, stuffed-shirt Charles as king for decades is bad enough, but having Camilla shoved front and center would be a nightmare come true, even without the formal title of queen. Imagine-year after year of pictures of the two puttering in their garden with their little spades and shooting grouse at Balmoral. Oh, the horror, the horror-made even worse by knowing that Will and Kate are having to lie low. Of course, knowing the media's attention will gravitate anyway toward the young and vibrant, I feel a tinge of sympathy for the sad fate awaiting Charles and Camilla.
column3: Elizabeth and Charles should both step down and hand it over to William and Kate.

column2: Simply said the Queen is not going to step down. Upon ascending to the throne she made a vow to serve her people until her death. Words and the people who spoke them truly meant something at that time and still do to people of her generation. Queen Elizabeth came to the throne during a very difficult period for her people and the world and she helped lead her nation from those days to today always as a constant source of pride and inspiration. And it appears that the qualities that made her a loved and inspirational leader skipped a generation bypassing her son, Charles, and now appears rooted in her grandson, William. So I say save the questions about stepping down for Charles for the day after he ascends to the throne.
column3: The Queen is just not going to step down. It meant something to her generation to make a vow which she did to serve her people until her death. Queen Elizabeth II lead through difficult time periods and is a continued source of pride for the United Kingdom.

column2: It doesn't matter what we think, but we hope the Queen would feel free to step down if she were so inclined. We doubt she would feel that way. It does not seem in the Queen's nature, having placed duty above all for decade after decade, and thinking of the war years and the Blitz and how close she is to being Monarch for a record number of years. Ultimately, we would expect precedent to not be broken. How does one vacate their birthright ?
column3: It doesn't seem like Queen Elizabeth II has it in her nature to step down since she is so close to being a monarch for a record number of years. Precedent should not be broken. It is her birthright, you cannot walk away from that.

column2: Queen Elizabeth has demonstrated she is a monarch with uncommonly good common sense. My guess is people can depend on that. For a lifetime, she has put the good of her people and country above all else. Why would anyone expect less of her in the future?
column3: Queen Elizabeth exhibits good common sense. Queen Elizabeth II is still a capable and intelligent leader for the United Kingdom and should remain in power.

column2: 'You must vote," I often hear, "because the next president will pick who sits on the Supreme Court!" That such a statement should even be made tells us that something has gone seriously wrong with our democracy.' Correct -- there is something wrong. Among the wrongs is that many of the Constitution's provisions are general ones, thereby allowing multiple interpretations (e.g. "living Constitution", "originalism", "texturalism"; conservative, liberal). This leads to Supreme Court Justices commonly being picked politically on the basis of the category (or their perceived politics) to which they presumably belong. Justices are not "umpires", to use Robert's word, in the sense of baseball where rules are clear and broadly followed. Rather, they are "umpires" each of whom follows their own set of rules and who are picked to do so. It's worth considering that doing similarly in baseball would destroy the game.
column3: The Supreme Court can be influenced by partisan politics. Justices all follow their own set of rules, and in baseball, such a policy would destroy the game.

column2: A core example of Kramer's argument is the Bush v Gore decision. The court anointed the head of the executive branch by first finding for Gore, but then not allowing the recount to proceed due to an arbitrary time limit the Court set. Never mind the votes, we got this. And yet, without a co-equal judicial branch, there is no protection against either the tyranny of the majority or the tyranny of vested minorities. MInorities like the super-rich, massive corporation-people, 40 senators, White House plumbers, or a president gone mad. If we agree a Court decision is wrong, changing the law or amending the Constitution can fix that.
column3: The supreme court protects against tyranny. No matter the outcome of a court's decision, we always have the option to amend the Constitution or create and amend laws.

column2: Of course legislation is a theoretically better option than a Supreme Court ruling. But legislators have proven themselves not to be bound by the constitution's guarantees of minority rights. The question remains whether majority votes can or should overrule minority rights. And if inalienable rights exist, a Supreme Court may be necessary to protect mob rule from extinguishing freedom of existence.
column3: The supreme court helps minority rights. The Supreme Court provides a necessary check on mob rule.

column2: I think it was Churchill who said that democracy is the second worst form of government devised by man. What's the worst? Everything else. Our democracy suffers from some serious dysfunctions as the writer notes but I'd be hesitant to entrust nine (actually 5) unelected, usually pretty disconnected jurists in black robes the power to ... well, keep expanding their power. Whether you consider any particular ruling open-minded or open-hearted or reactionary or downright evil or righteous, history is strewn with the corpses of societies which fail to improve their democracy and, instead, turn to a select cabal to make critically important decisions. You wouldn't even have to keep money out of politics if we worked harder at educating our electorate so that they understand the extent to which the rich and powerful, and their toadies in government, manipulate our fears and our wants to avoid what THEY fear get what THEY want. To think that those who are already part of the mightiest of the power elite will ever do what's necessary to protect those who are not part of the power elite is delusional, if not worse.
column3: Churchill said democracy is bad. Justices are not elected with creates power issues.

column2: I could not agree with Mr. Somins's opinion more. Without the court how long would it have taken for black children to go to school with white children? How long would it have taken for women to gain control of their bodies? How long until the LGBT could even have consensual sex in their own home? Without the Supreme Court we'd still be living in the dark ages.
column3: Without the court it may have taken longer for school integration, female reproductive rights, and LGBT sexual rights. Without the Supreme Court, the US would be in the dark ages.

column2: I would propose that Justices serve a fixed term, perhaps 12 years. No President should be allowed to make appointments that determine Supreme Court decisions for decades after that President is out of office or dead and all his policies possibly repudiated.
column3: Presidents should not have the power to appoint such long-servicing justices that perpetuate his/her policies.

column2: It is a known fact that the court has largely been a regressive institution of the status quo, upholding the worst aspects of our society, monopolies, capitalism, racism, slavery, Jim Crow, with holding of women's suffrage, segregation, abortion rights, voting rights and on and on. The exceptions are noteworthy and talked about as if they are heresy rather than proper. For example is it simply amazing that Justice Roberts cannot find anything in the Constitution that supports equal rights to marriage for all people!
column3: The supreme court serves mainly to keep the status quo.

column2: Nine people....deciding for all US citizens....: not democracy in action. Nine people...are not reflective of all US Citizens; do not represent all US citizens. Nine people...could topple our democracy....by simply saying....we are the rule of law. and. they are not ...the rule of law...the people are.
column3: Nine judges making decisions for an entire country is too much power. The Supreme Court is only 9 people, and does not represent all US citizens. Nine people could disrupt our democracy.

column2: Sounds like I'm not the only one who picked up on the obvious here, that cash is replacing regular patronage. Seems a dumb trade from the restaurateur's point of view. The few extra bucks he picks up from one-time diners is going to be drowned by all the money he loses from regular patrons, who can't get the convenience and service they want. They'll go elsewhere, and he'll never see those one-time trend-surfers ever again. Buh-bye, Empellon. As for myself, I think all this is deeply silly. If I can't get a table at a restaurant at a decent time without having to wait on line, I go somewhere else. Lots of people can cook. It's just not that rare a skill, especially in a city like New York.
column3: Cash is replacing regular patronage. While extra profit can be made by paid reservations, more revenue will be lost due to diners who no longer eat there due to inconvenience associated with it. I will go somewhere else if I can't get a table at a restaurant without waiting.

column2: How about the quant idea of respect for PATRONS, not attitude and an attempt add hidden fees (a la movie ticket 'service fees')? And a suggested correction: "If anyone understands anything about the economics of restaurants they would know that [ticked off patrons going elsewhere] are the difference between profit and [going out of business]." "If anyone understands anything about the economics of restaurants they would know that a few tables are the difference between profit and deficit."
column3: There should be more focus on service and less on fees.

column2: True, this may be a non-issue relevant only to a small number of elite restaurants. But if the issue is the cost and difficulty imposed by no-shows (a real issue for restaurants of any level), it could be solved by a slightly different model: charge for a reservation, on either a flat or an auction basis, but then deduct that amount from the check. Essentially, require a deposit on the meal. Egalitarian concerns go away, since everyone pays the same for the reservation meal; and no-show problems are reduced, since the deposit increases incentive to keep your reservation, and restaurants keep the deposits for no-shows, to mitigate costs. Et Voila!
column3: Paid for reservations would save restaurants money that no-shows cause. Charge for the reservation and lower the bill by that amount. Everyone should pay the same for the same thing.

column2: The author seems to excluding the most likely scenario which is the restaurants will sell some reservations AND continue to hold others for celebrities, the politically and socially well connected, and regular customers etc. Clubs, sporting events, etc. comp people all the time for admittance that would otherwise cost money. All this means is that the rest of us will pay to compete against each other for the limited pool of publicly available reservations. Hard to see how that is democratizing.
column3: Restaurants will continue to keep reservations for higher class diners. Paying for restaurant reservations will force customers to compete against each other for a limited resource at an increased price.

column2: I think this is a problem for most big cities like New York, Chicago, LA., Toronto and Montreal...and like is so often in these big cities money works for the wealthy. It buys great medical care, great dental care and great dinners. I come from the land of Joe Beef and Au Pied du Cochon and I can see myself buying a table at the last minute but if I don't care when I eat there then I will simply wait for an OpenTable or call. But then again our restaurants tend to be on the smaller size more petite size. Sometimes it take being a Chef to get into some of them.
column3: I would be willing to buy a table if it was a last minute necessity but I will probably wait for an open table if time was not important.

column2: According to Professor Cowen, "Money is ultimately a more egalitarian force than privilege, as everyone's greenbacks are worth the same." The reality is quite the opposite: money is far more authoritative than egalitarian, as those with the most money will always win in this situation. Everyone's greenbacks may be worth the same, but those with more greenbacks will be worth more. Therefore, the current system may be a pain, but it is far more egalitarian in its fairness than a system that allows those with the most money to go to the head of the line.
column3: Those with the most money will always come out on top. Reservations for sell will affect those with less money. The current system is more fair than a system that would allow those with more money to go first.

column2: I strongly agree. As far as I'm concerned, the money changes hands in exchange for the meal and the experience. And not for the privilege of walking through the door. And another thing, this is New York! Terrific dining can be found everywhere without trying to get a seat at the latest trendy spot.
column3: Paying for the privilege of walking into the restaurant.

column2: Seems reasonable but with a reduction in fee through a means test. And how about a CCC for appropriate deferred maintenance projects. And then how about a bigger budget from the increased tax revenues we will have from anticipated amendments to the Code.
column3: This is reasonable as long as there is a fee reduction for the people who would need it.

column2: An absolutely terrible idea. Wallace Stegner called them our best idea in that they are completely democratic, everybody can go. They should charge minimal entrance fees and the federal government should pony up the rest as it is only a tiny amount of the budget. Preservation isn't free. Give me a break.
column3: Wallace Stegner said they were our best idea. Everybody should be able to go. Overcrowded national parks should not have restricted access, but should charge small feels for entrance with the federal government providing the other support to insure preservation.

column2: Wrong, very wrong. What is needed is not higher fees, resulting in elitist parks, but increases in budgets to properly care for our parks. Like everything else the Republican Congress continues to shortchange our parks in order to fund fighter plane costing a billion dollars, Imagine what Yosemite National Park could do if the cost of one fighter was given to it.
column3: Parks do not need higher fees but need increases in budgets to help care for parks. Congress dictates what happens in our parks.

column2: Absolutely not. Increasing fees is the opposite of what we should be doing. The parks need more funding from the Federal budget. Which means we need to get those GOP members out of the House & Senate, since they only support billionaire tax breaks, evidently. We need MORE PARKS. And they should all be FREE. They are our - the American people's - great patrimony.
column3: The government should decrease fees and increase government funding of parks. There should be more free parks.

column2: Restricting access is essential since the world population has exploded and the a significant fraction of the National Park visitors are foreigners. The last time I hiked to the top of Half Dome in 2006, it was an awful experience with people falling over each other like in a shopping mall. Same with the hike to Cloud's Rest. I'm glad they introduced the lottery system for Half Dome. If folks really care about spending time in these precious places, they should have to make the early reservations for the most crowded places. I know we live in an instant gratification society, but we got to draw the line somewhere. In any case, there are several excellent Parks where once can go find camping spots on a first-come basis.
column3: National parks should have restricted access because there is not enough space to accommodate everyone specifically foreigners. There were so many people it was as crowded as being in a shopping mall. People who care about spending time in these places should be willing to make early reservations for the crowded ones.

column2: I love national parks. Growing up in India, unspoiled green spaces were really foreign, and National Parks are America's best idea for generations to come. I visit Mt Ranier National Park several times as it is almost in my backyard. I am struck by the damage that visitors can inflict on the fragile wild flower meadows in their eagerness and zeal to enjoy the beauty. While better funding and visitor resources such as mass transportation could help, something we can all do is volunteer at a NP for a few days a year. This will go a long way in relieving the already stretched NP resources and the benefit to the volunteer citizen is priceless. Picking up trash, pulling weeks, cataloging wildflowers, roving the meadows helping visitors, etc. can help give back to our country's best idea and recharge our batteries all in one act!!
column3: In India parks are rare, National Parks are great for future generations. I have visited Mt Rainer several times. Access should not be restricted but solutions should be found to reduce impact such as volunteering or mass transit. More people need to volunteer at national parks.

column2: Bless Justice Ginsburg for speaking out! It is unprecedented and beyond brave. I am scared of Donald Trump and I am grateful for her action. It is not lost on me that all the people more powerful than me, and the ones I hoped would be the champions of people like me, are acting blind to what Donald Trump is doing or faking deaf to what he is saying. Thank you Justice Ginsburg for speaking up. Thank you Mr. Butler for your story.
column3: Too many people in powerful positions are turning a blind eye to Donald Trump and his actions.

column2: Have the Editors of the Times never seen Judgment at Nuremberg? There are times when everyone--even judges--must speak up or live with the consequences of their silence.
