Even if they aren't used the Al Qaeda and other terrorist organization operatives know they are at risk and it makes their operational plans that much more difficult to implement. If nothing else, in Cold War terms, they are an effective deterrent.
column3: Drone strikes are an effective tool to deter terrorist attacks because they are difficult for terrorists to avoid. Drones are a deterrent.

column2: The question as to whether or not drones are effective is 'mental masturbation"We bombed Dresden in WW2 and atomic bombed Hiroshima and Nagasaki.Of course hundred of thousands of innocent civilian died;but the bombings save American troops lives. If the Arab/Muslim world does not like civilian casualties ;they can clean up their act by joining the 21st century by granting freedom and equal rights and a modern education to their people Yes America England France Russia Japan and Germany were imperialist nations- "past tense" ,and forced a Zionist state in the aftermath of WW2 However the fledgling Zionist state survived the attacks and it is not going to give the land back anymore than Americans will give the land back they stole from the native Indians When Arabs grant equal RIGHTS ESPECIALLY TO WOMEN;I may argue against drones but until then dead neanderthals from drone attack are necessary to save soldiers lives
column3: The U.S. is guilty of other terrible acts of violence. The attacks save American troop's lives. Drones are needed to battle a repressive culture that results in oppressed women and dead soldiers.

column2: Robot pilots and drivers are here to stay. We need to protect ourselves from these devices - not develop them to be used against us some day... I'm sure we'll see a story soon about a driver-less car or pilot-less plane used to harm innocents in the homeland that created these high-tech marvels.
column3: Drones could be used to attack the US one day, we need to be protecting ourselves.

column2: Drones are a weapon of the weak willed. Relying on them gives those unfamiliar with successful counter-insurgency tactics and strategies a sense of security when in fact the opposite is happening. If you do not 'drain the swamp' or wipe out the entire support systems that enable the insurgent/terrorist to survive, they multiply like vermin. Therefore we see the spread of the scourge throughout Africa and the Middle East. Also, the mood of these countries, especially Egypt, is increasingly anti-American. Had we wiped out the terrorists with our ground troops in and around Afghanistan (including the uncontrolled areas in Pakistan), with the correct number of troops needed, we would not be facing this problem today of increasing terrorism in Afghanistan and our troops under attack from the very Afghan military and police. Our policy is corrupt, ineffective and weak -- and it is the policy of the present Administration -- dragging our nation ever more into an abyss.
column3: Using drone attacks does not allow for the necessary tactics needed for counter insurgency allowing insurgencies to thrive. The environment in countries like Egypt is more and more Anti-American. Our current policy is corrupt, ineffective, and weak.

column2: Until 9/11 our country was almost universally regarded as a one that offered justice for all. It is part of our slogan, it was a recruiting point for Americans-to-be. Then fear and revenge and politics showed what a thin veneer our principles were. The drone strikes, with their extra-judicial nature, confirm that, especially the double strikes killing rescuers. I dread the day when the first foreign drone strikes in the US - clearly a legitimate act of war in response to what is not even necessarily a legitimate grievance, requiring only a suspicion of guilt, given the manner in which we use them (after all, if we do it, it must be legal). Such an attack could, by the standards we use, be justly mounted by families of civilians wrongly killed by our drones. I fear the day that the first US drone strike occurs here (if they are so effective at saving soldiers' lives, they will also be effective saving police lives). I look forward to the day when the Americans behind these strikes, including two presidents, are on trial in the Hague.
column3: Drones kill rescuers. Drone attacks could be mounted by families of civilian fatalities.

column2: May I ask. What the U.S. response will be the day a terrorist utilizes a small drone to deliver a toxin from just south of the border over to a city like El Paso Texas. The terrorist could stand in Mexico a fly a small drone with anthrax or similar agent causing great death. Yes, if I've thought of it, don't think they haven't or won't. When drones go both ways, trouble.
column3: Drone attacks will encourage similar attacks on the US. Drones can cause trouble.

column2: There seem to be deficits of wisdom and historical awareness with the drone program as well as with other weapons programs. Any new weapon can be ultimately used against its developer: tanks against the British, SAMs against the US. Atomic and nuclear bombs have done the opposite of making the US more secure. What will our security be like when drones are very numerous, when they can be controlled by mobile phones, and when we have made so many enemies?
column3: Drones may prove to be more dangerous to their present users in the future.

column2: In the early 80's and well into the 1990's, I frequently traveled from Paris to New York and back. French friends often supplied me with a list of specific American items 'they absolutely needed' and friends in the U.S. would do the same - asking for their favorite French things...Now, with the internet and globalization in full swing, this practice has completely stopped. Today, most of us *living almost anywhere* can simply order most anything 'foreign' on the web...and, more than likely, can actually find that very same item in a store close to where we live... The streets of Paris and New York are looking very much the same today (very boring)...and we're definitely inching closer to the dreaded one world concept. Real glad I experienced life (and the street) before globalization!
column3: The same products can be found in almost any part of the world, so they lose their uniqueness.

column2: David Harvey, of _The Limits to Capital__ fame, discussed this in __The Conditions of Post-Modernity__. He called it "the serial monotony of late capitalism." It had more to do with the proliferation of big box stores and various other icons of hyper consumerism, than with the effect of the internet.
column3: Street style being made available in big box stores and other places the mass consumers shop throughout the world.

column2: with regards to that first comment about putting grafitti on t-shirts. ugh. graffiti belongs to the streets. it's not supposed to be marketed and profited upon. it's like those jerks who throw in extras on skateboards into cereal commercials. corporations trying to tap into subcultures which they know nothing about.
column3: Graffiti is for the streets not for profit.

column2: I was in Shanghai in April and I was really struck by how, in a hip, gentrifying district (yes, they're there too!) like Xintiandi, (young) people were totally dressed in the 'hipster uniform' you'd find in, say, Williamsburg or the LES. Must be the influence of photo blogs!
column3: In Shanghai, people dress similarly to young people in Williamsburg, NY, possibly due to photo blogs.

column2: I do agree that there is a downside to globalization when it comes to fashion. I like seeing people from different parts of the world in different styles. But I've noticed that all the young couchsurfers who visit me (from all over the world) that their clothing all reflects the same trends we see in NYC as well. It's sort of like how many countries are slowly but surely losing their cultural distinctions as well, as people from other countries move in, store chains take up residence, McDonalds, etc. (NYC of course would be the sole exception to this, as that's what NYC is supposed to be all about...one huge melting pot.) But when I go to Paris for e.g., I want to see French people. I want to hear French being spoken. When I go to Rome, I don't want to eat Chinese food. If I go to some small village in Ghana, I don't want to see men walking around in Abercrombie or Tommy Hilfiger T-shirts. I want to see people in their traditional clothing. But I guess there's no going back in this respect.
column3: People from different parts of the world are starting to reflect the same clothing trends as in NYC. Countries are beginning to lose their culteral distintions as chain stores pop up. One of the enjoyable things about travel is experiencing different styles and cultures. I like to see people in their traditional clothing.

column2: Employees should be free to move or sell their talents to the highest bidder. A time restricted none compete that's enforced through compensation by the former employer who wishes to restrict the employee seems like reasonable protection for both sides. The employee can't work for a year or two in their most lucrative field but the employer who wishes to restrict them pays them a portion of their lost wages for the period of enforcement. A free market for goods and services includes labor. A none compete does more than protect intellectual property it suppresses wages and creates a sense that the employee is property of the employer if they wish to stay in the field were they have the most experience and potential value.
column3: Noncompete agreements limit employee opportunities in the labor market. If it is a time restricted noncompete with provisions for compensation for employment restrictions. Businesses should require new employees to sign noncompete deals so that they don't waste their resources on training employees that are not long term. Free markets include labor. Non-compete agreements are unfair to employees and restrict their freedom to work.

column2: It is ironic that the vaunted "American Business Model" was essentially based on the theft of manufacturing designs and processes invented in Europe during the early years of the Industrial Revolution. We stole that stuff but now that the shoe is on the other foot, the corporate line is "Oh My Goodness, We Need Protection." History laughs at nonsense.
column3: At the beginning of the Industrial Revolution America stole inventions from Europe.

column2: How ironic in which for decades now companies have been moving their manufacturing to low wage off shore locations to boost their profits yet they feel it necessary to attempt to legally inhibit an employee from moving on to a a better opportunity with another organization? Quite laughable when you think China, in particular, has paid little attention to patent rights and intellectual property, let alone their ongoing attempted hacking of American corporate secrets, yet, these companies remain there. If a company insisted on me signing such a questionable agreement, it is time to look elsewhere. The hypocrisy here is beyond the pale.
column3: Businesses shouldn't be able to stop employees from getting better deal when the businesses themselves try to get what's best for their business.

column2: It is absolutely venal and unsupportable for companies to think they have the right to suppress employees' future career options. Don't want sales employees to 'poach' clients? Keep the employees happy through good treatment and keep clients happy through relationships that go beyond the single sales person. I'd be willing to bet that every manager now trying to institute non-competes got to their current position by competing effectively up the ladder. Isn't honest competition the American way? Why should labor markets be allowed to dodge what all other markets are required to promote- competition? Just do your corporate job right, that's how you earn corporate success, not by limiting the career paths of employees after they leave you. The only legitimate use of these limitations would be in the area of trade secrets.
column3: It is unsupportable for companies to suppress employees' future career options. Competition is needed in business. Businesses shouldn't be allowed to have new employees sign noncompete deals because competition is part of the American fabric and labor markets should have to compete. One earns corporate success by doing their job right, not by limiting the careers of former employees. Trade secrets are the only reason to legitimately use these limitations.

column2: Non-compete clauses are not about protecting proprietary information. That can be done with non-disclosure agreements. What they're really about is inhibiting the free market for labor. Employers use non-compete clauses to discourage employees from leaving. That saves the employer the cost and trouble of training a new worker, and it keeps wages down by restricting the employee's ability to leave if he or she does not get a raise. Non-compete clauses should be banned as a simple matter of fairness, and because competition for labor makes companies better.
column3: Proprietary information in not the reason for non-compete clauses. Businesses can protect themselves with non-disclosure agreements. This simply is a loophole around the free market for labor. Competition improves companies, and non-compete clauses are unfair.

column2: If they were protecting small business that would be fine but that is not how I have seen them. I currently work for a sub 100 person company and we tried to hire someone who had been let go from a competitor 9 months earlier. The competitors was a large global company based in MA. We received a threatening letter from them about the non-compete. Because they are big and have more in annual profit than we have in annual revenue, we knew we could not challenge them in court and so we had to rescind the offer to the currently unemployed individual. This is how I have seen non-competes used.
column3: Noncompete agreements can be used to sabotage or threaten smaller companies with less resources.

column2: There's something really annoying about phrases "integral legal mechanisms for small businesses", "protect their intellectual property and confidential information". This is spoken like an attorney who makes money off of "protection." Wen someone only comes from a position of "protect", they rarely advance. Truth be told, most small businesses have little "intellectual property" and little "confidential information", and most employees are no so predatory as to be waiting to "sell secrets." Sounds like a Cold Way spy scenario. On the other hand, this is how some attorneys make their living an they are not going to bite the hand that feeds them. So short-sighted, the damage to employees while protecting the throne.
column3: Both "integral legal mechanisms for small businesses", "protect their intellectual property and confidential information" are irritating. Most small businesses have little confidential information and most employees are not looking to sell secrets. This policy is short sighted and could harm employees.

column2: Nonsense. I have watched people leave MA in droves for overseas or CA to be free to work when non competes were threatened. Massachusetts loses far more (including its reputation for innovation) when these are invoked. NDAs work while enforcing non competes drives new business elsewhere. Most non competes do not protect "trade secrets" (very widely interpreted) but are both punitive and designed to abuse workers earnings. Often it is the best and the brightest who leave regardless. And let's throw out that "underpaid for equal work women" as a class are doubly damaged.
column3: Business can be lost because of non compete deals. They are not in place to protect traditional business practice but more to enslave workers.

column2: One thing about these 'noncompete agreements' (a nice term for 'legalised blackmail') is that they actually manage to put this country behind Russia - Czarist Russia, at that. After all, Alexander II did end serfdom back in 1861. With these ridiculous conditions still enforceable, we've yet to do so. Doesn't this make you proud to be an American?
column3: These agreements put this country behind Czarist Russia in regards to our work force.

column2: First of all, the Palestinians live under occupation because Jordan, the original occupier left the territory to Israel after the 1967 war. What about the 20 years of Jordanian occupation from 1947-1967? Israel took over the care of the refugees of the 1948 War of Independence from Jordan. Remember this, Jordan, Egypt, Syria and Lebanon attacked Israel in 1948. Their collective goal was to wipe out the nascent Jewish State and murder all the Jews living there. But, they lost and Israel grew by a few kilometers. Jordan ended up on the West bank, occupying East Jerusalem, while Egypt occupied the Gaza Strip. For 20 years, the Jordanian and Egyptian occupiers held the West Bank and Gaza refugees in camps, in poverty and riled up. It is the mindset of these Arab leaders who do not want to have a Jewish State side by side with Arab Muslims who have caused the misery of the Arab refugees for the past 66 years.
column3: Jordan left the territory to Israel after the 1967 war this is why Palestine people are under occupation. Jorday, Egypt, Syria and Lebanon attacked Israel in 1948. Hamas-Fatah unity can't lead to Mideast peace because the Jordanian and Egyptian occupiers detained West Bank and Gaza refugees for two decades. Arab leaders have no interest in sitting beside a Jewish State that is responsible for decades of Arab refugees.

column2: And what happens if this wondrous one state is not the earthly democratic paradise that the blogger and some posters promise, that 60 years of bitter strife over land, religion, history etc insures that the Arab side, when in the majority, decides to exact revenge for all past wrongs real and imagined? The Jews would be lucky to get out alive, as witness the murderous strife in Egypt between Muslim factions. I suppose if that happens the blogger will write another article saying "gosh, I really feel bad about this, but it seemed a good idea at the time". As much as I have posted here about the evil of the settlements and the despicable "land before peace" attitude of the Likud, I would say that the Israelis would have to have a death wish, certainly for their state and likely also for themselves, to ever accede to this exercise in sheer Pollyannaish propaganda. Two states is the way to go, and to effect this outcome, the US government has to stop treating Likud with kid gloves.
column3: It is likely that Jewish people would be slaughtered, proof of that is what is happening between Egyptians and Muslims. It would be unwise for the Israelis to accede to this propaganda.

column2: Israelis would become the minority in a single state, subject to whatever retributions desired by the majority Palestinians. Palestinians would remain second class citizens by virtue of the Israelis having developed both a wealthy economy and having developed and controlled both the modern infrastructure, businesses, and public institutions. The Palestinians would have to be given much of what is in Israeli hands and help them to learn how to manage it and money to support the transition from taxes upon the more well to do (Israelis) to achieve equality in a single state. That's a lot of potential pain and loss for Israelis in a single state.
column3: It cannot happen until Israeli's learn how to better manage their money and put taxation equality into place. A single state would cause much pain and loss for Israelis.

column2: Perhaps when the Arabs are ready to recognize their own culpability for their situation and stop blaming Israel, the US and Santa Claus for all their problems we might get a resolution to the conflict. When the land was divided between Arabs and Jews in 1948 it was an Arab army which swept into Israel, not an Israeli army which swept into the neighboring Arab countries. Arab Jews were expelled from Arab countries and Palestinians were expelled from Israel. For too long the Arabs have played an all or nothing game. The only peace they want is one with no Jewish State. Calling the entire area Palestine under Arab rule or using the euphemism of a non-denominational democratic Israel (in the Arab world of Islamic Republics?) the goal is the same: The eradication of the Jewish State. Palestinian leadership is so weak and so vulnerable to violent overthrow that they cannot make the tough choices of trading concessions with Israel. Only when there is strong leadership, one voice for the Palestinians, and widespread Palestinian support for trading concessions with Israel can there be peace.
column3: The leadership in Palestine is too weak to make the choices needed for trading concession with Israel. One voice for the Palestinians is necessary for concessions to be made with Israel.

column2: Arab League has forbidden Abbas to recognize the Jewish state. Arabs showed clearly that their goal is not a peace, but a destruction of Israel. About what can Israel speak with Arabo-fascists? About a destruction of Israel? Pandering to the Arab aggressors and sacrificing the tiny Israel contradicts the moral values of the West.
column3: Abbas has been forbidden by the Arab League to recognize the Jewish state. Arabs main goal is to destroy Israel. Israel cannot speak with Arabo-fascists. We should not pander to the Arab aggressors.

column2: The post election standoff was cemented in place by a US/Israeli sponsored coup prepared by Fatah's leader-in-prospect Dahlan. He so bungled that he left himself out of serious contention for leadership of Fatah. That was his power play to replace Abbas as the useful tool of Israel, and he both failed and exposed himself for the Quisling that he is. Still, the Palestinians never recovered from the coup attempt pushed by the US and Israel. The reaction to this unity attempt highlights the continuing use by them of the division of the Palestinians, the gift of the Quisling that keeps on giving.
column3: Unity will not work because Fatah is US/Israeli backed. Palestine has yet to recover from the coup attempt advocated by the US and Israel. The unity attempts shoe that Hamas and Fatah cannot work together.

column2: Almost exactly 50 years ago today we had the March on Washington. A great moment in non-violence. Did we learn nothing? We should bomb the people who are being gassed? IF there was a way to extract Assad and have him stand trail for war crimes I would be all for it. To pour more violence into the region does not make sense to me. That said I do not know what the answer is.
column3: It would be unnecessary violence. There shouldn't be more violence in the region.

column2: The warring factions in Syria are, it can be safely assumed, enemies of the United States. It escapes me, therefore, how the intervention of the United States' armed forces on one side or the other is in the best interest of the American people. When will they ever learn? The U.S. could do worse than simply watching and learning from Russia's and China's foreign policy decisions.
column3: The US should not attack Stria because they are all US enemies.

column2: Mr. Walt presents not an argument against defending the norm prohibiting the use of chemical weapons, but an argument against the norm itself (". . .Using nerve agents like sarin is illegal under international law, but they are not true ' weapons of mass destruction.' Because they are hard to use in most battlefield situations, chemical weapons are usually less lethal than non-taboo weapons like high explosive. ..."). That may be an argument worth having (I'd vehemently disagree) but it's clearly not a position shared by this government. And a norm that can be violated without consequence is no norm at all. More, beyond mere moral issues implicated in chemical weapons bans, the US - as the most powerful conventional military on the planet - has a powerful interest in upholding norms against the use of non-conventional weapons.
column3: The US should be interested in using their powers to keep non-conventional weapons use to a minimum.

column2: I agree with some of this writer's assessment but where is the moral imperative here? Do we see people on TV including small children who have been gasses and ignore that? Have we forgot the lessons of the Holacaust of WW 2? I would hope not at this stage in world history. That is why this must not be a US decision but a world decision done in concert with thhe countries of the Middle East and not another unwanted invasion by a foreign power.
column3: People have forgotten the lessons from the WW2 Holocaust.

column2: We cannot sit idly by and accept the Syrian government' actions, if there is clear evidence of the alleged atrocities. Sure, we were misled into Iraq and the non-existent WMD. We have to forget THAT mind-set. How clear and solid is the evidence of chemical weapons used against the Syrian people by the Assad regime? I don't buy the Russian claims. But we have to be very certain before we take any unilateral steps this time in that region. IF the allegations are true, no civilized country can watch it without doing something. We should also ask our 'friends' in the region.
column3: The US can't just sit by as the Syrian government acts. No civilized country should watch without doing something, if allegations are true.

column2: The west is already engaged in the conflict. Has been since its inception, because it was one of the causes of it. Ignorance of NYT readers is astounding; why don't you read other media for a change, and get out of the information bubble that is shaped by the state department. This foreign policy has been around for the last 2 decades and getting rid of Assad is one of critical components. Crushing of Syria will cut the supply chain to Hezbollah and secure peace for israel. There are other interests as well. Saudis would like to pipe gas to Europe and undermine the monopoly of Russian Gazprom. Europeans would like that too. Foreign policy had an article recently that when Saddam was gassing Iranians in the 80's, he was getting logistical support from USA.
column3: The west is already involved. Without Syria providing supplies to Hezbollah Israel would be at peace. USA support for Saddam gassing Iranians in the 80"s set a precedent which now supports US attack on Syria.

column2: The biggest mistake Obama made was his red line comment. Now US credibility is on the line and Iran is watching us. No good will come out of bombing Syria, but much worse may come out for not bombing Syria. Intervening in Syria must have a real purpose. The Administration hasn't given a purpose other than punishing Assad for using chemical weapons. That will not stop Assad. In fact it may even embolden him to use it indiscriminately. Then what? Topple Assad? Who will control Syria afterwards? Obama should have read Lincoln - Better to remain silent and be thought a fool than to speak out and remove all doubt.
column3: The credibility of the US is at stake as Iran watches us. While bombing Syria isn't a great idea, worse things may come if the US doesn't bomb them. There has to be a reason to attack Syria.

column2: Any intervention is a slippery slope to full involvement which is why we should stay as far away from Syria as possible no matter what they do. Lookt at Libya -- we started out with R2P just to save those Jihadist in Benghazi from Qaddafi. Well it quickly morpher into regime change in violation of the UN SC resolution. So we acted outside the law. We didn't care we are the US - we are not bound by any LAW not even one passed in Congress. And regime change in Libya led to the muder of a US Ambassador -- does anyone think that what is about to happen will end any differently. The President will lie to us as we were lied to about NSA and lied to about US intentions in Libya. In another month we will be bleeding and dying in Syria to remove Assad and install Al Nusra in power -- the so called FSA will either defect to Al Nusra or be buthchered by them. This is a disaster in the making for the US.
column3: In order to avoid becoming fully involved in their war, we should stay completely out of everything going on in Syria. Regime change in Libya led to the murder of a US Ambassador, and attacking Syria could have similar results. It would be a disaster.

column2: Not our fight. What is the objective? How would we know when we have achieved that objective? Who really wins? Al-Qa'eda again, would be my guess. The British, the French, and Turkey all have the ability to project military power in the Eastern Mediterranean. Let them go after Syria, and let them bear the consequences. To be fair, I only worked in U.S. embassies in the Middle East for 10 years, and have only studied the Arabic language, culture, and politics for 27 years, so I might not know what I'm talking about.
column3: Not our fight. The US attacking Syria would only create more problems no matter which faction wins, probably Al-Qa'eda. The British, French, and Turkish should project military power on Syria, and bear the consequences.

column2: One Iraq debacle in our nation's history, added to our failure in Vietnam, should convince any sane American there is no gain to our waging war in Syria. If we can't sort out the criminally insane from the violently stupid, it's not our battle.
column3: Syria has not tried U.S so there is no war but if so we are ready. The US should stay out of Syria because we don't know who the good guys are.

column2: To deter the future use of chemical weapons should be the stated and sole goal of any military strike; it is consistent with the "red line" statement of a year ago. No other goal should be put forth. The military strike should be significant, short of duration, and then concluded. Concluded. Concluded. Talk about a future Syria "that is peaceful, non-sectarian, democratic, legitimate, tolerant..." should be absolutely avoided. We're talking about the Middle East here, not Scandinavia.
column3: The US should deter the future use of chemical weapons.

column2: This is a terrible idea. Attacking Syria will only make things worse. Obama knows that. Chuch Hagel really knows that, Kerry should know that. Yet our supposedly wise leaders are counseling the use of force. Remember WMDs in Irag? We don't know for sure whether chemical weapons have been used and if they were we don't know who used them. Not to mention the apparently minor point that attacking a country except in self-defense is illegal under international law.
column3: It's a bad idea. An attack on Syria would worsen things. It's unsure whether chemical weapons have been used, and if so, who used them. It is illegal to attack a country except in self-defense.

column2: Russian and Chinese opposition in the UN notwithstanding, the US (not alone) with our allies will have to do something IF there is enough solid evidence of Syrian government using chemical weapons against its own people. I know we are tired of wars in that region, but the other shoe seems to have dropped in Syria, and we can organize our allies to take appropriate actions within the UN, but not unilaterally. Syrians are and have been difficult, but IF they took the steps they are alleged to have taken against their own people, no civilized country can afford to ignore that.
column3: The US (not alone) with our allies will have to do something IF there's enough solid evidence of Syrian government using chemical weapons against its own people. Syria has hurt its own people and it should be addressed.

column2: I like the idea of blowing up Alawite Thugs and running over Assad with a bus as much as the next contractor, but after we boot the Alawite Crips and Assad is beheaded, then we have to prevent the Islamist fascist Bloods from getting the chems, Right? We will be back in the same 4 or 5 sided Gang War we encountered in Afghanistan and Iraq. We can't kill our way out. O was dumb to draw a redline, but we have nothing to win in this one. We are Americans. We don't know who is who or What is What. The only redline should be, point any of those chems in our direction and we'll take you All Out. That's the way we roll. Iran? Same thing. If I want to send a message to a bully I punch him in the nose. Not his sister.
column3: The US should not attack Syria as it is a mult-sided war that cannot be ended with killing. Americans should mind their own business.

column2: Kerry's threat to punish a country that violates the US Government's sense of morality and obscenity -- in the absence of any threat to the US -- will tear US society apart. His advocacy of war to overturn the government of that disfavored country places him in something close to the posture of a colonial ruler. If the standards applied to Syria today had been applied to Iraq in the 1970's, we would have intervened in Syria back then. The USA seems to be taking a step back in time with Kerry at State.
column3: Punishing a country that violates the US Government's sense of morality without any threat to the US will harm society. The president's actions to overturn other countries governments is akin to colonialism. The United States should not attack Syria because the same conditions existed in the past, and we did not attack then.

column2: The costs of inaction outweigh the significant risks of military intervention. And exactly what are these "costs of inaction". I submit that we and the Syrians will be better off if we opt for "inaction". So far our military interventions in the Middle East have had bad outcomes for ourselves and the countries we were trying to help.
column3: Not acting would be more dangerous than intervening. I believe doing nothing in Syria is the best option for the US and Syria. Our military interventions in the Middle East always have bad outcomes for us.

column2: The key question here is not "are polygamists deviant?" The key question is whether "child abuse and exploitation of women are not inherent in polygamy," as the author states. Professor Banks, can you site a single existing or historical example of a society that allowed polygamy but wasn't patriarchal or didn't exploit women? You can't, because there aren't any such examples. Every shred of evidence, present and past, shows that child abuse and exploitation of women ARE inherent in polygamy.
column3: Exploitation of women and child abuse are not part of polygamy. Evident shows that polygamy comes with child abuse and exploitation.

column2: Marriage as it pertains to government's involvement is an issue of tax law, entitlement benefits and property rights (especially in the case of divorce), government should not be defining morality. Leave morality to the churches, etc. Either government legally protects consenting adults to enter into any type of marriage and provides equal benefits in such unions, or the government completely removes itself from all marriages.
column3: Marriage as it pertains to government's involvement should not be defining morality. The government should acknowledge all marriages, or stay out of them.

column2: My first class came back to see if I would return--such was the nature of my terror and inexperience. It didn't take long to pick up the basics, but 42 years later I'm so much better and more consistent. I know how to be more generous and more demanding at the same time, and I know how to catch the fragile students before they tune out or disappear. And the need to innovate doesn't come from the teaching style du jour: it comes from a continuous involvement and pleasure in getting better at what you do.Experience counts.
column3: Teachers become better and more consistent with more experience. Teachers need to have experience because as an experienced teacher I know how to catch the struggling students before they tune out or disappear. Excellence and innovation in teaching comes from continuous years spent and experience.

column2: I am in my 9th year teaching, and yes, I feel sorry for the students I had my first year. I am a good teacher today, and it did take about 5 years to reach that point. I have never worked in a charter school, but I did once interview at one (and decline the job offer), and I know several teachers who currently work at charters. Charter schools do not offer competitive salaries. In addition, charter school teachers have more duties and longer hours in school, so, after factoring in daily lesson planning on top of their extended hours, they work much longer, in poorer conditions (the shiny buildings don't mean good work conditions) with much lower salaries. No education professional actually believes that charter schools are hiring superior teachers.
column3: It took me 5 years to become a good teacher.

column2: I was a public school teacher for 25 years. The large majority of teachers I observed were hacks on sinecure waiting for their pensions, resenting the students, the parents, the administration and the education professors (the last two mostly justly). There were exceptions, but not many. Enthusiasm is lost by the sixth or seventh year. One enthusiastic, dedicated young teacher is worth more to a child than many of these plodders, whose influence actually may be more negative than positive.
column3: Experienced teachers lose their zest by the 6th or 7th year. Enthusiasm by young teachers can actually be worth more than teachers who have a negative attitude.

column2: Teaching is a profession - we wouldn't want a doctor who wasn't educated in the profession, nor a plumber who was not trained in their profession, nor have a school constructed by someone not trained in engineering. We want a trained teacher conducting classes; outsiders coming in to supplement a lesson are fine, but not the same as a teaching professional.
column3: As with any other profession, teachers should have some sort of classroom experience before they begin professionally teaching. Teachers with experience are not replaceable.

column2: I agree with Princeton's move as a useful first (but small) step in addressing America's woeful inabilities to communicate around the world. But Betty is absolutely correct--the right and best place to teach foreign languages is as early as possible and over many years, while the mind is most plastic and language can be taught in the same manner we learn English--naturally, and without the mind numbing exercises that teach the infrastructure of a language--not how to actually use it.
column3: I believe Mandatory language classes are a good beginning to increase America's communication ability.

column2: A realistic assessment of what it takes to learn a foreign language (it takes a lifetime). All the advertising about learning a language in 3 months are nonsense. Not even the best government schools training someone 8 hours a day, 5 days a week take less than six months of total submersion to offer anything close to proficiency. And then if you don't use it, it fades quickly.
column3: It takes a lifetime to truly learn a foreign language.

column2: I'm old enough that I had to take 2 semesters of foreign language to graduate college. I don't remember most of it and I can't say it was a good use of my classroom time. A smattering of college language isn't much different than the high school foreign language studies required for college admission. For most people, a couple of semesters isn't enough for any fluency and ends up being largely wasted.
column3: It was a waste of my time and I don't remember most of the language. College level foreign language classes are similar to high school level classes and shouldn't be manditory. Foreign language classes ought not be mandatory because taking a couple semester doesn't add up to fluency and is a waste of time.

column2: As an academic for more than 50 years, I say, especially around grading time, that every university should require two things: minimal competence in a (new) foreign language, and performance on a musical instrument. You can cheat or get around the requirements for all kinds of other academic subjects, but you either speak French in public, or you can't. You either play the Bach Invention, or you can't. Simple. You can't cram it, you can't cheat. Besides the obvious benefits of the learning processes in both of these activities, the study of each is a valuable exercise in integrity. Yes, I'm serious.
column3: They can not be cheated through like most other classes. Foreign languages are a skill that can't be cheated and must be learned and the study of them itself is a valuable experience.

column2: rYes! And in grammar school and every year of any education. We spoke Latin in high school in public school. It was mandatory. I studied French in high school and in college and added german in college. Sure I cannot do well with my german friends, but at least I can muddle through. We need to be able to speak multiple languages and not expect everyone else to speak english. I ignored my father when I was in grammar school and he told me to learn spanish as it would be the universal language. He was right.
column3: We should be able to speak other languages rather than expect everyone else to speak english.

column2: Of course students should be challenged to learn another language at college. Proficiency in a second (or third) language is beside the point. The actual learning process enforces a discipline that incorporates several facets of adult education - logical thinking, memorization, multimedia exposure (video, audio, in-person interaction, etc). Learning a language creates good study and education habits.
column3: Foreign language classes ought to be mandatory in college since proficiency can be valuable. The process of learning a language helps learn discipline as well as logical thinking, memorization and exposure to multimedia. Foreign languages teach good study habits.

column2: Most Americans have the same attitude about languages other than their own, as they have about those people who might speak them--fear [and eventually hate]...Although I was educated in what seems like the last ice age, instruction in foreign language began in earnest in middle school and graduating with a bachelor's degree required competency in both a classical (Latin, Greek, Hebrew) and a modern language (French, Spanish, or Italian). With all the teaching aids at our fingertips now, the old curriculum should be revived. [And don't ask high schoolers what they think-just tell them what they should do.]
column3: Americans fear and hate people who speak different languages. While in my education we were grounded in classic and modern languages since middle school allowing me more understanding. We should still be able to provide language classes with modern teaching aids.

column2: If more learn to code, then the United States will maintain it's leading position on the world stage, resulting in English continuing to be the only language worth knowing. Let other people learn English, so they can serve us food and give us directions when we visit them, and so they can order food and ask for directions when they visit us, and do business with us. But if we want to continue to lead, we should learn to code. Other languages? Not so much. It's a waste of time. Even the Spanish speaking help knows enough English to get by.
column3: People in the U.S. should learn to code in order to ensure the dominance of the English language. Other people should learn English. Foreign language classes are not helpful.

column2: Both of my college-graduate children are fluent in foreign languages, learned in high school and college, fine-tuned in trips overseas: my son in German, my daughter in Spanish. Unquestionably, their foreign-language skills have been rewarded in the U.S. job market and in academia at the highest levels. We are in a new global marketplace, and America needs bilingual education now more than ever. Sorry, I must vehemently disagree with several of these very smart young writers.
column3: Foreign language skills are rewarded in the job market. America needs bilingual education to compete in today's global marketplace.

column2: I took my required 2 semesters of Spanish in college. I can't say I remember any of it. 2 semesters of a foreign language is required by many colleges. I'm not sure how this proposal is different. I don't think you can demand fluency in a foreign language as a graduation requirement.
column3: I can't remember any foreign language instruction I received. Fluency can not be expected as a graduation requirement.

column2: I think the time to learn a language is early, in elementary school. That's when being exposed to other ways of speaking, doing things, other cultures, can make such an impact. In college it's just a burden, and a very expensive burden with the cost of tuition.
column3: Elementary school is the optimal time to learn other languages and cultures. They are an expensive bit of extra work with no true purpose.

column2: OF COURSE ! Speaking a foreign language is absolutely wonderful ! I feel it is because of the so-called powerful place the USA occupies in the world that it has no interest in the ability to speak another language than its own. The USA would benefit from a little more humility and real understanding of the many other cultures that exist on our Earth. It enables one to assimilate a culture in a way unequaled to any other.
column3: Learning a language is fun. American students would benefit from learning foreign languages, by being exposed to other cultures. Learning a language allows you to assimilate a culture in a way not possible by other methods.

column2: Foreign languages have been one of the greatest gifts that a person can receive; for me French in middle and high school (still not fluent), and German beginning when I was about 27, (fluent/bilingual). I thought it was crazy when universities dropped the language requirements.
column3: Study of language is a gift for the person that does it.

column2: The research on this issue is clear, which the Yale provost might read ---picking up a second language in college is exceedingly difficult, if not impossible, for adult learners ---that is not to say that there are students who do have a talent for second language acquisition, but most of us do not. Now having said that, the odds of learning a second language increase dramatically at the elementary level. We have a habit, when discussing educational matters, of aiming curricular reforms at high school and colleges, when, we should be focused on the age groups where learning a second language is optimum---so, instead of Yale, we should be looking at enlarging dual language programs at the K - 8 system.
column3: It is hard for an adult to learn a second language. The odds of learning a second language are higher at the elementary level. We should be teaching language in elementary school instead of college and high school.

column2: It was a requirement in my high school in Italy. I took English and French. In later studies of engineering at a university in the USA, I had the 'audacity' for my electives to take modern English literature courses:)! It was a great opening not only for widening my intellectual horizon, but as well gaining deeper, if still not full, understanding of American society and behaviour. Saluti
column3: Foreign languages were required in my high school in Italy. Foreign language classes ought to be mandatory because for myself it was a way to broaden my intellectual interests and gain a fuller understanding of American culture.

column2: The NYT recently ran an article about how people lose the ability to make decisions as it gets later in the afternoon. The example given was that parole boards cease giving parole to prisoners whose cases come up in the afternoon, not because these inmated had worse cases but because , by afternoon, the human brain needs a break and decides not to decide. How does this new research fit into longer school days? Will late afternoon classes be useless? I know at work most people I know, including myself, run out of steam at about 3 p.m. If adults can't keep up to par all day, how are children expected to make decisions all day?
column3: The school day should be shorter, as evidence shows that people do not function as well late in the day. The brain needs a break. Adults tend to begin to wear down around 3 in the afternoon, it is logical to believe that children would do the same.

column2: People need sleep. Starting so early so there is enough daylight for a sports programs? That's why today so many of our graduates (?) are only good for sports programs... I am now 63, with 3 degrees from an ivy league school, and having run my own business for over 30 years and having had 100s of employees. I know--with moral certainty--that so many people are underperformers (including me) when they don't get enough sleep. Be it in school or at work... people need to be well rested with at least 8 hours of sleep to perform optimally. Public schools shouldn't begin before 9:00 am. Period. Then we'll have better performing students and workers. Guaranteed. And don't tell
column3: I am sure the additional hours would affect sleep patterns causing people to underperform. Everyone needs plenty of rest, school should not interfere with that.

column2: Hear, hear. School is for learning, not for creating a schedule that will allow children to have more time for after-school sports practice (how many kids actually become successful athletes anyway?). Not to mention, a longer school day should mean less homework, resulting in a more rejuvenating downtime or creative period (by choice!) for these already-overscheduled kids. Is anyone listening out there?
column3: The school day is long enough for academics; no extra time is needed for sports. A longer day would mean less homework.

column2: As a public school teacher, it is not my job to raise children. They have parents for that. Dumping more and more responsibilities into the schools' laps only enables the parents who are choosing to abdicate those responsibilities. While I recognize that there are many factors that make it challenging for some parents to fully meet their children's needs (physical, emotional, educational, economic, etc.), passing those off onto schools, as Canada advocates, is not the answer. I don't think we'll see any real change in this country until we address issues like poverty and working conditions (including the long hours that force parents to choose between seeing their children and feeding them). Incidentally, I am completely baffled and frustrated by Canada, whose success comes largely from the fact that his programs have taken huge steps to improve the living conditions of his students and their families--and then he turns around and credits that success to non-unionized teachers and extended school days. Really??
column3: It is not the job of a public school teacher to raise children - that is the parents' job. Putting more responsibilities on the schools enables parents to abdicate those responsibilities. There are many other issues such as poverty and working conditions that should be addressed over longer school days.

column2: Aron (#36) is right. Not every part of the educational system here in the U.S. is broken. Only those parts that serve the poor are broken. Mr. Canada's suggestion might well be necessary for the schools he oversees. But most schools don't have the same problems, and for them a longer school day seems unnecessary. To bridge the achievement gap, we need to bring the bottom up. The top is for the most part where it ought to be.
column3: Many things in the educational system in the US functions well. Many schools do not have problems requiring a longer day. The bottom end of students need to be brought to the top.

column2: Both of my elementary age children are bored to tears at school everyday, from 8:30-3:00. In an effort to make everybody a winner, our schools have dumbed down the standards so much that our curriculum is now 2 grade levels below 20 years ago. Students have always had varying abilities, you cannot change nature. As it is school is just a place for my kids to socialize, as they learn practically next to nothing during Reading, Math, Social Studies. I wish school hours could be shortened to include only Recess, Library, Music, PE and Art so that I could have more time to teach my kids the real important stuff at home.
column3: My children's schooldays are too long to keep their attention. Schools should improve their curriculum, not increase time in school. Students have various levels of natural ability.

column2: Don't make the school day longer. Shorten the working hours for parents -- especially where both parents have jobs -- and let the parents spend more time with their children. The parental influence on children is the most important in their development and in their education. Besides, children need time to have fun -- just to be kids.
column3: Children need down time to have fun and be young.

column2: Exactly. There's no doubt that AI will continue to evolve, and the exciting possibility is that a new kind of intelligence that humans don't do well, or don't do at all, will be discovered. But simply trying to mimic human intelligence seems like a waste of time, like reinventing the wheel. Until computers decide unbidden to start writing lyrics like The Sound Of Silence and weep at the music, I'm not too concerned about AI replicating what we do.
column3: AI is evolving and perhaps it will evolve beyond what we as humans can do. I don't think AI can write music and feel the emotion the music can evoke so I am not worried about them replicated what we do.

column2: This is not AI. It is a program that plays a game and that is all it does. It can not interact on any other level. It has to way to view, evaluate, determine best or worse probable outcome or even to discover whether or not what it is presented with is a problem needing solution. We are a long long way from true AI. All that is possible at present is to design a program which can learn the answers we provide for it and that is not wisdom not intelligence. It is a filing system.
column3: Artificial Intelligence can play a game and not otherwise interact. AI has the ability to determine probable outcomes, and decide if what is provided is a problem it has to solve.

column2: Oh please, they're inducting KISS! This is not greatness, not deserving of being inducted. The RRHFA inducts too many people because it is an annual event and they need the buzz to get people to visit and keep museum viable. If they were really serious about the contributions to the genre they should only induct every 5 years. They've tossed in too many people on the periphery and diluted the value of the induction.
column3: The Rock Hall of Fame has inducted KISS I don't think they deserve it, so it's selctions don't matter. The Rock Hall of Fame does not matter, because they are not exclusive enough in selecting people to celebrate. Hall of Fame induction is not as valuable now that many people on the periphery have been induced.

column2: Yes! Because just like all sports, it is entertainment! The Hall's existence, and determination of honorees, gives people more things to discuss and argue about, to give them some relaxation, from their workaday lives! Only gripe I have right now, which has me all preplexed, is if you are going to call it, The Rock n' Roll Hall of Fame, how can you have Rappers, whose music, if you want to call it that, is just, Talk, with an edge?! Oh, and wasn't that PBS Great Performances Special, on the Dave Clark Five, wonderful?! Now, that's enduring Rock n' Roll, which despite a few mean spirited cynics, is what made many of us, Glad All Over, then, as it still does, today!!!
column3: Entertainment matters. The Rock Hall of fame gives people distraction from everyday life.

column2: Brian Epstein and Linda Rondstadt are getting inductedin 2014. Who's in charge Rip VanWinckle ? Miss Rondstadt could have been inducted in the in the 70's. She was on the cover of Time magazine in 1977 and has been a Superstar ever since. Brian Epstein ?? Oh yeah I think he managed a rock Band.
column3: Linda Rondstadt is getting inducted in 2014, but she has been a superstar for decades.

column2: I once spent several weeks exploring Rock and Roll Hall of Fame while recovering from an injury. Pouring through the vast archives, listening at every station I was permanently enriched, inspired and even healed. The Rock hall is a ttreasure house! I am SO grateful to the Rock Hall for all they do to tell the story and preserve the sounds. And, I'll be even more grateful when they induct Gram Parsons.
column3: Listening and exploring the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame helped me heal and I gained knowledge. The Rock Hall of Fame is a house of treasures. to tell the story and preserve the sounds.

column2: Those already born here would, practically, have to be grandfathered if there were any changes. Reviewing the citizenship of people already born here would result in endless paperwork and heavy expenses, and would force us to make difficult moral decisions, some of which we would undoubtedly get wrong. I don't think that a constitutional amendment is actually necessary to clarify that the meaning of the Constitution is not something that it clearly was not intended to be, though. Defining the meaning of "under the jurisdiction of the United States" to exclude those who entered the country illegally or are here on short term travel visas should only require a law saying as much. The courts could strike it down, I suppose, but it's far from clear that they should, and their decision would have to explain some interesting contradictions between their position and contradictory aspects of past immigration laws. I think that the current problem is due to a lack of clarity from Congress, not due to actual demands of the Constitution.
column3: It would be too challenging to review citzenship of people born in the United States, so the government should keep the rules as they are.

column2: It may have made sense once upon a time but not anymore. I am liberal thinker and I don't mean to say that we need to deport people in mass or not have systems in place to care for newborns of any status who happen to be born here. But citizenship should be a priveledge that is applied for by families or legal representation in exceptional circumstances, and it should be earned thorugh a process by which it is clear the person (or family) is well invested in our culture and economy. I have two daughters born in Switzerland, neither of whom were offered Swiss citizenship at birth because the simple fact of their birth didn't make them Swiss. Under the current system it is simply too easy to take advantage of the current law and use automatic citizenship to take more than is earned. Again, I am not saying we shouldn't be a compassionate country, and how a new system is implemented would be a lengthy, difficult task, but it definitely should change.
column3: Citizenship should be earned by people through their investment in the culture and economy. Birthright citizenship is too easy to take advantage of.

column2: Birthright citizen cannot be found in the US Constitution or the XIV-th Amendment. Ms. Stock may be a lawyer, but she demonstrates no understanding of A1S8P4 or the 14th. Anchor babies born 40 years ago are still not citizens and that issue has not be adjudicated.
column3: It is not in accordance with the U.S Constitution.

column2: A national birth registry would be unnecessary if birthright citizenship were restricted to those in the country legally. Under this system, in order to obtain a birth certificate for a state, the mother would be required to provide the equivalent of an I-9 form showing her presence in this country legally.
column3: It should only be available to those born in the country legally.

column2: There is nothing in the Fourteenth Amendment that permits birthright citizenship to non-citizens. In 1866, Senator Jacob Howard, co-author of the citizenship clause of the Fourteenth Amendment wrote: "Every Person born within the limits of the United States, and subject to their jurisdiction, is by virtue of natural law and national law a citizen of the United States. This will not, of course, include persons born in the United States who are foreigners, aliens, who belong to the families of ambassadors or foreign ministers accredited to the Government of the United States, but will include every other class of persons...only thru expatriation, which could be accomplished thru law alone, and not thru any immigrant acting on his own outside the law-and certainly not by any act of birth alone-could an alien become a citizen...[the] Constitution as now amended, forever withholds the right of citizenship in the case of accidental birth of a child belonging to foreign parents within the limits of the country."
column3: The Fourteenth Amendment does not outright permit birthright citizenship. Senator Jacob Howard, in 1866, wrote an opinion that excludes foreigners born in the US from citizenship.

column2: Reality check for those so far removed that have no idea what the issue is: Women come to the U.S. on temp visas or illegally to give birth in order to have the child become an American citizen. In some cases they stay, and in others they leave with the American child. Those that leave will eventually reap the benefits of American citizenship without ever contributing to it. It's become status symbol for foreign nationals to have children with the blue and gold passport. This is reality; and I'm sure the founding fathers didn't have this in mind when the constitution was adopted.
column3: People are abusing the system to create American citizenship for their families. If a person leaves the US they get the benefits of citizenship with out contributing to the US. It is now just a symbol of class for people to come and have children that are citizens by birth to have the right passport.

column2: Because this is a right conferred on the baby who has not done anything wrong, this right should not be abolished. But the parents should be stripped of the privilege of coming to the US for life, even for family reunification or aNY other purpose.
column3: Birthright citizenship is a right of a baby who has not done anything wrong.

column2: According to the Mexican constitution, Article 30- one way for Mexican nationality is - Those born in a foreign country of Mexican parents; of a Mexican father and a foreign mother; or of a Mexican mother and an unknown father; So if Trumps immigration plan begins with deportation for those from Mexico, it would in fact be deporting Mexican citizens...Mexico doesn't recognize them as American citizens. They are subject to the jurisdiction of Mexico.
column3: In countries like Mexico someone born in a foreign country can still obtain citizenship if their parent(s) are Mexican.

column2: Though I would like to agree with this article I have to disagree with it. The 14th amendment was a amendment rushed into the constitution after the civil war and it said that all people born here are citizens. The problem with this law was it was directed straight at freed slaves the writers never meant it to cover what it does today. The only way we can change that view is for it to go to the SC and say that this is what the authors meant and stop anchor babies.
column3: The 14th amendment was rushed into the constitution. The Birthright Citizenship law was intended for free slaves, but is not applicable to today's issues.

column2: This is a continuation of the "birthers" who still deny Barak Obama's right to be President. At some time or another, except for Native Americans, we were all "anchor babies". My question is how can Republicans (many of whom are "anchor babies") lobby to eliminate "anchor babies" to introduce themselves into women's wombs, and to prevent young people from competing in the world economy by denying them access to science, still support "small government"? When will a crowd arise that shouts, "this Emperor has no clothes!"
column3: Every person in the United States is descended from an anchor baby. How can republicans support small government when some of whom are anchor babies are against allowing anchor babies to educated.

column2: Stock's argument confuses me. It likely confuses her too. I favor population control everywhere. England does not need the Moslems of the East nor does France or Germany. This statement of mine should not be read as prejudice towards the MOSLEMS OF Europe. It is meant to say that if the Moslem states cannot run their business in a way that its people enjoy a reasonable standard of living for all its people it is no one else's responsibility to pick up the slack. The only exception to this broad principle might be war refugees. But people who come to the USA to deliver a child so that it can enjoy the fruits of citizenship , should not enjoy this privilege. That child is the result of two participants only one of whom resides in any sense of the word in the USA
column3: War refugees should be the only exception to this principle. Those that come to the US solely to have citizenship conferred on their children are abusing the system. Birthright citizenship should be abolished because the child may not have two parents who even live in the USA.

column2: We created this problem ourselves in the way we've chosen to enforce current laws. The birth of an anchor baby should never have had any bearing on whether the parents are eligible to be deported. Once we caved in to the notion of 'keeping families together', we were doomed. I am all for keeping families together. If we send the parents home they can take their children with them. We need to make that clear up front.
column3: Having a baby shouldn't prevent illegal parents from being deported.

column2: Not subject to the jurisdiction of the United States suggests, for example, people born in embassies, which are extraterritorial. Jurisdiction in this context is a territorial concept: i.e. where the laws can be applied. Immigrants, Legal and Illegal, tourists, students, etc. present in the united states while pregnant who deliver a child in the United States are subject to the Jurisdition of the U.S. by virtue of that presence.
column3: People born in the United States should be given citzenships, because they are born within it's jurisdiction or territory. Immigrants have to abide by the laws of the United States.

column2: What caste system? The Mexicans (who are most of the people abusing the sytem) who give birth here should have their kids take the nationality of the parents. They're Mexicans. Asking them to go home to Mexico and providing incentives for them to do so is hardly unfair.
column3: Babies born here should take the nationality of the parents.

column2: Count me a longtime fan of the 14th Amendment of the US Constitution, for its breadth and scope that encompasses the greatest of American values: not just defining citizenship, but setting forth states' obligations, due process, equal protection of the laws, This was the Amendment that required the states to follow the Bill of Rights. Brown v Board of Education, civil rights laws, privacy rulings, women's rights, gay rights, disability protections, they all flow from the 14th. Start tinkering, and you're risking a lot more than the status of some native-born children.
column3: The 14th amendment is good for the country in that it keeps citizenship rights stable across the states and ensures equal treatment. There are a lot of laws based on the 14th amendment it's too risky to change it for native-born children.

column2: I'm a psychiatrist on the faculty of Johns Hopkins University, and although I now specialize in dementia I used to work heavily in addictions and chronic mental illness. Drugs of abuse and addiction tend to move in fads, fashions, and trends, and it is important for public health that doctors' training adjust to these constant changes. At this moment the trend is opioid addiction particularly prescription drugs. The trend is moving a bit back to heroin (because it's cheaper!) but prescription drug addiction is still a huge public health problem. We (doctors) created the problem (inadvertently) and we should help solve it. A brief web-based training is not too much to ask; for many doctors it will be redundant as is much of the ongoing training we are required to participate in; but it is important to spread the word widely in the medical community.
column3: Doctors should have opioid training so they are aware of the drugs being abused. People are addicted to prescription opioids. Opioid training should be mandatory because prescription drug abuse is a public health problem. Since doctors are responsible for the issue, they should help address it. Short, web-based training would be helpful to doctors.

column2: The author assumes the conclusion about education on opioids- without providing evidence. Like Ioannidis said we have an epidemic of opinions in medicine today. Some studies have shown that education in opioids improves care. There is also studies showing education on pain care improves pain care. Education on opioids will miss the mark, in my opinion, if the goal is to improve pain care and prevent addiction to opioids. It is clear doctors do not wish to have education in either pain care or on opioids- as statements by the AMA and aafp and efforts by the MSSNY are indicative of. But being a doctor is not a god given right and society has the right to dictate to those who want to be doctors what education they need to obtain and maintain their license. So we should try to reeducate doctors in both using opioids and in pain care- its morally right and there is evidence that it can improve care.
column3: Studies have shown opioid training improves care. Doctors should have education in pain care or opioids. Doctors need to be held to nationwide educational standards to get and keep their licenses. Doctors should be educated in opioids to improve care.

column2: I'm a severe brain injury survivor (Grade 5 SAH). When dropped to inpatient sub acute care a gerontologist treating me prescribed Percocet for pain. I refused any medication other than prescribed by my neurosurgeon. In my situation a phone consultation with my neurosurgeon would have been best practice. Percocet could have destroyed any chance I had to regain neurological and cognitive function.
column3: Because of my experience with pain prescriptions, I would have benefited from consultation with a neurosurgeon. Medicines can destory neurological functions.

column2: Patients should also have to undergo mandatory training. I have used opioids for 12 years and I have not increased that amount in all that time because I studied up on pain medication and addiction. Not one doctor over that time told me one thing that I learned in my own. I know more than most doctors. Doctors are passing out pills they don't understand and their patients have even a less understanding how to use them. No wonder why there is a big problem.
column3: Doctors should be trained because mine have not provided that information. Doctors do not fully understand the medications they are prescribing.

column2: Maybe part of this training would include to not withhold pain relief from those who suffer from conditions that are painful on a daily basis. It seems all the hysteria on the misuse of opioids has given rise to more government control in the doctor's office. The majority of patients who take these drugs take them responsibly. They do not take them for the high, they take them for just enough relief to help maintain normal function. Let's not make doctors afraid to take care of the suffering they encounter, let's help them learn to distinguish between the budding addict and the the poor soul who is legitimately suffering.
column3: Training should include not withholding pain relief form those who suffer pain daily. The hysteria on misuse of opioids has put the government in more control of the doctor's office. The majority of opioid patients take the drugs responsibly. We don't need to make doctors afraid of caring for patients.

column2: DR Ballantyne- Sydenhams views no longer apply to modern medicine- we have treatments now- like platelet rich plasma, LENS neurofeedback, stem cell therapy, German new medicine, neural prolotherapy, oxidized ATP, MitoQ, ESWT, acupotomy- that you and your colleagues need to learn to help people in pain. No doubt the overuse of opioids has stemmed from the moral laziness of doctors when it came to offer the right care for people in pain. Doctors and medicine is still remiss in developing and deploying good treatment for pain. And training based on the little that pain specialists know and do will be of too little help to people in pain. Its time for Ballantyne to call for raising standards of care for all involved in pain care. And lets not maketoo much out of past treatments for the prevalence of pain is on the rise.
column3: There are many treatments that doctors need to learn to help people in pain. Opioid training will help stop lazy doctors from over prescribing for pain. The medical field needs to develop a better treatment for pain.

column2: Why are the trade names for these medications suddenly taboo in the news? Are the reporters for some reason not allowed to say Percocet, Vicodin, Hydrocodoe, suddenly, just like they were not allowed to say 'torture' . And of course, training is required. Doctors shoveled Hydrocodone at me after my back operation, 240 pills, and I needed exactly zero. It was weird. Not only that, an intelligent nurse took me off hydrocodone while I was in the hospital, saying it was not having a good effect on me, and that should have guided the exit prescriptions, also, instead of just getting the xerox copy from the already written doctors wrote orders. Doctors are not allowed to divorce their brains from their profession, despite the obvious example Ben Carson showed us of what type of skills make one a top surgeon.
column3: Doctors gave me Hydrocodone that I didn't need after a back operation. A smart nurse took me off hydrocodone because it wasn't affecting me well and that is what should have determined what prescriptions I was given when I left the hospital.

column2: I see no reason why this has to be an either or situation. Doctors should be trained about the prescribing of opioids as it is apparent that they are either ignorant or negligent in their prescribing practices. Imagine a doctor having the ability to check to make sure a patient isn't getting more than one prescription for an opioid by going to a computer and looking it up but chooses not to....is that good medicine? Somebody needs training or maybe they just need their licenses pulled!
column3: They should be trained since they are currently negligent or ignorant as see in their practice of prescribing.

column2: The right to vote is enumerated more than any other right. And while no right is absolute, this right is, or should be, easier to exercise than any other right. Barriers to vote such as those enacted here in North Carolina serve no purpose other than to disenfranchise citizens. These barriers exist in many forms, with the photo ID requirement being the tip of the disenfranchisement iceberg. These tactics abridge not only the right to vote, but violate the equal protection clause of the 14th amendment, and create the very taxation without representation that the founders rebelled against.
column3: The right to vote should be easier to exercise than other rights. Some of the rules for voting are simple barriers that only make voters less likely to vote. Voting should be a right because tactics are being used to infringe on voters without a constitutional protection. If it is not then we will be returning to the type of government the US rebelled against.

column2: Please name one First World country that does not require a strict I.D. to vote, not to mention the same requirement in numerous Second and even Third World countries. For the left to claim that asking blacks and Latino citizens to provide valid, photo I.D.s, despite the necessity of having such to engage in ordinary life in America, is to say that they are malignantly stupid and detached, as if Algonquin J. Calhoun and Lightnin' were representative of ordinary minority folk.
column3: IDs are required to vote. It is stupid to ask citizens to provide ID since you need an ID to be an  ordinary American.

column2: The liberals' contributions to this section are basically saying that two Articles and four Amendments will fix what two Articles and three Amendments haven't. Yet, the states do a good job of running elections and the required IDs are easy to get, in a process already overseen by our heavily politicized DOJ. Regarding the extravagant demand for transportation, both major parties have local people who drive you to get IDs or to vote already. We should keep that effort in the private sector where it arose. If you are frantic enough not to trust the judicial system already, one more amendment won't cure what ails you. What would help all of us is more knowledge of history - which we won't find on the Soros blogs. Force people to vote? When all they are interested in is celebrity and sports buzz or their iPhones, absolutely not. They'll end up simply voting for the first name, and when that is a GOPer, we'll have to keep watch over the bridges in the big-city liberal-statist philosophical ghettos/campuses.
column3: It should be something for the private sector. If you don't trust the judicial system to protect voters an amendment won't help anyways. People should not be forced to vote when all they are interested in is trivial things.

column2: It was never about the ID but about the roadblocks put in place to keep certain groups of people from ever obtaining the 'chosen' ID. With rules like the ID has to have an expiration date on it or it is invalid or requiring several copies of documents then raising the cost of those copies ten fold or the need for bills in the person's name with the physical address so that renters and people with post office boxes and married women could be kept from getting the ID. We all know what is really going on, the only solution looking for a problem is voter fraud claims by republicans. It is just an excuse to let the worst people in the country skate unhindered into office by cheating and discriminating. Shame on you for all the lies and deceptions that you put in this piece and shame on NYT for allowing you to do it.
column3: It is about keeping certain people from voting, not about simple ID. The worst people get into office easily by cheating and discriminating.

column2: The guarantee that voting shall not be denied on account of race, sex, or age for citizens 18 or older, is not a guarantee that voting shall not be denied on account of not having a drivers license or gun permit, for having had a past felony, or for having recently moved. We need an affirmative right to vote, not just a prohibition on certain forms of voting restrictions.
