Requiring humanities will broaden the education of engineers. This would be a major loss to society as a whole, and people would miss out on an amazing experience.

column2: Cultivating what imagination? Our schools are turning into test taking factories where the emphasis is in passing the take no prisoners do or die high stakes NCLB exams. Only two subjects matter these days--reading and math. The rest is nothing but alot of expensive twaddle that the stressed out taxpayers just can't afford. Want to learn French? Go to Berlitz
column3: Humanities programs are a waste of taxpayer money with no result.

column2: These cuts could lead to an examination of the humanities in science and engineerings programs. As an engineering student I took anthropology, history, economics, and psychology courses. They were more useful than the electives in nuclear engineering. Economics was required for engineers, very reasonably, and the the psychology was required by the Navy ROTC, also with good reason. Humanities and context to science, and humanities and science together would improve the quality of many current issues, climate change is an obvious example.
column3: Cuts in universities could lead to examinations of humanities in other programs. Humanities programs improve understanding of current issues.

column2: The Humanities are our values and we are loosing more and more of them. The result is the Tea Party movement, a group of people who repeat buzz words with no understanding of their true meaning. We are gradually becoming Weimar German (the meaning of that can be found in a book somewhere in a Humanities department text-book, which is being thrown away).The result is this country is being sold to the highest bidder and the foolish American public has no clue to the ramifications.
column3: Humanities represent societal values and removing them impacts us negatively. We are slowly turning into Weimar German. Humanities are still important in our society and should not be eliminated because they are not viewed as leading to a profitable career.

column2: Very simple question: who is going to pay for this? Convince me, an average Joe Shmo, that my buck, spent for Medieval History or French Poetry of 18th Century studies, will actually do good, and I'll gladly pay. But so far I see just a bunch of snobs that look at me down their noses and say: you don't understand anything, just give us your money! Those who chose humanities as their occupation and way of life, should just be prepared to starve from time to time. I think it is very noble, if you guys have the goal to make the World better, not just earn some bucks.
column3: Who would be paying for the humanities programs?. If you can show me how my tax money for French poetry and the such benefits anyone and I will gladly pay. Colleges do not need additional humanities programs.

column2: As a French-speaking Canadian who obviously understands English, when I saw the title of the article I was looking forward to the debaters' comments. Yet no one answers the question: do colleges need French departments? Nobody mentions the unique perspective French culture, literature, philosophy and language can bring to students. Nor does any debater write about the worthlessness of French, should that be their opinion. Were there no debaters who knew something about French? And when I mention French, I refer to all countries that, through history and to this day, have lived and still live in French as well as those countries, such as the United States, that have pockets of citizens that live and think in French. If the debate was not about French departments then there is a subtle English code that I fail to decrypt.
column3: Studies in the humanities are important because they expose students to subjects that help to expand their minds and think creatively.

column2: It would be a shame for universities to give up the teaching of French; it is a language spoken throughout Europe. Even if we don't master the language,it is a wonderful help when traveling. The same people who will go on to financial success after college are the people who will spend vacation time touring France and Italy. Of course, the humblest waiter in France understands some English but an American appears uneducated if he/she can't even attempt speaking some French. We can't expect that all foreigners have studied English when we haven't studied some foreign language ourselves.
column3: French is a language that is used all throughout Europe. Learning just some French can help with travelling. Those who find successful careers after college often spend their time touring Europe after they are done with their education. Americans need to learn about other cultures.

column2: One would think that SUNY believes that the only goal to an education is to find a job and moreover, that the only jobs that exist (or are worth pursuing) are related to math and science. This would seem to ignore the vast number of jobs that require creativity, langauge skiils, communication skills, and cultural understanding on a global level, not to mention countless others. I am a resaonably successful attorney and can think of no better degree for my personal and professional development and satisfaction than my undergraduate degree in French.
column3: The humanities are important for developing a student's creative and critical thinking which are important skills for succeeding in a global economy. My undergraduate degree helps with my personal and professional development and satisfaction.

column2: As a recent college graduate with a degree in French, I have to say that I am disappointed that foreign language literatures are first on the chopping block. Not only does the study of literature prompt students to critically analyze texts and articulate arguments in writing, it provides students with a more well-rounded and global view of a discipline that all too often focuses on old dead white British and American men. As a student of French I have had an enormous exposure to the cultural and political issues that dominate North African, West African, and Carribean peoples. Moreover, I have been fortunate enough to gain an understanding of the American immigration debate through the comparative study of Chicano/Chicana literature juxtaposed with the literature of North African immigrants in France. It would really be a shame to see this multifaceted and dynamic discipline disappear from some Universities because of uninformed notions that the study of French is nothing more than an American romanticization and fetishization of a European culture and language.
column3: Studying literature develops critical analysis and writing skills. It offers a wider perspective when it comes to education instead of simply focusing on a curriculum that was created by old white British and American men. I have broadened the scope of my knowledge to include issues relating to North African, West African, and Carribbean peoples. I have learned to understand American immigration from my studies in Chicano literature and that of North African immigrants in France.

column2: The U.S. desperately needs to strengthen its ties to the larger world. All of its failures stem from its traditional and on-going isolation. The Humanities, and in particular, the acquisition of a foreign language (culture, literature, history, alternative ways of living), are vital to broadening the professional lives of all young Americans. The study of French is the doorway to understanding our own background (some 40% of English derives from French), our history, our identity. Cutting such vital elements of education is in fact suicidal for U.S. society.
column3: The US's failures come from its ongoing isolation, and needs to strengthen its ties to the larger world. The humanities are vital to a broad and professional education. French language study helps with understanding culture. Cutting humanities departments is suicidal for US society.

column2: Cutting these programs will deprive Americans enrolled at US universities of the broader and deeper intellect they need to compete in the global economy. I specify Americans, because all the non-American students acquire multi-lingual fluency in the home countries, etc. I acquired fluency in German while taking it at Indiana University as a minor. That skill has made all the difference in my 30-year marketing career.
column3: Americans will be deprived of the broader and deeper intellect they need to compete in the global economy if these programs are cut.

column2: This debate is misleadingly headlined "Do Colleges Need French Departments?". I say that because Nussbaum, and most of the others who have answered after her, are addressing the much bigger question of "With humanities programs being cut at many universities, what do students stand to lose?" I agree with most of what Nussbaum says, but my take on it is this: money is short, and we need to use it more wisely to ensure that all university students get a good education in humanities, be they future businesspeople, engineers or journalists. The existence of this or that four-year degree, or a given department, doesn't mean this will necessarily happen.
column3: In my opinion if money is lacking then it needs to be spent more wisely in the humanities to ensure that every field has a grounding in them.

column2: Having lived in Germany (Army bases) and traveled widely, I am well aware of that there are few Americans that can speak foreign languages. Most Americans cannot understand why someone would want to learn a foreign language. Having said that, my 5-6 years of French and limited German never proved of much use in those countries (many Germans speak English, and the French are less than helpful to foreigners trying to speak their language) or elsewhere. Later in life I took up Spanish, and this has proved to be very useful in travel and being able to practice it on a regular basis (Washington, DC area). I think that the colleges need to rethink their language curriculum. At an east coast boarding school I attended in the '60s, Latin classes were mandatory absent a waiver. The world has changed and French use in the world has changed dramatically. Colleges need to take this into account. It is a shame to have people spend years on these languages and then never using them in their adult life. BTW I have one niece taking college Arabic and another taking high school Spanish.
column3: Few Americans can speak foreign languages. Limited foreign language study is not enough to be effective in those countries. Spanish classes were very useful when travelling.

column2: I agree with Dr. Bauerlein. I am but one case study of what is probably a larger trend. I graduated with my B. S. in Computer Information Systems. But what I was really enthused about was literature and writing. So I took two years off from work to go into a Masters program in English. My enthusiasm turned to repugnance when I realized that succeeding in the humanities was more about politics and high theory than a passion and a dedication to teach literature. Now I am back to working in information technology. Universities were once the gateways to information and learning. With the internet and our vast open information resources, we no longer have to pay outrageous tuition costs in order to get access to those resources and commentary on those resources. The best thing that my two years off gave me was the time to read the great works of Western culture. Unless things change in the humanities departments, I will advise my children to pursue their study of the humanities in their leisure hours. As I found out, when you make a profession out of the humanities, it leads to crass careerism and outlandish theory.
column3: I lost my enthusiasm for humanities when I realized success was was more politics and high theory than a dedication to teach literature. The internet provides this kind of information for free. Humanities should be for recreation.

column2: I can't understand why the justification for the study of Humanities is utilitarian in most of the pieces and blogs in this article. Certainly critical thinking skills can be obtained in the social and natural sciences (often to a greater degree than in languages) and ditto for the other general skills it supposedly provides (but not necessarily). The point is that Humanities constitutes windows to many areas of human thinking and accomplishment in the past and present--and that in itself is sufficient justification. The arguments put forth by Humanists in this piece are not very compelling (if that is a sign of the skills the discipline trains them for). Include some scientists in the debate to make it interdisciplinary. An important issue that has determined the desperate thinking of parents and students is that the cost of university education--even public education--has gone up enormously and the investment cost in education (for families and the state) makes them increasingly think in these narrowly pragmatic terms. It is a reality, not merely a sign of increasingly philistine times.
column3: The humanities help students learn about many areas of human thinking and accomplishment.

column2: While I was getting my doctorate at Harvard, I wrote two articles saying basically the same thing Prof Bauerlein says here. In both cases readers attacked me as reactionary (Tea Partiers would likely call me a Communist) and argued for the importance of abstruse theory. Even though I have a PhD in medieval literature, I wonder if there's any point in saving the humanities at the university level. It's become a sewer. A sewer of fashionable theory. I remember one faculty member at Harvard proudly justifying the decision to give tenure to a woefully underqualified professor of Spanish literature on the grounds that the department "needed" an openly gay professor who could teach about things like gay pride and gay rage. The two articles I refer to are: "Apartheid in the Curriculum." Harvard Magazine, January-February 1992, p. 14. "A Crit of Lit: Teaching Literature in the Ivory Tower." Perspective, vol. X, no. 3 (April 1993), 8 ff. Reprinted vol. X, no. 5 (summer 1993), 20 ff.
column3: Humanities at the university level have become a sewer and it is pointless to save them.

column2: The skillset involved in learning to write clear, concise and engaging prose will not go out of date. Ditto the ability to evaluate and process information from a disparate range of sources, or to listen compassionately or (heavens!) communicate with someone else in THEIR language. Why has no one mentioned that French is still the lingua franca of many African nations, one of two official languages of our neighbors to the north, and a significant language throughout Europe?
column3: There is always a need for people to know how to write well and engage an audience is a timeless skill. Humanities help students to process information and communicate with other people more effectively, sometimes in other languages.

column2: This is the one post that I agree with. The humanities are that: a human endeavor. Language is probably the most important thing we do, both physically and mentally. It's what makes us human. Ultimately this takes us back to a question the Greeks often asked: what's a good life? What's rewarding, what's fulfilling? These days we all live relatively well, compared to our ancestors at least. Is it absolutely necessity to think purely in terms of utility? I have an HDTV, is it absolutely necessary I have a 3dTV tomorrow? Why? Studying languages and being able to communicate successfully gives insight into culture, gesture, and structure; how is that not useful? I study languages on a daily basis, and I'm not that good at them as I get older. But I liken it to exercising, like front squatting or distance running; somehow, deep down, I know it's good for me.
column3: The programs are a study of humanity itself. College needs humanities programs because language is what makes us human. Studying languages aids in communication and can help students learn about other cultures.

column2: That's absolutely right! The one-country/one-vote system means that it becomes all too easy to corrupt the voting system by offering inducements/bribes to representatives of poor countries. However, to change the system to favour the developed world cannot be the way to go, neither in the UN nor in FIFA. My preference (hardly ideal, but practical) would be to have a rotation of World Cup venues: Europe, Asia, Africa, the Americas, Middle East. This would not eradicate corruption, but might well limit its scope. And, btw, it would be a very good idea to have term limits on elected FIFA executives. Blatter after Havelange is a sequence that does not inspire confidence.
column3: A one-country/one-vote system would be too easy to corrupt. Soccer really needs FIFA, but protections need to be in place so the developed word is not favored.

column2: Turner's argument that Obamacare is inherently flawed and cannot be made to work overlooks some important counterexamples, including the success of the Swiss (and to a lesser extent the Dutch) healthcare system. Furthermore, the same basic premise (guaranteed coverage across a large risk pool without adverse selection) is working well even in America, in large employer-subsidized group plans. A responsible market-oriented conservative would be asking why Obamacare isn't working as well as those plans, not seeking to bury it without any serious analysis.
column3: Taking a cue from the success of the Swiss and Dutch healthcare models proves Obamacare can work, too.

column2: Medicare for anyone who wishes to enroll, regardless of age or employment status? Yes. It is long past time to see health care as a necessity of survival rather than a privilege of wealth. Premiums tied to age and income, with no penalty for being diabetic, being a survivor of cancer treatment, being mentally ill. How un-American can you get? Maybe it's time we eliminated the profit motive from some aspects of survival.
column3: Healthcare should be a right, not a priveledge.

column2: The American public is being taken for a ride. The Left knew all along the Obamacare model would fail, paving the way for the PUBLIC OPTION. The Left believe that the people cannot be trusted to elect the politicians who would propose the PO in congress and take the heat for it. Instead the Left resorts to flim-flam tactics like Obamacare. There is no trust in government and this flim-flam is a big reason why.
column3: The American public is being lied to.

column2: Health Insurance may still be a functioning industry (barely), but HEALTH CARE is a market failure. As such, the only solution is a single payer system paid through payroll and/or income taxes--everybody pays something. Cut out the profits, pay off medical school debt for doctors and then pay them as government workers, based on their level of expertise.
column3: Health care is a market failure, even if Health Insurance is still barely functioning. A single payer system is the only solution.

column2: My take away lesson from these years of ACA is that we were sold a political promise that like too many was a lie. The Republicans dont have to raise their little finger for this program to fail, it will die of its own losses. Where are the number guys and what do they say about it now, the guys who were touting the program for Mr. Obama? Its a wonderful warm and fuzzy notion to fund healthcare for everyone, and in countries that pay their doctors around 50,000 a year and drugs aren't outrageous etc etc, it may be feasible, but thats not the USA. Check out how much money the drug companies pay our politicians for example. Those tens of millions of dollars comes from the citizens and their insurance in an endless cycle of financial and political imbalance that is always spiraling towards that 1%.
column3: Healthcare for all is feasible in some countries, but not the USA. Drug companies pay politicians.

column2: Of course it's sustainable but the party (republican) in control of congress wants it to fail and has thrown every roadblock in its way that they could. If they had actually worked with the democrats, we could have had a much better plan. For almost 8 years now, they've refused to help in running the country and have tried to block everything.
column3: Obamacare is sustainable but the republicans want it to fail so they are throwing up all the roadblocks they can.

column2: With an increase in insurance mergers, and the most recent Aetna/Anthem failed merger due to the FTC, there has been a substantial decrease in competition within the insurance sector. Lack of competition is bad for consumers because there are less players fighting for your business, so it is easier to raise, and keep prices high. Obamacare has also made it impossible for insurance companies to price policies based on pre-existing conditions, which is forcing actuaries to increase insurance costs across the board. Aetna has lost hundreds of millions of dollars on it's Affordable Care Act arm and is dropping the option in 11 out of the 15 states where it was offered. If insurance companies keep getting strangled by the government, there will be a sharp decrease in the participation rate of the Affordable Care Act and the Gov't may be left on the hook to provide policies (socialism) although I'm not sure what would happen if private participation drops off a cliff. If the trend continues, AFA is not sustainable.
column3: Obamacare makes it impossible for insurance companies to price based on pre-existing conditions and this causes insurance prices across the board to increase. The Affordable Care At is being dropped by Aetna in 11 of the 15 states it is available in because it's lost hundreds of millions of dollars. Insurance companies should not be governed by government policies.

column2: America will never be a truly great country until health care is provided for all for little to no cost. We pay for public education whether we want to or not, we pay for wars that cost trillions. The U.S. can afford health care for all. Just do it.
column3: Health care will make America great when it does not cost much. We spend trillions on wars and pay for public education. Healthcare is still affordable for the United States.

column2: As a Medicare provider, I see confusion on the part of most of my patients, and a serious decline in my reimbursement rate. Patients seem to look first to cost (monthly premium and pharmaceuticals), then to services. Large insurers (Aetna, Humana, Blue Cross) are in the business of making money, not providing services. Medicare (as an insurance company) is in the business of cost-control for established medical services. As long as medical care is dependent on a business model (i.e., competition), and not disease management, we will be forever in a conundrum. Healthcare needs to become a right, not a benefit.
column3: Most of my patients, as a Medicare provider, are confused and my reimbursement rate is declining. Customers prioritize cost over anything else. Mega sized insurance companies aren't looking to provide services, they are only seeking to make more profits. Medical care should be dependent on disease management, not a business model.

column2: Marijuana Is Now Big Business Wrong - marijuana has been big business for decades. The California Dept. of Agriculture has listed it as the number one cash crop in the state for over 20 years in a row. Now, the business is above ground, where it should be. Regulation, taxation, better education, savings in enforcement and incarceration costs - everybody wins. We are slowly now heading in the right direction - ending the biggest and most widespread wrongful jailing of American citizens since slavery. It can't happen quick enough.
column3: Pot has been the number one cash crop in California for over 20 years - it benefits everyone via regulation, taxation, education, savings in enforcement and incarceration costs. Ending the prohibition on marijuana would ensure that fewer citizens are unfairly jailed.

column2: Former Nobel economist Milton Friedman once said that the main purpose of government, with regard to illegal, black-market drugs, was to serve as a protection force for illegal drug cartels. By Friedman's definition, professional drug-warriors like Kevin Sabet, with their relentless, decades long campaign to incarcerate marijuana users, help cartels and drug gangs maintain their markets. A new, legal, regulated market for marijuana will have problems, but that system will replace a brutal, totally unregulated black market that rarely asks for a driver's license before making a sale. Mr. Sabet makes a show of concern for public health, but turns a blind eye to the damage done when young people are arrested, strip-searched and thrown into cells with violent criminals and rapists. The ACLU reports 749,825 arrested for marijuana in 2012.
column3: Government when it comes to illegal drugs is to protect us from drug cartels. The activities of drug-warriors ensure that cartels and drug gangs keep their markets going. A regulated market has replaced an unregulated and dangerous black market. There was a low number of arrests for marijuana.

column2: Legalization is just too dangerous, says Ms. Evins. Has she studied the Rat Park experiments? Conducted over 20 years in a prestigious lab, then published as peer-reviewed journal studies, they establish that addiction is almost impossible to induce when the subjects are living in healthy environments. Oh, one detail: the subjects were rats...which correlate to humans 80% of the time in lab study results. So there's an 80% chance that human addiction results not from the substance but from deprived, abusive environments. There is a place she could put her efforts productively, instead of fighting a losing battle against a public jaded by decades of lies.
column3: Research on marijuana was conducted for 20 years before being made legal in Colorado. Addiction is almost impossible when the subjects are happy and healthy. There is a high chance that addiction actually stems from bad environments rather than the substance itself.

column2: The juvenile attitude in which people treat legalization is embarrassing. We need more study? Contrary to what some believe, cannabis has been around forever, and people have been smoking it forever. We don't need more study, we need to legalize and treat our populace like adults. We do so many things that are much more dangerous but we don't go to jail for them.
column3: Humans have know about and used cannabis for a long time. Adults should be able to make their own choices. There are much more dangerous things than smoking pot that are not illegal.

column2: . Do alcohol and marijuana affect some users negatively? Absolutely. Should minors be allowed to legally consume either one? No. But the war on drugs is a failure. All it does is promote violence and enrich big time drug dealers and the utterly corrupt interdiction apparatus both in the U.S. and abroad. I don't endorse the use of either marijuana or alcohol. But making them illegal protects no one.
column3: The war on drugs has failed. Making  marijuana or alcohol illegal protects no one.

column2: The U.S. DHHS estimated, in 2008, that more than 18% of our population smokes pot. More than 55 million Americans. Under prohibition they are all subject to becoming coerced by the courts "patients" of Prof. Evins and her profession cohorts. Legalized she, and her pharmaceutical industry sponsors, lose that potential court ordered government business. Dr. Evins CV: "Dr. Evins has been the recipient of a career development award from theNational Institutes of Drug Abuse (NIDA)" "Career development" indeed.
column3: Colorado did not go to far because 55 million Americans are already using pot.

column2: We have hundreds of thousands of scientists; we have hundreds of major universities; and millions of marijuana users over the last fifty years. So, why so little good research? Blame the federal government which made marijuana research unduly difficult. and similar foreign governments. A Catch 22: little research since marijuana is illegal; illegal party because little research showing it is relatively safe. Somebody had to blow this dam of repression sky high; Colorado has done this. Now, belatedly, the research can go on.
column3: There is not enough research on marijuana. Since Colorado has legalized weed, research can be done as to how successful that policy is.

column2: Arguments such as these frustrate me. When Dr. Evins comes up with a solution to the downsides of keeping marijuana illegal (which any 16-year old in the country can find now without any difficulty whatsoever), not limited to the money flowing to drug cartels, the violence associated with illegal distribution, the racial and ethnic differences in lives lost, ruined and diminished due to disparities in criminal justice processing, (should I go on?), I'll take state control and distribution any day of the week. If she wants to whine about the marketing to children, tell her to go whine to all those free-market Republicans who believe that the markets can do no harm. Maybe they should be required to take the Hippocratic Oath.
column3: Colorado's legal pot deters crime and reduces jailing of minorities. State control and distribution of pot is something I can support.

column2: I'd like to know where Dr. Evins is getting her statistics. They contradict virtually everything I've read about marijuana, and they contradict my personal experience. I smoked marijuana from August 1972 to November 1973, at first fairly rarely, eventually nearly daily, for a few weeks twice daily, then abruptly stopped completely for about two months, then smoked a few times a week for a couple months. I haven't smoked in since. These changes in usage had to do with availability and (mostly) social circumstances. (I didn't begin to crave it more; I gradually lost interest as the novelty wore off.) Marijuana in those days was very much a social drug; I smoked it alone just once in my life. I wouldn't even say that stopping and starting was easy; it was nothing whatsoever. I never encountered anyone at any time in my life who showed the slightest sign of being even slightly addicted. (I do know what addiction is. I've known many people, some of them close to me, clearly addicted to alcohol.) It's true, however, that marijuana does cause "like memory and cognitive impairment"--TEMPORARILY. It's called "being stoned".
column3: Marijuana used to be a social drug. Colorado legalizing marijuana had little impact on society. I never met anyone addicted to pot. Marijuana only causes temporary memory and cognitive impairment - being stoned.

column2: I hate pot. I think putting it in candy is stupid. However, even though I gave it up after 2 years of thinking thee must be something wrong with me for not enjoying it, I came to the conclusion that it was so far from addictive that it probably drove some people to abandon it in favor of mindless drug like cocaine, heroin or beer and booze. If the AMA and foolish and misinformed people like MS Evins believe the nonsense they spread; let them sleep alone. I suspect that almost all hardcore users of pot are already using it. If Ms Evins were truly honest ,she would be pushing for re-enactment of alcohol prohibition, which , like all drug prohibitions, didn't work either, but was at least based upon a great deal of experimental and observed fact. All our history with marijuana is based upon the predilections of one side or the other in the argument over it's status.
column3: Marijuana is so far from addictive that it drove some to abandon it in favor of harder drugs. Most marijuana users aren't influenced by the ruling. Alcohol is more dangerous then marijuana. Marijuana is labeled by one side or the other as what they want it to be.

column2: Is there any other substance whose legal status is dependent upon ALL users to be completely responsible upstanding citizens? Imagine if we debated outlawing soda because it was found that kids involved in school shootings consumed it. Fortunately, due to Bloomberg's attempts to just limit sizes, I know that the American Beverage Association would be there to remind us that it's not about protecting us from ourselves, but about our choices as Americans! It's not just alcohol that gets a different standard, it's literally everything that's not cannabis.
column3: No substances require users to verify they are completely responsible citizens. Everything that isn't pot is subject to a double standard so Colorado didn't go too far with pot.

column2: We put limitations on a number of felons once their time has been served, sex offenders must register and their housing options are limited. Child molesters are limited in the jobs and activities the can have. I believe felons should be able to petition the courts and demonstrate they are a solid citizen and their full citizenship rights should be restored. Gun ownership should never be restored to violent felons. Just one man's opinion.
column3: Felons are already limited enough. Felons should be able to have their full citizenship rights restored if they can demonstrate they are a solid citizen.

column2: I agree that once an obligation to Society has been made by serving the penalty assessed at trial, the felon should be restored to full citizenship. Having said that I would add a period of time, say five years of good behavior after release from prison, before voting rights are restored. There should be a burden of proof that a felon must endure to prove that he or she can be a good citizen once again before voting rights can be exercised. This can only be done after the felon has been back in free society for some time.
column3: Felons should be allowed to vote to make things fair for African-Americans. A former criminal who's paid off their societal debt should be afforded the same rights as everyone else without arbitrary exclusions.

column2: Most definitely, I agree that felons should be allowed to vote. Their rights should not even be suspended in my opinion, not for a day. Taking away the right to vote is the ultimate affront in a so-called democracy, and it helps create the downward spiral of criminals in our system. It is just another reason that once a person becomes a felon, they have very little chance of ever succeeded in this country. They'd be much better off leaving the country, however even that right is removed. Criminals are citizens too. This antiquated idea of removing voting rights is akin to the policies you see in North Korean.
column3: Felons should be allowed to vote. Felons should not lose their rights, for even a day. Every citizen should be allowed to vote, even felons. Felons are people just like everyone else and this practice is similar to North Korea.

column2: We live in a society where the criminal charges that a defendant faces and the likelihood of conviction depend very strongly upon how much money the defendant can spend for legal representation. As long as that remains true (and it is true), Roger Clegg's argument remains invalid. There are very many poor people in prison for non-violent crimes that were prosecuted while the defendant was too young and too poor to pay for legal representation. Many of them would not have been convicted of felony crimes if could have afforded a competent attorney. Thus, the blanket denial of suffrage for all felons cannot be justified.
column3: Prisons are full of people who did not get a fair trial because they lacked the money and experience. Not all felons would have been convicted of felony if they could have afforded a good attorney so their privilege to vote cannot be justified.

column2: How about a middle ground: felons, after a certain period without any more troubles with the law, except for very minor infractions, should have their voting right automatically restored - without any special processes that can be opened to voter suppression abuse.
column3: After a period of probation, felons should have their voting rights restored.

column2: People convicted of crimes don't lose their interest in how their class is treated. While the Constitution barred slave, women and who knows from voting, times have changed. Without those who know the unfairness of incarceration, the voter lists would be tipped in favor of those who want to continue the incarceration industry. Once released and encouraged to renter after paying their debt, how can they be denied the right to help select someone who might change the way society treats people who have erred?
column3: Convicts still care about the treatment of their class. If felons were allowed to vote it would help to put an end to the unfair incarceration industry. Felons should not be denied their right to vote after paying their debt to society and reentering the community.

column2: There are a lot of politicians who make laws before they go to prison, or before they are found guilty of ethics violations. And many who write laws to give politicians relative indemnity. Any politician who claims convicted felons shouldn't vote more or less consider themselves above the law. Those who are convicted felons are not always guilty of the crimes they were convicted of, and when they are, they are a fraction of Americans who have committed crimes but not caught. Most Americans are guilty of some violation of law during there lifetime. Refusing to treat all people with dignity and make them feel forgiven and responsible citizens is a greater crime than most convicted felons are imprisoned for.
column3: Many felons are not actually guilty and many guilty are not caught. Most American's are guilty of committing crimes. It is a crime to rob people of their dignity and forgive them once they are free from imprisonment.

column2: I don't think anybody should be voting while incarcerated. The point of a criminal sentence is to deny criminals, for a period, the rights and freedoms of a citizen. But once someone is released from prison, surely they should have a chance to reintegrate. Haven't they paid their debt? To say to someone who stole a car at 17 that they can NEVER again be a full citizen is completely unjust.
column3: Have they not already paid their societal debt on completing their sentence. A person who stole a car at 17 should not be barred from being a full citizen for life.

column2: Our drug laws would probably have been liberalized far sooner if we had simply allowed all US citizens to vote including former felons and even those incarcerated. Our politicians would probably be paying attention to the issue of recidivism if the people most affected by it were people who could vote. Improving educational and employment prospects for former felons would become a priority if these people were in fact voters. Wrongful convictions, which still happen with far too much frequency in America, would get the extra special attention they deserve if we allowed felons to vote. By disenfranchising this entire group of people, we have created a system that ignores the serious issues related to this population. We have the highest incarceration rate in the world and we disenfranchise millions who are formerly incarcerated because of past mistakes. This process further exacerbates the challenges of ethnic minorities and the working poor. We need to empower all US citizens to be able to participate in our democracy so we can start to create the more equal and fair society we all claim to support.
column3: Politicians would pay more attention if felons could vote. Education and employment would become more important for felons if they could vote. Allowing felons to vote would help wrongful convictions get proper attention from government. If felons are not allowed to vote, it causes society to ignore issues that pertain to prison populations. We put a lot of people in jail and punish them for their past mistakes once free and this is a challenge for the poor and minorities. We need to empower all US citizens to participate in our democracy, to create the more equal and fair society.

column2: I believe that felons should have to petition a court for restoration of their complete citizenship rights. Those that can show a reformed lifestyle should have their rights restored. Some will argue that if they have paid their debt to society they should be automatically be restored, but we make sex offenders register and limit their housing choices. Child molesters are forbidden from some occupations. We do limit the rights and freedoms of some felons even after they have served their time. I do not believe anyone convicted of a violent crime should ever be able to own guns.
column3: Felons can be restored to society, thus they should have their rights restored.

column2: If felons complete their sentences, their punishment should be over. It's bad enough that they can't get hired. Punishment continues because they can't be full citizens even though they've paid their debts to society. No wonder there is so much recidivism.
column3: Once a felon has paid their debt to society they should not continue to be punished by not being able to vote.

column2: I live in Florida which makes it very difficult to restore civil rights to felons. The laws have become a new form of Jim Crow to prevent minorities from voting. Your chance of becoming a felon is much greater if you are dark of skin hue. Or a different ethnicity than being a WASP. Time to end this persecution of people We need to reform our justice system.. After release all voting rights should be restored . If a non violent conviction even the right to own fire arms should be restored.
column3: The laws are a form of discrimination to prevent minorities from voting. We should reform our justice system so that once released from prison felons are able to vote.

column2: I'm not sympathetic to felons but there are many with essentially minor possession convictions who are felons for no good reason. Any attempt to exclude felons has to take the deeply racist nature of drug enforcement into account. Aside form that sticking point I don't believe that felons should vote.
column3: There a people who are felons for no good reason.

column2: If there were any evidence that a state's disenfranchisement law is truly discriminatory, it would be considered unconstitutional under Supreme Court rulings. That assumes an impartial Supreme Court. As we all know, the Republican appointees are on a mission to disenfranchise minorities. That is why they were placed on the Court. Clegg assumes his conclusion, and then reasons back to it.
column3: Disenfranchisement laws are disproportionately discriminatory against African-Americans. Republicans are on a mission to disenfranchise minorities.

column2: While not all former inmates truly "learn their lesson," I do believe more former inmates come to realize what they've done wrong and desire to live a better life post-time served. It is most unfortunate they are almost always denied of a being able to start a new life solely based on the basis of the fact that they are a "felon." As a current resident in the Commonwealth of Virginia, today I am grateful "Virginia's Governor Terry McAuliffe just restored voting rights to more than 200,000 convicted felons." (source: NYT). People change; people change daily. Before denying a convicted felon of any and all of his/her privileges (e.g. voting rights), why not consider the fact that he/she did serve time of which, was deemed sufficient for his/her crime before coming to a firm decision that convicted felons should not have the right to vote?
column3: While not every person who has served a jail sentence has reformed I believe many realize the wrong they have done and strive to be better. People can change and grow over time, once their time is served they deserve to have their rights back.

column2: Isn't federalism wonderful. States can be laboratories for democracy, ... except when they do something judged inappropriate. Can we expect Roger Clegg and his friends to take up the fight to deny felons the votes in Maine and Vermont, which do not disenfranchise their felons at all, or in the states that re-enfranchise their felon on release from prison. More importantly, it's time to ensure that the census counts incarcerated felons at their place of last residence rather than their prison? Counting the incarcerated at their prisons boosts the legislative representation of the prison areas at the expense of the prisoners' real neighborhoods.
column3: Prisoners being counted at their prison instead of their home impacts legislative representation.

column2: So this thesis is "Once a felon, always a felon?" The stated purpose of incarceration correction. In California it is the CDC or California Department of Corrections, not the prison department. A convict is released, put on parole, satisfies the requirements, and is expected to become a normal member of society. But at the same time loses certain right that other citizens have. He/she is in effect no longer a whole citizen, even after having paid satisfied the conditions imposed by the court. So even though his behavior has been corrected he/she is treated as uncorrected. Worse yet, in many cases they can not get certain work, are relegated to the lower levels of society, yet expected to be productive. So what is the purpose of conviction and incarceration? Some may be career criminals, but as we have seen fr to many times, most are not, but in many cases return to crime as that is what they know best. What we see here is a call for permanent retribution, no matter the crime.
column3: Felons should have the same rights as citizens. He/she is in effect no longer a whole citizen, even after having paid satisfied the conditions imposed by the court. Though his behavior has been corrected he/she is treated as uncorrected.

column2: I believe it's true that Prozac along with talk therapy has been more effective than either alone for many depressed people. And not years of psychoanalysis either, but limited time cognitive therapy. The Prozac lessens the feeling of being out of control, subject to moods with little power over them. Then once that takes effect, the person can benefit from therapy, gaining some objectivity and distance from what had previously overwhelmed them. This may suffice, and also lead to taking positive steps to improve their lives, which would have been impossible without the stabilizing effect of Prozac drugs. Budget cutting has lessened availability of mental health treatment, leading to crime, violence, family pathology and incarceration. We should study the methods used in the many countries with universal tax supported health care. What are their mental health budgets, and how do they treat with Prozac type drugs and therapy where needed? Have these countries reduced funding for mental health as part of a spending austerity campaigns?
column3: The combination of Prozac and talk therapy have been very effective for many depressed people. Prozac helps people perform well in therapy by controlling their overwhelming moods and help them make positive improvements in their lives.

column2: My pursuit of my 'right weight' also includes a daily cardio & weightlifting routine, cycling (18-20 miles a trip), hiking (6-10 miles) and the like when I'm not in the gym, visits with my physician, a nutritionist (confirming my already stellar diet) and an endocrinologist. And here I sit still, @ a 35 BMI. There are nights I've cried myself to sleep, exhausted and sore while my body mocks my attempts to reach my 'right' BMI. And while I will likely never, ever get there, I take comfort in my fitness. Yes, FITNESS. My blood sugars are stellar, my cholesterol good, blood pressure low and resting heart rate my doctor's envy. Are all obese people this way? Of course not. But as discussed now, I would be labeled a high medical risk for 'failing to be thin' and fair game for discrimination. Tell me how these things would apply to ME, oh sage ones who think everyone is fat because they want to be.
column3: Despite some peoples vigorous efforts to be healthy they cannot lose weight. I am in good health as measured by certain parameters. Obese people are still people who have rights.

column2: More legislation, more lawsuits, are not the answer. Let's be clear. Many people with real disabilities - people who have lost a limb, for example, or who are partially sighted - deserve and need legal protection against discrimination. But obesity is not in the same league. It's a lifestyle choice.
column3: People with real disabilities - people who have lost a limb, or partially sighted - deserve and need legal protection against discrimination. Obesity is not in the same league. Obesity is a choice, not something forced on someone.

column2: Churches SHOULD do this, employers SHOULD do that, insurance companies SHOULD do this! Everyone should do something except the person who weighs too much for his or her own good and who, as a result of excess weight, increases health care costs for society as a whole. You don't need money to walk more and eat less.
column3: Obese individuals should care for themselves both for their own health and the economic burden on society as a whole. Good health can be obtained without money.

column2: Obese people live difficult lives to be sure, but pointing the finger at genetics or saying they are discriminated against is simply avoiding the ugly truth. They are addicts - plain and simple. Obesity is no more a disability than someone with a drug problem. You say genetics are to blame? Same for someone who has an addictive personality who turns to illicit drugs or alcohol. In the end, they may not be personally to blame, in full, but when it comes to drugs, you can fire the abuser instantly without repercussions. Obese people are of the same ilk, except that their drug of choice is food. All the nonsense about slowed metabolisms due to defective thyroids is nothing more than smoke in mirrors. Anyone can lose weight - even lying still in bed. So, the real question isn't about discrimination, it's about leveling the playing field. If you have an addiction, any addiction, you should be treated equally in the workplace.
column3: Obesity is not a disability, just as addiction isn't. A person with an addiction, which includes addiction to food, should be treated equally in the workplace.

column2: Could someone explain to how "see the doctor more than people of normal weight" is proven by "persons who are obese spent $1,429 (42 percent) more for medical care?" Yes, being obese increases the risk of major hospitalization, but so does many other factors. Do we increase rates on a sliding scale based on weight? Oh, that extra five pounds after the holidays is goin' cost you. Are we also advocating forced retirements to reduce medical costs? How about genetic testing prior to being hired? Could we require listing your family medical history on the job application? Could we charge you more for insurance if you purchased a motorcycle, or a sports car, or a ski boat, or an ATV? What about TV, could we monitor your viewing time, and charge you more if you don't get enough exercise? Could we require tests of your spouse or kids? Your 150 lb, 10 year old has been dropped from your plan. This type of thought is insane.
column3: Obesity is just another health problem that leads to hospitalization. Rates should not be increased on a sliding scale based on weight, as even a small weight gain could cost you. People should undergo genetic testing as a part of the hiring process.

column2: During my career as a college administrator I interviewed my fair share of obese job applicants for professional positions. Regardless of their intellect or job experience, there was no chance of their being hired. Why? Because they couldn't fit in the chairs at the conference table where search committees met. They sat on the edge of chairs and almost fell forward trying to balance, which didn't do much for their concentrating on complex question from faculty members. They were constantly out of breath, and sweating, and struggled to reach for the glass of water set before them. They could barely walk to various sites around campus for a required tour, and in some cases, wouldn't even try. They shuffled down the halls while their fit escorts waited, if not patiently, certainly politely. Faculty and other professional jobs require energy and stamina. No amount of intellect can overcome these kinds of self-induced problems, and discrimination is really irrelevant in such cases when one considers the terrible burden such people impose on employers.
column3: These people have self induced problems that over rule any of their intellect. Obese people are burdens on employers because of health insurance costs.

column2: Obesity is a complex problem that cannot simply be reduced to eating too much. Genetics, some mental illnesses and medications are often factors. There are other factors that we do not yet know about. Obesity seems to be the last great bastion of acceptable prejudice in our society. Derision and prejudice that is now unacceptable (and rightly so) for blacks, gays, the disabled and other minority groups apparently is still okay for our obese citizens. Maybe we should think about that.
column3: Obesity is not as simple as just eating too much. Other groups have been protected, so our obese citizens should be as well.

column2: All this hand wringing over the plight of the obese! I think the bottom line is that asking people to take responsibility for their health, in the light of so called "Societal problems/mass obesity" theory is just a joke. If you want action, do something that rewards the behavior you seek to reinforce - lower health care premiums if you drop weight. If I hear another person claim that "this is my natural weight and I'm comfortable with it" I'm going to be sick. Just wait and see if your knees are comfortable toting around an extra 50 pounds over a lifetime...
column3: We should reward those who exhibit the behavior we choose such as lower premiums for those who lose weight. I get annoyed hearing people say that their weight is natural.

column2: I was obese. Then, undergraduate school and white crosses changed that. I am aware that my opinion will be challenged, but we should not discriminate in any manner against obesity. Why? Because it's not the right way to treat people. All of the evidence presented in this debate is valid. Particularly that on the costs of our health and its burden on others. I do not believe that there is one obese person that would choose to remain obese if a miracle drug could return them to a normal weight. Obesity is a physical and an emotional nightmare. It eats at you (no pun intended) every hour of the day. We have irrefutable proof that it's thoroughly toxic, in every sense of the word. And yes, we should, as a people, be nutritionally sophisticated. Yet, we're not - we're nowhere near. But, by adopting many of these reforms and legislating stiff penalties, we are just going too far. Have we sunk so low that we are now to make laws and develop policies against the physique of our neighbor? The very thought is insane. There are better ways to solve this problem.
column3: This would simply be treating people unfairly. I don't think Obese people would remain obese if there were a drug to make them a normal weight. There is proof that this idea is terrible. It is low to develop laws against the bodies of people.

column2: Our American life style is an agenda for soda , fast food with too much sit time at work then at home have made us the Fat Nation we are today. It's a math problem - calories in and calories burned . many take Easy street which ends up being a Dead End. But , there is alot of money made off these products , soda , diet plans & services like the doctors who treat fat people . As another reader said : It all gets down to making choices , the right choices. To some , it easier to pick up fast food and harder to pass by - go home and make a healthy dinner tonight. Cooking burns calories.
column3: America is an obese nation because our lifestyles revolve around unhealthy foods and sitting. Obese people should not be protected from discrimination by businesses because they are responsible for their condition.

column2: Apparently self discipline is a thing of the past -- and the whole country is paying for it. These undisciplined people will eventually use up all of our Medicare and Medicaid money -- a person can only hope not to get cancer, break a leg, or have any expensive medical problems in the future -- as there won't be any money left to pay for them.
column3: The unhealthy people in question are drains on the system.

column2: All the medical evidence points to the fact that it's nearly impossible to keep off weight once lost. The body just won't let you. This is incorrect, and could lead to fatalism that could harm people who are overweight. For example, I lost 70 pounds. That was at least a year ago. It has not come back. It is easy to keep off. The studies to which you refer examine calorie restriction diets, which do not work because they induce a starvation-like state that leads to metabolic changes. Changing the *types* of foods we eat is far more productive. There's evidence that eliminating wheat alone will reduce the number of calories people eat by an average of 300 a day. Exercise has also been shown to help prevent the return of weight, though it isn't useful as a weight loss tool. Sadly, what is known today is far different from the older diet and exercise advice that many still follow.
column3: Overweight people can lose weight. We know more today than older diet and exercise advice told us.

column2: I see a procession of overweight, obese, and morbidly obese women in my practice which includes the cure of stress urinary incontinence. I refuse to hitch up the bladder neck of obese women (Body mass index>31). I ask them to lose 30 lbs because 30% will be cured without an operation. I have had a death in my practice because of a pulmonary embolus which is a risk of obesity. A few comply, get their BMI below 31 and I operate if they continue to have a favorable trajectory. I seem to be alone in this practice. One academic told me that if he discriminated against the obese "he could not earn a living (sic!)". I think M.D.'s are mostly in cahoots with the MacDonalds of the world in ignoring the obesity epidemic. I think employers should discriminate but they should start with the CEO of publicly traded corporations and media comentators. Some of the CNBC crowd is overweight. They should slim down and then go after the CEO's by publishing their BMI's. I think the effects on the general population would be rapid.
column3: As a doctor I have seen a death caused by obesity which is an avoidable risk. The obesity epidemic is ignored by Doctors and McDonalds.

column2: While true that some people are genetically predisposed toward excessive weight gain with the same fatty diet, employers should not be held accountable for the poor choices these individuals make. Doing so, would be another step away from personal responsibility which is so badly lacking in America today.
column3: Obese is a disease treat it the same in stages higher stages means i am no longer in control help. It would be another step away from personal responsibility, which is lacking in America today.

column2: I did not have a weight problem growing up, was a cheerleader in high school, and led an active life in college. I have scoliosis, sciatica, severe osteoarthritis, osteoporosis, spinal stenosis, osteopenia, psoriatic arthritis, lupus, have also been bone on bone on both knees since 1997 and need a knee replacement. On a pain scale from 1-10, I am probably at 12 or 13 all day long. I am 5'3" and weigh 250 pounds. I can walk about 100 feet without my cane and can stand for about 5 minutes. I am now a Type 2 diabetic because of the weight and I consume no more than 900 healthy, yes healthy, calories a day to maintain this weight. The weight is due to the lack of exercise and, for obvious reasons, I cannot do that any longer. I am not a stupid person (have a high IQ), am not lazy or indolent, but, in the past, have had to work three times harder than the normal person to prove that I was worthy of being considered, at the very least - a human being. There are many more out there like me and we should not be judged by appearances.
column3: Obese people are not stupid or lazy, they must work harder to prove their worth. We should be judged on more than our appearance.

column2: Whatever obesity is or isn't, it is an economic factor in the globalized market place. If it adds an ultimate cost to US products and services, then it decreases the US competitive advantage and thus negatively affects the US economy. You can argue about all the other factors for as long as you want, but, you can't get around this one!
column3: It is something that affects economics. This decreases competition which could negatively affect the economy.

column2: We are so becoming a failing nation. Between the rights of illegals and uneducated and now obese are claimimg rights, we will never survive as a country because the ills of the country will never ever keep the country going.
column3: Illegal residents, the uneducated, and the obese claiming rights threatens the survival of the country.

column2: Penalizing the obese? What about the penalty employers must pay for hiring obese people? How is that fair? Why should the employer foot the bill? Who should pay the price? How about the responsible party? Why isn't it fair to ask the person responsible for the increased cost to pay it, rather than ask the employer, who has no control over the employee's lifestyle choices, to pay the increased cost?
column3: Companies have a right to align themselves with healthier individuals if they so choose, which doesn't penalize obese people but instead might motivate them. It is unfair that employers must pay a penalty for hiring obese people. If you are obese, you should be responsible for paying the overage costs associated with insurance, not the employer who has no control over your life.

column2: My understanding is that college athletic teams were started to teach leadership, discipline and teamwork to students. With the introduction of the athletic scholarship schools went down the slippery slope of bringing in kids who either were not prepared to do collegiate work or had no serious intent of gaining a degree. Instead of being a benefit to the academic student body, athletics became something more geared toward the fan in the stands and the alumni association- students be damned. What Spelman has done is right in so many ways. The new program will benefit all students, will open new friendships among students and will give students valuable training in how to maintain a healthy body for a lifetime. Truth be told, intramural athletics can provide the same benefits to the student body as varsity and can engage many more students at a far lower price. The fitness program is wonderful.
column3: Sports programs teach important things like leadership, discipline, and teamwork. Sports programs in undergraduate schools should not be dropped since the new program stands to benefit all students and con provide the students opportunities for friendships and increased health.

column2: I agree with this 100 percent. Growing up overseas, I played sports w/ a German city club. Not only is it separate from school, but it allows kids to sample a wide diversity of sports (e.g. squash, handball, track. fencing) in addition to the standard.
column3: In Germany as a kid I played sports with a city club and had access to a larger sampling of sports.

column2: I would agree that the Division III model makes more sense than Division I or II, but I'd still ask, why is even that much a good use of educational funding? University should be about education. The European model where sports clubs are sponsored by cities or municipalities allows people who want the chance to participate in competitive athletics, at zero cost in distraction to the mission of their universities. That's even better than Division III.
column3: Sports programs are not a good use of education funding. Sports programs are not what universities are there for. Other institutions can provide would-be college athletes with the same athletic opportunities without imposing costs on the universities.

column2: I have a son who has participated in DIII cross country and track and field for the past four years. It has been a wonderful experience for him; he loves the competition and the team spirit, but everyone understands that academics comes first.
column3: School sports have a place as long as academics come first.

column2: Why wasn't Reed College in Oregon not included in this discussion? As long as I can remember, this elite liberal arts college in Oregon has advertised its non-participation in intercollegiate athletics, offering only intramural sports. Theirs, I believe, is an ideological choice (and one with which I agree). I believe that sports has no place in schools and even less of a place in universities. Make sports part of the community, as is done in places such as Germany.
column3: Sports should be part of the community, not part of school.

column2: Sounds like I need to go back and polish my early 60's hack speech class "persuasive" contribution - questioning the role of football on college campuses (school wasn't in any major sports conference) with half the football team in the class. It was interesting - at same time my sister was photographed at a "Ban the Ball" demo at the UofC campus. The purpose of higher education is, in large part, teaching a young person how to approach learning and apply that learning to life as it unfolds. Sports on an intramural level or low key interscholastic plane have a place - but not the spectacle of college sports serving as the training ground for professional teams. I always cringe when Americans justify marginal enterprises, products that really shouldn't exist, extreme sports, etc. with the usual "but some people make a lot of money doing it". Is that all there is???
column3: The purpose of higher education is teaching and applying that learning to life. Intramural and interscholastic have a place but not college sports which just train athletes for professional teams.

column2: I'm not sure what Mr. Clotfelter means when he states: "Virtually every college with a dormitory gives its students the chance to play sports." I'm guessing he refers to inter-dorm, intramural sports that many schools have. Data collected by the U.S. Department of Education clearly don't show this level of participation in intercollegiate sports. Only 8 percent of college men and 5 percent of college women participate in those sports. The data also show that intercollegiate sports programs are quite expensive. When I looked at 2003 Big Ten data, I conservatively calculated that intercollegiate sports added between 400 to 800 dollars to other students' annual costs. Mr. Clotfelter assumes that big-time competitive sports can only function as they are currently structured. He states that "there is no going back." How about going forward? How about spinning off the profit makers (men's football and basketball) as university-owned semipro operations totally independent of the NCAA and educational regulations? Such a change would free the university from the requirement of pouring its earnings into the athletic department's money-losing sports and allow it to reduce its tuition bills for everybody.
column3: Only a small percentage of college students participate in sports. Data shows that intercollegiate sports programs are quite expensive. College sports make tuition higher. If universities drop money-losing sports they can use that money to reduce tuition.

column2: Boy, is this asinine. The commodification of everything, the thimble-witted emphasis on turning everything, including research universities, into a "brand", is precisely the problem. The fact that high-stakes college athletics are in synergy with this larger trend is no recommendation in their favor. As to the idea that "there is no going back", well, that's pretty feeble, too. In 1988 in Moscow I'm sure that most people, including everyone in the Politburo, would have told you that the Soviet system in Russia and elsewhere in Eastern Europe was so firmly ensconced in power that "there's no going back". And had you talked to them three years later?
column3: College athletics being turned into "brands" is causing universities to lose context of their true purpose.

column2: The author failed to explain why school loyalty is valuable. Nor did he address why being a cultural touchstone or a valuable brand is something to which an institution of higher education should aspire. He needs to make those arguments because big-time competitive sports cost money that could otherwise be spent on students' educations or research.
column3: School loyalty is necessarily a good thing, nor is making a school a valuable brand or cultural commodity. If they didn't have to spend money on competitive sports it could be spent on research and education.

column2: College sports are almost a case of the tail wagging the dog. They end up dictating student life in many cases, lead to undesirable behaviors (from riots to binge drinking), and negatively affect students' ability to focus on academics. On good years, sports do just enough to fund themselves. During bad result spells, they end up eating up significant amounts of money. It's hard to get rid of them, especially at big state schools, because many donors seem to identify more with the teams than with the university. I'd either go the Division III route, and also provide the option for the teams to go pro while paying a license fee to the college for use of their logo and name. Pay the athletes, give them contracts, and keep the finances of the teams and the schools separate.
column3: Sports in college are extraneous and have inappropriate impact on academic issues. Sports take over student life and cause bad behavior and an inability to focus on academics. If sports preform well, they can fund themselves. Sports programs spend a lot of money, but often they attract donors.

column2: For a small college dropping such sports programs is probably wise but for the big schools, it's not. The Penn State scandal brought out all the reasons that intermural athletics which draws popular audiences can undo an institution of higher learning. The enormous amounts of money from the media, media sponsors, alumni and fans of the sports programs led to the University finding itself incapable of dealing with a serial pedophile on it's staff. But these programs do bring lots of revenue which all of the other activities of a University simply don't. There are no taxpayers in this country willing to support the education of other peoples children, anymore. The costs of going from papers and books to electronic communications as well as the collapse of actual wealth creation in this country has raised the costs of doing everything that Universities do. The revenues from NCAA athletics are very important.
column3: These programs bring lots of revenue, which all of the other activities of a University simply don't. No taxpayers in this country are willing to support the education of other peoples children. The move from paper to electronic communication and the lack of wealth creation has made university more expensive. Sports should stay because revenues generated by college athletics are important to universities.

column2: What is it about a good football team that exerts such a pull on alums? Why...would sophisticated erudite people invest so much emotion in the outcome of a game played by...20-year-olds? (Because)...we are bonded by common experience, and when the attachment originates with our school, the effect is powerful. We want to exult...in that feeling that comes with being part of a successful 'tribe'. A sports team represents everyone in the group, and serves as an agent of togetherness. Doesn't matter what your politics are, or where you're from, or what your job is--everyone can stand shoulder to shoulder and cheer for the Cardinal...We care, more than we usually want to admit, about what happens when those 20-year-olds take the football field on our behalf every Saturday. For those few hours, they are us and we are them. From "Stanford", a publication of the Stanford Alumni Association, November/December, 2011 My sentiments, precisely.
column3: Common experience bonds humans, and the effect is powerful when the attachment originates with our school. Sports teams represent a sense of togetherness and bring people together every Saturday on a football field. The public can live vicariously through the sports teams.

column2: Israeli universities are serious academic institutions with some sports for fitness and recreation, but little in the way of organized competition. After the army, students are ready to begin real life: get a career, get married, and go to work (often while they are at college). They seem undiminished by the lack of sports in their life and their schools set an example of what American college life could be if it were cured of sports mania. Bravo for Spellman and other schools that divest from intercollegiate sport and reinvest in the education, health, and maturation of their students. Their graduates will have an edge because of it.
column3: In Israel, the lack of organized collegiate sports does not impact the education or lives of graduates. Schools that divest in intercollegiate sports, and invest in education, health and their students will turn out more competitive students.

column2: As a former Big Ten athlete, I find the idea of eliminating sports and replacing them with wellness programs flat out ridiculous. Those who do not compete in sports have no true understanding of what they do for you. Highly competitive sports really helps you learn to compete in the business world far more than those who have never been part of competitive sports can ever understand. It gives you the energy and will to compete and succeed. At my Alma-mater, student athletes have a significantly higher graduation rate than the general student body. It's no mystery as to why. You learn discipline and purpose. At my school there are many athletic facilities for those not on varsity teams that if they are out of shape, they have only themselves to blame. There is a huge variety of intramural sports, exercise facilities that include weight rooms, pools, running tracks, a golf course, etc.. You can lead a horses to water, but you can't make them drink.
column3: Sports have a place and serve a purpose, they are necessary to learn certain skills. Highly competitive sports helps you learn to compete in the business world. Far more than those who have never been part of competitive sports can understand. Sports programs teach competition and the will to succeed. From what I have seen student athletes graduate at a higher rate than everyone else. Sports teach discipline and purpose.

column2: I taught at a couple universities. Often I'd be asked by parents of college age kids about where to send their kids. My quick response was usually, "send them North to a school that does not have a winning football team. Poor athletics departments usually means better funding for everything else."
column3: Money from discontinued sports funds other activities.

column2: Playing Varsity Lacrosse in college saved me. It was the very best thing I could have done. It kept me focused, gave me a great group of friends, challenged me both physically and mentally, taught me a lot about trust and teamwork and propelled me through school. It was an incredible outlet for my energy and competitive spirt. I still to this day, believe many of my personal and professional strengths were developed by playing sports. The NCAA, without a doubt, needs to change. There is far too much money spent around the NCAA and the culture at top levels can be nasty and unattractive. But that doesn't that mean that Varsity Sports should be cut from colleges and that Varsity athletes should be punished. The NCAA needs reform as a whole-- sports need to be taken off the peddle stool that they currently stand on. But the importance of sports for many shouldn't be forgotten-- it is just as important as the arts and academia. The debate shouldn't be if varsity sports should be cut-- but how to reform the NCAA so that all schools can keep varsity sports without spending so much money.
column3: Sports programs should not be dropped in undergraduate schools because playing varsity lacrosse was great for me as it kept me focused, provided friends, challenged physically and mentally, and taught lessons of trust and teamwork. Sports helped me both personally and professionally. Arts and academia are important but sports should not be placed by the wayside.

column2: Sports is big business...Great...Move it out of ALL SCHOOLS and into other plces. I wish our local schools would get out of sports, as we spend mch to much money on a few gifted athletes and almost nothing on our gifted students.
column3: Sports is a business and should not be involved in educational institutions. Local schools should get out of sports. Too much money is spent on a few gifted athletes while almost nothing is spent on gifted students.

column2: More than half a century ago, Robert Maynard Hutchins observed that intercollegiate athletics bears the same relation to education as bull fighting to agriculture. He then shut down the program. RMH, where are you, now that we really need you?
column3: sports in college are as important education as bull fighting is to agriculture.

column2: It is a no-brainer - of course college sports should be eliminated. They have nothing to do with education nor with college. They are simply money-machines and training facilities for professional teams. Ms. Tatum from Spelman is right on the money: college sports have nothing to do with physical fitness, except for the few so-called students who participate in those sports. The TV and sports betting world benefit far more from college sports than do the athletes.
column3: Sports programs have nothing to do with education. Sports programs do not benefits colleges. College sports only benefit a few, who are barely students in their own right, leading to little value for other students. Gamblers and TV benefit from college sports more than the players.

column2: intercollege sports should be eliminated so that costs for an education can drop. physical education on campus should concentrate on teaching stretching and personal physical conditioning. intramural sports are fine. the huge expense of facilities and time and money spent flying around make off campus sports in this environment out of date
column3: Eliminating sports programs would make college more affordable. Campuses should focus more on teaching stretching and personal conditioning than sports. Off-campus sports require a huge outlay of time and money for transportation and are out of date.
